TALK.START.PARA: —I was attracted to an article which appeared in the Melbourne Age on Tuesday, 2 May 1995. The headline read `The rains to end the heart-breaker drought'. I can attest that it has not broken the drought in central Victoria. It has rained water, but it has not rained any money. The farmers in my area will have no income for at least nine months. They are now at the stage of trying to put in a crop. It is costing them between $20,000 and $25,000 for fuel, for superphosphate and for the time and effort spent putting that crop in. It will be at least nine months before they receive any income.

PARA.TAB: My concern about this article in the Age was that it raised speculation that the federal government would not provide any drought assistance to the area of central and northern Victoria. The article reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it does jeopardise the state's chances—
the state of Victoria—
of receiving federal drought assistance, due to be decided by the Minister for Primary Industries, Senator Collins, later this month.

I want to impress upon the House that the drought has not ended in north-central Victoria. It is absolutely essential that the people in that area, the farming community, do receive some federal government support. The Victorian state government has done its part; it is now up to the federal government to do its part. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, you will notice that I am wearing a badge on my lapel this morning. In Victoria all the state Liberal members have this badge of Victoria. I have got one too, only it is upside down. The reason for that is Victoria is in a state of distress. I will continue to wear this while it is being governed by the Kennett government.

PARA.TAB: Let me give the House a couple of examples. The Kennett government has been flogging off all our schools in Victoria. Eighty-nine schools have been sold and closed, and $127 million has been raised by the Kennett government from the sale of those schools. While the government raised only $127 million, let me say that the developers made $500 million.

Who are these developers? One developer is the mob called Baillieu Knight Frank—the biggest salesmen of all these schools. Who is Baillieu Knight Frank? The president of the Victorian branch of the Liberal Party is Mr Baillieu. He has made a fortune out of flogging off all of our schools. The other big winner is Hudson Conway. Hudson Conway has always had links with the Liberal Party. It is the mob which has actually developed these sites. So Jeffrey Kennett is once again looking after his mates.

Jeffrey Kennett is one of the biggest con men anywhere in Victoria or Australia. I will continue to wear this badge upside down to show that Victoria is in distress, and the sooner we get rid of that government the better. I am quite pleased to say that John Brumby will, after the next election, be the next Premier of Victoria. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The fudge-it budget will dash the hopes of many families buying and building homes in and around Wanneroo. Building materials are going to be slugged with a 12 per cent GST—the government's GST. The pressure on interest rates for those families has not abated. Together, these two items are going to stymie the dreams of many young families who want to build a new home or, for that matter, to hold onto their existing one.

PARA.TAB: The new GST—the government's GST—on building materials will add about $2,500 to the construction cost of a $100,000 home. Interest rates show no sign of going down. In fact, we think they are going to go up very shortly. A one per cent increase on an average mortgage in my electorate will add a further $80 per month to the mortgage of young families. There are many other new taxes and charges in the budget which when added together would far outweigh any possible benefit from the government's $800 baby bonus.

If the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) thinks that this is the budget that will save his bacon he is mistaken. This is a budget filled with porky pies and fudged figures. The electors in my electorate of Moore will see through the government's deception. Many of them have to have a motor vehicle to travel to work. The $1,000 increase to the cost of new vehicles will raise the cost of used cars as well. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few positive comments about the tourism industry on the central north coast of New South Wales. The electorate of Paterson takes in the bottom section of this area. Last week I was very pleased that the Minister for Communications and the Arts and the Minister for Tourism (Mr Lee) came to the Hunter region to announce a couple of grants: one grant of $160,000 to the Maitland City Council and another of $155,000 to the Great Lakes Council.

PARA.TAB: Each of these grants will trigger development on a much larger scale because the funds will be matched by each of those councils. Each site will be the centre of a new work opportunities program giving job opportunities for young people who are unemployed currently in those areas. This is an example of how various departments of this government are working together in very intelligent ways to create employment and to promote tourism. The member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) understands that tourism is a major growth industry in this area, and it is certainly being promoted in a most sensible way by this government and creating jobs while doing so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it fascinating that the member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) would be concerned about the way that the current Victorian government is working. I think he has a case of Alzheimer's disease, frankly. He really needs to look at the similarities between this government and the Cain-Kirner government of Victoria he seemed to talk so loudly about. Some people may remember the state Treasurer in Victoria writing the letter in support of the Pyramid Building Society. There are some similarities between that and the letter that has gone out in the prospectus from the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and between the selling off of the trains and other assets in Victoria and the selling off of Comcar.

PARA.TAB: When you look at the excesses in expenditure and the way it was able to cover those, you will see that all it did to provide for that was to sell off assets. In this budget $5.3 billion is raised by selling off assets. The real question is: next year when we are trying to look at a budget, what will you sell off to provide for your programs again?

The reality is that, if we are going to solve the problems in this country, we have to look at genuine budgets, not fudged ones. We need to have budgets that provide funding, not from the sell-off of assets but from the collection of funds, or have a serious look at the range of services that are being provided. I suggest that the member for Dunkley start to have a serious look at the way—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to report the successful opening of the Australian South Sea Islander exhibition at the Rockhampton City Art Gallery on 5 May. This is a display mounted by the National Maritime Museum and funded by our government as part of our package of recognition of South Sea Islander Australians in this country, following the tabling of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report The call for recognition.

PARA.TAB: I congratulate my South Sea Islander community in Central Queensland for its enthusiastic support for this exhibition. I opened this exhibition in Brisbane on behalf of the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney) in October of last year. I was able to say to the many people who attended the opening in Rockhampton that we had a value added exhibition because many extra artefacts and paintings were donated for the special opening at Rockhampton.

I was delighted to see at the opening Ms Zena O'Donnell, who is the recipient of one of the cultural awards which will enable her to go back to her Pacific island of origin to study her family origins. This is part of a whole package that we have put in place to make sure that a very belated recognition of South Sea Islanders in our community is at last taking place. There was a great deal of pride and enthusiasm from the community at the Rockhampton launch.

I also pay tribute to Mabel Edmund, a painter and writer from Central Queensland who has been a very important leader in this community over a long period. It was delightful to see many of her paintings at the exhibition. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to turn the mood of the chamber from the aggression and humour we have just had to a more sober subject. This morning I would like to grieve about the state of the administration of family law in Australia, which, frankly, is approaching proportions of a modern horror story. The subject of family law—and I am not just talking about the Family Court and the Child Support Agency; they are part of the overall story—is something that is touching an increasing number of people in our community today.

PARA.TAB: In the last week or so it has perhaps been given a particular prominence through a dispute, carried on through the media, between the head of the Family Court, Justice Nicholson, and the chair of the parliamentary committee conducting a review into family law, the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price). Whilst I do not agree with every comment the member for Chifley made in a recent speech, I have some sympathy, as many members in this place will have, with his clear frustration at the administration of the Family Court and the fact that, quite manifestly, in the view of many of us, it is not functioning very effectively. I would also have to say to him that, as the chair of a committee currently conducting an inquiry, it was probably somewhat imprudent of him to make those views on the public record at this particular point in time.

It was also interesting, however, to see the response of Justice Nicholson. He got very heated and upset about those remarks. I have noticed on previous occasions, when people had the unmitigated gall in a democracy to actually question the operation of the Family Court, that Justice Nicholson frequently gets very upset and disputes other people's rights to make any comment, constructive or otherwise; but he, himself, is quite happy to enter into the public debate. I would suggest to him that if he wants to enter into the public debate he must expect some robust responses from time to time.

It seems to me that for most people who come into contact with family law in this country, in one form or another, there are very few at an operating level who would have a view other than that it is a mess. What is not in dispute is that the Family Law Act and the Family Court do not really operate in an effective way and the Child Support Agency continues to be an absolute shambles.

I think government administration is lacking here. It is a major area that affects a lot of people. I think the government has some responsibility to start doing something about the situation. The slowness of government to move; the slowness of government to respond to reports; the slowness of government to bring forward meaningful legislation, I believe, is doing lasting damage to our community. The costs for the individual man or woman who comes into contact with the family law system in this country are considerable. The grief and personal upset for not only adults but also children are, I believe, unacceptable. The delays are often horrendous and quite frequently we actually see injustices done.

I might add that as a member of parliament, as with all members, I would spend a lot of time with constituents on issues affecting the family law system in this country. I have also been through the Family Court and experienced some of the problems. It is interesting to note that some 40 per cent of people in this country are going to finish up in the Family Court in one form or another by the end of this century. So we are not talking about an area of administration that affects a small minority. We are talking about something that affects a large number of people. Therefore, it is more deserving of attention from the government.

Recently a parliamentary research service report Australian family law: some current issues, by Dr Juliet Behrens, a consultant to the law and public administration group, was released. I certainly do not have time this morning to go through the details of what she talks about and her findings, but I will say that she raises great concerns. It seems to me to be a pretty well reasoned paper. In it she states:

SPEECH.PARA: . There needs to be greater coordination between the two levels of government on "family law issues"
. The Commonwealth Government should legislate for a broader range of relationships than is currently the case
. A great deal more should be done to change the rhetoric of children's rights in family law into reality
. The recommendations of the ALRC's report on Equality before the Law: Justice for Women, concerning the treatment of violence in the home in family law should be legislated
. The FLA—
that is, the Family Law Act—
should be amended to make it clear that violence in the home is relevant in determining how property should be divided on marriage breakdown.

I am not saying that I support all the conclusions that she has come to but she has highlighted a number of very relevant issues that we need to talk about. Frequently when constituents come into my office—and I am sure you, Mr Speaker, and many other honourable members in this place have experienced this—they are concerned about costs. The costs to deal in the family law area these days are just phenomenal. Unfortunately, for many people, it is money that they do not have.

PARA.TAB: The time scales are horrendous. It can take months just to get a hearing to get something ratified, or agreed to. The inconsistency of decisions means that you really do not know what is going to happen in your case. People in identical circumstances with the same judge being heard on different days have had different decisions made, so the lawyers who specialise in the field do not really know how to advise you.

In my own personal case I had a solicitor who said, `Frankly, it depends on which judge you happen to draw.' There is no consistency in the rulings. There is no guidance as to what the situation is. When we went to court and saw our barrister for the first time on the morning of the case he said, `I really don't know whether we are going to do very well today or not because it'll depend on which court we are allocated.' We then found out which judge we had got and he said he thought we would probably be all right.

For your case to depend on the whim of the judge, the luck of the draw as to which court you get, the state you go to, the judge who happens to be on duty that day or whether the judge got out on the right side of the bed, is an appalling state of affairs. There is need for some consistency and some guidelines to avoid a lot of the aggravation and difficulty and to ease the pain of people seeking advice and going through the process.

I also want to say a couple of words about the counselling and mediation services that are available through the Family Court. One of the problems is that it is very difficult to get an appointment within several weeks. An emotional situation is quite often involved with a couple who have separated and are perhaps having a dispute over the children. They cannot afford to sit around having the next world war while waiting for the counselling services to become available.

Counsellors have been known to take sides. They do not necessarily stand up afterwards to back up agreements made in those counselling sessions. One of the major problems in that whole counselling and mediation area is that usually the articulate person comes out the best, and that often is reflected in subsequent orders in the court. Where there is a power imbalance in the relationship, the weaker member may not be in the wrong but often loses because of his or her inability to be articulate or because of a lack of financial resources. The Family Court does not seem to acknowledge that situation in its administration of these matters.

There is a major failure in the way the court is organised, apart from the fact that when you go there you might have to wait for an hour or five hours before your case is even called, which is often bad news for people travelling interstate, those who have jobs or those with scarce resources. The failure is that the court itself does not carry out its own instructions. I know one notable case where a judge said in June, `I want this case brought back to me in November so that I can make a decision by December and the children's schooling will not be affected when the decision becomes operable in January.' The court administration did not even bother to bring the case forward and look at it until December and a date was set for the following March, which immediately destroyed the prospects of making any suitable schooling arrangements. I could go on.

Whilst I do not agree with the honourable member for Chifley in some areas, I think he makes a fundamental point that I would certainly commend Justice Nicholson to take on board. That point is that there are many administrative problems with the family law in this country. We all know about the Child Support Agency, but the Family Court administration, not just the law, needs to be sorted out. I urge the government to give it urgent attention. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —`It's a bloody disgrace' were the words I used at Anzac Cove in the early hours of 25 April 1995 to describe a situation which, to my mind and those of many thousands of other Australians and New Zealanders, should never have happened. As well as being the 50th anniversary of the end of hostilities in World War II, 1995 is the year we celebrate the 80th anniversary of the landing at Anzac Cove in 1915.

PARA.TAB: The federal government in its wisdom chose to honour the memory of those who fought and died at this most hallowed of places by selecting nine young Australians, descendants of the original Anzacs, to return to Gallipoli to take part in and be the focal point of the celebrations this year. They were joined by three servicemen, also direct descendants, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca), the shadow minister, the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), and their wives.

I was privileged to be part of the pilgrimage, my motivation being the fact that my late father, Robert Quick, served with the 7th Battalion at Gallipoli. All who went had in their own minds their separate and personal thoughts about what they would find on the Gallipoli Peninsula and whether the many stories they had listened to and the diaries they had read would convey the real meaning of what took place there so long ago.

The day before we left for Turkey, the pilgrims were farewelled at the Merrylands RSL by 40 World War I veterans, some of whom made the trip back to Anzac Cove five years before to celebrate the 75th anniversary. These blokes are now known as national treasures—a term coined by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. This was an emotional time for all of us as we shared their memories of a place we would soon visit. Later that evening we were feted and farewelled at a function at the Gallipoli Club in Sydney. Leaving Australia, many of us were not just carrying memorabilia from our own families, but carrying it for others in our community. They wanted us to take back to that hallowed place souvenirs, colour patches, photos, letters of loved ones and diaries of those who served there so long ago.

Touring Istanbul made us realise that we were in the streets of the city that proved so elusive for our forefathers to capture 80 years ago. It really hit us that we had finally arrived at a special part of the world when we drove through the town of Gelibolu, or Gallipoli as we know it. To actually be able to see the Sea of Marmara and the Dardanelle Straits first hand and not just from photos in books increased our enthusiasm for what lay ahead.

We, the pilgrims, were fortunate to have as our guide for the battle sites Kenan Celik, a Gallipoli historian and English teacher at one of the high schools in Canakkale. The two days prior to Anzac Day were spent exploring the various sites—Anzac Cove, Lone Pine, the Nek, Shrapnel Gully, Cape Helles and Gaba Tepe. These were very special days for each of us as we individually sought out places, graves and trenches that held memories for our relations who fought there. Kenan embellished our memories with his expert commentaries at each site and in all places enabled us to better understand what actually took place those 80 years ago.

As we returned on the ferry from the peninsula, fresh from the many memories gained as we explored the trenches, picked poppies, waded ashore at Anzac Cove, read our diaries as we sat alone by special gravestones, you can imagine that most of the touring party had started to build up expectations regarding the dawn service to be held the following morning. Most of us found it difficult to sleep that night, and it was not just because we had to get up at 3.30 a.m. to catch the ferry. All of us had attended dawn services before, but this was the special one—Anzac Cove for the 80th anniversary.

Arriving at that hallowed of all places for Australians, we were greeted by an amazing sight. Thousands, from all parts of the globe, had gathered in the darkness to participate in the ceremony. Candles flickered in the pre-dawn darkness, someone played Waltzing Matilda on a mouth organ and Australian flags fluttered in the crowd. The air was electric with expectation.

All the pilgrims braced themselves for the emotion charged ceremony that was about to envelop them. Tears glistened on cheeks as the lone piper played his mournful dirge prior to the arrival of the Governor-General. A hush gathered over the assembled throng as we waited for the official party. The last strains of the piper wafted over the darkened hills that tower over Anzac Cove.

Mindful of standing order 74, I would now like to recount how this wonderful atmosphere of solemnity and remembrance was totally destroyed by a lack of thought and understanding on the part of what I would call `the official party'. To everyone's dismay, 5.30 arrived and there was no sign of the Governor-General and the other high ranking dignitaries. There were gentle murmurings in the crowd, but because of the security and the amount of traffic on the roads we could all excuse a slight delay. Fifteen minutes passed. The soldiers were still at reverse arms with heads bowed; it was still dark but the approaching dawn light enabled us to see the outlines of the hills behind us.

The atmosphere and solemnity that is a dawn service were rapidly dissipating; tempers not only among our pilgrimage party but throughout the assembled throng became frayed. Voices could be heard expressing outrage that this service, above all others, could be desecrated in this way. `Start without them.' `It's a bloody disgrace.' `Why haven't they let us know they'll be late?' Tears of frustration could be seen running down the faces of the pilgrims as they saw the fiasco unfolding before them. `Our leaders stuffed it up before; it is happening once again,' shouted someone from the crowd.

Six-fifteen a.m., 45 minutes after the scheduled start. Dawn. Daylight bathed the thousands huddled at the cove. The dignitaries finally turned up. We were all beyond caring. We had each in our own way paid our respects to the memories of our forefathers and we went through the ceremony with our thoughts far away.

`At least we have the ceremony at Long Pine; let's forget this and concentrate on Lone Pine,' commented someone in our party. We journeyed down to the international ceremony at the Martyrs Memorial at Morto Bay, and once this concluded we headed back to Lone Pine. As I stated previously, the 75th anniversary contained the original Anzacs; the 80th has their descendants. One would rightly assume that in the Lone Pine ceremony these 12 young Australians would feature prominently, be the centrepiece of this ceremony.

Lone Pine, for those lucky enough to go there, has a haunting and wistful beauty. For me it is a special place, as my father's battalion, the 7th, fought there with distinction, winning four Victoria Crosses and losing 12 officers and 342 other ranks in these trenches. My wreath was to be placed at that beautiful place in memory of my father and his comrades, many of whom lie buried there.

After the morning fiasco at Anzac Cove, we were all looking forward to a service at Lone Pine. Because of the security evident on the peninsula, our bus arrived between five and seven minutes late. Unbelievably, the `official party', the Governor-General and the ambassador, David Evans, had decided to start without the pilgrims and the minister, those people who should have been the focal point of this wholly Australian ceremony.

Reasons for the delay in the morning ceremony were believed but not excused: protocol demanded that the dawn service commence on time irrespective of what travel arrangements had been made. Lone Pine was ours, a totally Australian affair. The ambassador knew we were not there and should have insisted that the Governor-General wait for us.

For the same officials to compound the anguish of the pilgrims was beyond belief. Our party was forced to scramble from the bus with our wreaths and hustle our way through the large crowd to find that the ceremony was almost over. I expected better of our representatives. To do this and then wholly ignore the pilgrims, and for the head of state not even to meet and talk with them, does not fit with his high office, nor the spirit of being an Australian epitomised by this hallowed place.

The feeble attempts by the Foreign Affairs officials to paper over this disaster do them little credit. I sincerely hope that any future pilgrimage will be wholly the domain of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, which recognises the importance of this place and those who fought and died there. It certainly would not put the welfare of veterans' descendants second to trade considerations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this morning's grievance debate I want to highlight a couple of things that have taken place in my part of Australia, the electorate of Lyne, on the mid-north coast. They revolve around community service obligations as far as the provision of services by government is concerned. This is a very important subject that will sift through to the higher level regarding a lot of issues of concern to the constituents in my electorate and, indeed, the taxpayers of Australia. Later this morning the Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts will table a report into the efficiency and appropriateness of the commercialisation of government business enterprises. An integral part of that report is about the identification, funding and provision of CSOs to people around Australia and particularly people in regional Australia, outside the greater metropolitan areas.

PARA.TAB: What I want to concentrate on this morning regarding the electorate of Lyne is what I perceive to be the very important community service obligations regarding the services provided by government or semi-government bodies. Since coming into this place in March 1993 I have been continually pressuring the minister for communications with regard to the extension of SBS television services into my area. They have gradually come down the coast and in the current program I believe they are being extended into the northern parts of New South Wales, but not quite down to the mid-north coast region of New South Wales. The consistent answer I get from the minister is that these decisions are made based on growth generally but particularly on population growth.

As far as I am concerned, the mid-north coast of New South Wales between Forster and Port Macquarie is experiencing enormous growth equal to that anywhere else in Australia. During the time when I received these answers from the minister for communications, SBS television services were extended into the north-west areas of Tasmania. I fail to see the growth that has taken place in the mid-north coast in New South Wales being outdone by growth taking place in north-western Tasmania. The most pressing issue at the moment is that of ABC radio services on the mid-north coast of New South Wales and regional Australia. In years gone by we have received the service in my electorate based at Kempsey, radio 2KPTR. It services an area from Coffs Harbour down to the Forster, Tuncurry and Gloucester areas.

At the end of last year I made an adjournment debate speech in this chamber about the changes being made to the services provided by ABC radio in my electorate. The position of the journalist posted at Taree, servicing Taree, Forster and Gloucester, was being relocated to Coffs Harbour. That decision has been made permanent now. So in regard to ABC radio services on the coast of New South Wales, from Lismore to Kempsey there are six journalists: at Lismore, Grafton, Coffs Harbour and Kempsey—a distance of 300 kilometres down the coast. From Kempsey to Newcastle, which covers Port Macquarie, Taree, Forster, Tuncurry, Gloucester and Bulahdelah and, I might add, down into the government-held electorate of Paterson, how many journalists are there? None. Another 300 kilometres and there are no journalists; there is no service from the ABC.

So community organisations, local government, state government bodies and representatives, federal government bodies and representatives have no access face to face with journalists to get their message across through the taxpayers' owned organisation, the ABC. That decision has been taken recently. I will reiterate it: in the 300 kilometres from Lismore to Kempsey there are six journalists. In the 300 kilometres from Kempsey to Newcastle there are no journalists. There is no service being provided in an area where there is probably a population of 200,000-odd people. I bring this to the attention of the House and I propose to raise it with the minister yet again. I know that the response I will get is that it is an ABC management decision; it has nothing to do with me. But it is of great concern to me when my constituents are trying to access information and I am doing interviews with a journalist in Coffs Harbour, 200 kilometres away.
In that speech in October 1994 on the adjournment debate, I said:
The Taree outpost services—

SPEECH.PARA: and this was at the time—

the biggest ABC audience in this region in an area which includes the fastest growing town in New South Wales—Forster/Tuncurry—the population of which grew by 30 per cent in the period 1986-91. The city of greater Taree grew by 25 per cent in that period. In contrast, Coffs Harbour—
and in due deference to my colleague the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl)—
grew by only 14 per cent . . .

And that is where this position has been relocated to. So we have the main base station at Kempsey, a journalist at Coffs Harbour and nothing at Port Macquarie, Taree or Forster-Tuncurry. I then said:
Audience response on 2KPTR is by far greatest in the region encompassing Forster/Tuncurry, Taree and Gloucester . . .

Bear in mind that part of the Forster-Tuncurry area and Gloucester are in the electorate of the member for Paterson (Mr Horne)—and I am sure that he has been made aware of the withdrawal of these services. So we have the greatest audience response in the region which has lost all the services of the journalists who have been taken out by management decision. I just highlight that.

PARA.TAB: Certainly, some of the decisions that have been taken by the ABC management as far as its radio services are concerned are very interesting. Some interesting statistics have been brought to light by the research that has been undertaken following these actions. The information coming from the department of planning indicates that the Coffs Harbour outpost covers Coffs Harbour and Bellingen, with a population of 700,400 people; the Kempsey news room covers Nambucca, Kempsey and Port Macquarie, with a population of 91,500 people; and the now closed Taree bureau, as it was, covered Taree, Forster-Tuncurry and Gloucester, with a population of 71,900 people.

New population projections about to be released by the department of planning give the following population estimates for the areas in the year 2001: Coffs Harbour, 79,000 people; Nambucca, Kempsey and Port Macquarie, 112,000 people; and Taree, Forster-Tuncurry and Gloucester, 89,000 people. The actual urban centre populations are: Coffs Harbour, 20,000; Forster-Tuncurry, 14,000; and Taree 16,000. So as to the actual population centres now, as they are serviced, there is in excess of 30,000-odd people in the Forster-Tuncurry area who have no service, and we have built up or boosted the service in Coffs Harbour where there is a population centre of 20,000 people.

It really is beyond me to understand this decision. I do not believe that the ABC is providing a service to the region that is equitable, as far as government intentions should be where community service obligations are concerned. If we look at the 1993-94 ABC annual report, the ABC's objectives are `to provide the best programs, performances, products and services it possibly can to all the people of Australia and to our target audiences overseas'. It says that it will do this by `providing the best, most reliable and independent coverage and analysis of contemporary issues, ideas and international, national and regional events'.

That begs the question: in providing the best possible products and services to all the people of Australia and to cover regional events, it is beyond me how the ABC will adequately cover on ABC radio the regional events that take place between Port Macquarie and Newcastle in the south—a distance of 300 kilometres—without any journalists, apart from the journalist based in Coffs Harbour who is actually delegated with the responsibility of covering the day-to-day events in that area. The lady is doing quite a good job; I do quite a few radio interviews. But the present situation is nothing like the situation where, upon an event occurring in Taree, we would have the local commercial radio news person turning up, the ABC news person turning up, the community FM radio news person turning up. The ABC radio news person cannot turn up because she is based at Coffs Harbour.

I believe that my area in the electorate of Lyne on the mid-north coast is being discriminated against. I cannot understand this management decision and, as far as I am concerned, it is quite inequitable. I repeat: 300 kilometres, Lismore, Grafton, Coffs Harbour, Kempsey—six journalists; Kempsey, Port Macquarie, Taree, Gloucester, Forster-Tuncurry, Bulahdelah—no journalists. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Between 21 and 26 April this year, I was privileged to represent the Speaker at the 75th anniversary of the Turkish Grand National Assembly and to participate in the commemoration of the 80th anniversary of the Anzac landing at Gallipoli. I was joined on that occasion by a number of members, including the member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), who is in the chamber today, and the member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay). Representatives from the Senate included Senator Baden Teague, Senator Grant Chapman and Senator Michael Baume and their families. It was a very moving occasion and, like most Australians who have had the opportunity to be present at Gallipoli on Anzac Day, something that all the delegation looked forward to with great anticipation.

PARA.TAB: My colleague and friend the member for Franklin (Mr Quick) had a very special reason for being there. He was part of the separate pilgrimage organised by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca). I wholeheartedly concur with the sentiments he expressed in the grievance debate this morning.

I will not dwell too much on the dawn service, but I will relay my concern and my grievance at some of the events that occurred subsequent to the dawn service. I will begin by making the point that, from about 9.30, most members of the delegation were present at the international service. The Governor-General, as the principal international representative, was able to give the speech on behalf of the international representatives at that ceremony on 25 April.

There was some distance between the Turkish memorial and the Australian memorial at Lone Pine, where a special commemoration ceremony was scheduled for later in the day. As the member for Franklin has commented, the whole point about this event was the fact that some descendants of the original Anzacs were involved in a very special pilgrimage to mark the occasion of the 80th anniversary. He has already indicated the excitement and obvious anticipation of that event.

At the time of our arrival at Lone Pine, the parliamentary delegation moved to an area near the memorial, principally because no-one from the department of foreign affairs seemed to know where we should stand. Members of the general public were positioned in an area which was roped off. At the time of our arrival the ambassador, Mr David Evans, and the Governor-General were speaking to the public, presumably waiting for the rest of the group to be in place. They had received an official escort and were in position some considerable time ahead of our arrival.

As you would appreciate, security was intense because President Demirel was on the Gallipoli Peninsula at that time. Some members of the delegation became concerned when we moved into position because the Foreign Affairs officials could not locate the wreaths that had been ordered by certain members of the delegation ahead of the ceremony.

The administrative assistant to the head of mission, Ms Betty Sutinen, was in charge of these arrangements. She said that there was no wreath for the parliamentary secretary, the member for Herbert, and there was not a second wreath for Senator Grant Chapman. This second wreath had a very special significance to Senator Chapman, who was accompanied by his spouse and his two children. His son was the captain of the prep school at Prince Alfred College in Adelaide. He was laying a wreath on behalf of his school, which had 14 members as part of the original Anzacs, and some of those 14 lost their lives. Senator Chapman was visibly upset—and I do not blame him—at the mess-up that occurred. The member for Herbert was also upset, and he then moved to a separate part of the proceedings. Subsequently, the missing wreath was found and given to Senator Chapman.

It was obvious at this point that the Governor-General, the ambassador and the rest of the official party were moving into place for the commencement of the ceremony. I commented to Ms Sutinen that surely the ceremony could not begin in the absence of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the shadow minister and the nine pilgrims who were accompanying them. She commented to me that the ceremony had to begin as there were time constraints. I further suggested to her that, knowing the reaction of my parliamentary colleagues, the minister and the shadow minister, she should think again and perhaps advise the ambassador that the minister, the shadow minister and the official party were not yet in place. Again she ignored those requests and then, of course, the ceremony went ahead.

Captain Jackson, who was the master of ceremonies on the occasion—I attach no blame to Captain Jackson, who was simply carrying out orders—then began the ceremony. I turned to Ms Sutinen and said that it was an absolute disgrace that such a ceremony would commence in the absence of the minister. The ambassador then came to the microphone, apologised to the gathering for the events at the dawn service and explained to those gathered that many of the events had been beyond the control of the Australian authorities—comments I largely endorse.

It was obvious, though, that the ceremony was going to continue. I suggested to the Minister for Trade, Senator McMullan, that he be ready to deliver the speech of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. To my amazement then, the captain called upon the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to give his address. There was, understandably, a pregnant pause. There was a titter from the crowd, laughter, and, of course, total embarrassment among the rest of the party gathered for this very special occasion. To his credit, the Minister for Trade went forward and delivered the speech—mistake and all. I had pointed out to the deputy head of mission the day before that the speech of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs contained a reference to Friday, 25 April when it should have read Tuesday, 25 April.

Subsequently, the Governor-General gave his speech. Shortly afterwards, the rest of the official party, including the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the shadow minister and the pilgrims, arrived. Even when the shadow minister read the ode and there was a wreath laying ceremony, Ms Sutinen asked me whether I knew who Wilson Tuckey was. I suggested to some of my colleagues that she must be the only person in Australia never to have heard of Wilson Tuckey.

As I said, I make no criticism whatsoever of Captain Jackson in my grievance today. In my view, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade's inadequacy is being shifted largely, I believe, to the Australian Defence Force because the department knew it would be very difficult for the ADF to respond. I am grateful for the reports that have been given to me to examine by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, but I must say in this House that some of those reports are at odds with my observations and, I would suggest, the observations of many other members who were present on that particular occasion.

I suggest that, at the very least, Ms Sutinen be certainly severely reprimanded for providing an obviously false statement to the department of foreign affairs and that Mr Perry, who was charged with the responsibility of organising the events, should have his position very closely examined. In my view, the organisation was absolutely disgraceful. It was appalling. There was little attention to the detail of the solemnity of the occasion and some of the basic techniques that any organisation should be aware of were totally ignored.

I found it quite fascinating and quite appalling that at the wreath laying ceremony that took place towards the end of the proceedings we as members of parliament, but even more significantly the nine pilgrims, were somewhat herded like sheep or cattle without there being any account taken of the significance and special meaning of the occasion by Mr Perry, who seemed intent on getting the ceremony over and on fulfilling the time obligations.

I attach a great deal of blame to Mr Perry. At the conclusion of the ceremony I asked Captain Jackson who gave him the order to commence the proceedings and he clearly beckoned to me that it was Mr Perry. I have no reason to doubt that advice from the officer.

A great occasion was marred by a disgraceful piece of organisation. It seems that 80 years later the confusion and the planning mishaps are a continuing legacy. As the saying goes, on this occasion: the tradition continues.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, as honourable members would be aware by the previous comments, seek to grieve today about a circumstance that really and truly destroyed what must have been one of the great highlights of my political career and one of the great highlights for a group of young Australians who are descendants of Anzac veterans some of whom are buried on the Gallipoli Peninsula. They were also greatly downgraded as a result of what were just plainly foolish planning arrangements associated with the events of 25 April 1995 on the Gallipoli Peninsula.

PARA.TAB: Nevertheless, as the custodian for the coalition of the Australia Remembers program, as must be very plain to the parliament, I have been committed totally to avoiding controversy in terms of conduct this year. I think whether it be the Gallipoli program, the other ceremonies, the general activities or the distribution of money—everything—I am not prepared and will continue to not be prepared to allow minor issues to override the great bipartisan support that exists in this parliament for what is a wonderful remembrance program of the contribution of literally millions of Australians in the wars that are past and in particular those who attended and fought at Gallipoli where 8,141 Australians were killed and 17,970 were wounded. So let me just put that on the record because I do feel, as obviously members of the government feel, that criticism is warranted. I just do not want it in any way thought of as a criticism of the general program and Australia's outstanding commitment to remembering the efforts of soldiers and service personnel of the past.

But let me just add to the remarks that have been made. I was very grateful for the invitation to be one of the party that travelled directly to Turkey. In fact, after a short stay in Istanbul, I went to the peninsula to spend four days there not only just to attend the ceremony but also to spend two days on the battlefields with the assistance, as the member for Franklin (Mr Quick) has drawn to our attention, of an outstanding Turkish academic, Kenan Celik, who gave us huge enlightenment as to the war with the benefit of his 12 years of research into it. I think he exploded a few myths for us but he certainly highlighted the high regard of the Turks for the skills and the courage of Australians in what was a very difficult task, which he identified as being the people who had to draw away from the British landing a large proportion of the Turkish defenders, which they did. They were sent to Anzac Cove with that purpose in mind, which of course is proper military strategy.

We were given a very well organised tour, if I can use that word, during the two days prior to going to the ceremony. We viewed the battlefields and the intensity that we understood in that battle. We are talking about an area fought over by tens of thousands, where 8,000 Australians were killed, which is only half the size of my farm! When you see trenches that are eight metres apart from opposing forces you can understand the words that I used at one stage, that this was one of the last battles where the human body was the principal weapon of war. It was tragic.

So when we had been there and experienced that we headed off for the ceremony, which was a dawn service. The Australian dawn service is because of that dawn landing. Our whole procedure to remember the fallen is built around the dawn. That is not common to many countries. It is not common to the Turks, who conducted their ceremony later in the day. So, as the member for Franklin said, we were woken at 2.30 in the morning because there was no accommodation on the Gallipoli Peninsula; it is a national park. We had to be transported across the Dardanelles. We were loaded on to buses to get to Anzac Cove.

As the member for Franklin said, I guess the first thing to strike us was that we were preceded by literally thousands of people, primarily Australians. There was a very large number of young people who were backpackers, many of whom we had met in the streets of Canakkale. It was mentioned that I am well known. I was delighted to be confronted by a number of these young people in the streets and in the restaurants wanting to talk to me. They knew who I was and they were delighted to see me present.

Here were all these people; here was the ceremony; and then, as an observer, things started to go wrong. Our huge media contingent—not unexpected; everyone knew they were going to be there; the service was well publicised—had no facilities whatsoever. Consequently, they sought to crowd around the memorial to the dissatisfaction of the other thousands of people—quite properly. But, as one television camera man was herded away, he said, `Well, there are 2,000 there, but I am trying to get a message to 18 million.' Nobody thought to give them a couple of elevated stands where they would not interfere with the people, yet which at the same time would give them some opportunity to pass this great ceremony back. That was one of the first things.
Someone had put up a lectern for the purpose of delivering these speeches, but it was behind a tree. You could not see the speakers from it, and nobody knew where to stand. There was no organisation.

Here we were in the dark. Young people were on the hills behind that had been climbed and fought over by our soldiers. They knew why they were there because they had bought Australian flags. One of the great pictures of the whole thing was one of those young fellas up there with his flag. Everybody knew what they were there for.

All of a sudden, out of the blue, it starts—at 5.30. They march the Kiwi soldiers—as it happened to be this year—into their positions as a guard of honour, and over in the crowd they started to light all these candles. All of a sudden we had the piper, and then we had nothing. We just watched this whole thing collapse.

I just could not understand it, because all we needed was one phone call from an officer of the people who were delayed. A lot of Australians were delayed, as well as the Deputy Prime Minister of New Zealand. All they had to say was, `Go without us. It's a dawn service. We understand that.' I can say that it was not their fault, except that I thought their schedule for getting the people there was impossible. The ship was to anchor an hour before our ceremony. I just thought that was ridiculous in terms of planning. Somebody should have said something. At that point you could not ask the soldiers there; you could not even ask the members of the embassy to say, `We're going without the Governor-General.' Someone on his staff or on the other staffs should have simply sent the message—and communication was available—`Go without us.' By the time they got there, the speeches could have been made at the end.

We have to do something in this parliament to ensure—maybe an amendment to the Anzac Day Act is the answer—that it never happens again. The fundamental thing is that it is 5.30, if that is the time that is appropriate on Anzac Cove for the ceremony. Let us say that it should be primarily conducted by our service personnel and the clergy; let us say that there should be hymns. We had no hymns. We had good background music with a beautiful PA system, but nobody thought to give us some background music for a couple of hymns. It would have brought another tear to my eye, I have to say, but that is how the ceremony should be conducted.

In the few seconds I have remaining, let me concur with the other two speakers. The big deal for our pilgrims was the second ceremony at Lone Pine. The first one had to be conducted on time; the second one could have been half an hour late; and we got the reverse of that. But, worse, by that time those young people's expectations were very high. In fact, most of them had brought other items with their wreaths to put before the shrine. Some had the names of their relatives listed there. Some had found the gravestones.

They should have gone through one at a time. They should have been introduced. They should have told where they came from. If you could please give me another minute, Mr Deputy Speaker, they were called out as a group, and they were sent through two at a time as though they were just members of the public. It was their ceremony. Why were they sent through two at a time? So the official party could get away to a luncheon with the President. They had plenty of time for that luncheon. As we discovered later, they had double the amount of time because the President just happened to be an hour late getting on to the ferry that then went out to this luncheon. He knew where his responsibilities were: they were to the Turkish people and the ceremonies that were going on on the peninsula. We wanted to rush our officials back to the bay. It just was not good enough.

I just wanted those points to be made. It was a tragedy of a great ceremony. I hope that, when we come up with some solutions by way of a little bit of simple legislation, we can all support it in this parliament, as we have supported everything that has happened this year. Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for your consideration. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I concur with the comments made by my colleagues this morning in the grievance debate about the difficulties they encountered on their mission to Gallipoli for the celebration of the 80th anniversary of Anzac Day. This morning I rise to bring to the attention of honourable members the contempt with which the opposition holds the north coast of New South Wales. Last week the Senate committee on long-term unemployment, led by Senator John Tierney, visited the Tweed.

PARA.TAB: I can assure members that the actions of Senator Tierney were nothing more than a political stunt, as the day prior to the hearing the opposition frontbench also visited the Tweed. I can understand why it would want to hold a shadow cabinet meeting in that location at this particular time of the year. I am sure the people there enjoyed the amenities, not to mention the climate. It was all very conveniently timed, you may well suggest.

Senator Tierney later stated that he was concerned that unemployment levels in the Richmond-Tweed area could reach levels of the Great Depression. Not once did Senator Tierney attempt to back up any of his rhetoric with figures. His concern was nothing more than a cheap attempt to have a shot at the government at the time. Unfortunately, all he managed to do was show his utter contempt for the region and the hardworking people across the region who have committed their time and efforts to get the region moving. But why let the facts get in the way of a good headline, you may ask. Senator Tierney certainly did not, nor did the daily news at the time.

As the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) pointed out on local radio, unemployment in the Richmond-Tweed region has fallen from 17.5 per cent to 12.1 per cent in the last 12 months. In actual fact, the figures started to show a downward trend at the start of 1993 and that steady decline has continued all the way. At each three-monthly interval when the figures are released I am asked to comment, at the behest of the media, as a result of comments made by my political wannabes. I respond by pointing out that the figures are showing a downward trend, which is to be commended, and that it is a hopeful sign, but certainly there is a lot of work to be done because, obviously, the unemployment figure is still too high. I did that on every occasion during the year, so on at least four occasions I did that.

During that time, 25,600 jobs have been created and the participation rate in the region has increased. These are not pie in the sky figures or any of that hollow rhetoric that coalition candidates in the region are renowned for but are figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the Department of Employment, Education and Training. Despite the fact that there was only one set of figures used in the editorial in the daily news, the editorial did state that there was a dispute on local unemployment figures between me and Senator Tierney. So what figures were in dispute?

Unemployment, while it has fallen in the region, is still unacceptably high. We cannot afford to be complacent just because of this fall. I have never backed down from that statement, nor have I ever neglected to say it. Having grown up and been educated on the north coast, I am well aware of just how far back the chronic nature of unemployment extends on the north coast. I went to school there and, like most of my friends who finished school, without having a tertiary institution established there, I had one option and that was to get on the train and head for Sydney.

Most would also be aware of coalition politicians and hopefuls changing their opinion now to see unemployment as a government fault and not that of the unemployed. It is a welcome change for them not to be blaming the unemployed for being unemployed. Nevertheless, there certainly has been a sea change in their attitude.

The problem of unemployment is something the federal government will continue to tackle through innovative employment programs targeting the needs of employers in the region. As I understand it, the only legacy of decades of National Party representation in the seat of Richmond is the Murwillumbah Post Office. It takes only a drive through any part of my electorate—Tweed Heads, Byron Bay or Ballina—to realise that the north coast economy is growing rapidly and new jobs are being created, bringing with it long-term benefits to the region.

How dare Senator Tierney treat the region with such contempt. Maybe I should remind him that the Northern Rivers region was the first region in Australia to establish a regional development organisation. That organisation, the Northern Rivers Economic Development Organisation, or NOREDO—an organisation that has worked tirelessly for the betterment of the region—is pulling the region together and striving towards the future. It is made up of many different organisations across the region—some of them, I would dare say, have quite diverse political persuasions, not to mention economic and sociological backgrounds. Nevertheless, they come together in NOREDO and they work for the common betterment of the north coast.

NOREDO has received funding through DEET and the Department of Housing and Regional Development and now has a chief executive officer, Mr Charles Liggett, at the helm. With NOREDO, the North Coast Area Consultative Committee is now driving initiatives from the Working Nation package on the ground in the Northern Rivers region. In some ways there seems to be some concern from Senator Tierney and others that there may be some success in that. I hope there is, and I hope that, if that is the reason for their concern, they do have great concern. I have met with Mr Liggett on a number of occasions and have impressed upon him the need for these programs to be implemented across the region. I am glad to see that this is now happening.

NOREDO is a unique organisation in that it has the broad support of a wide cross-section of community, industry, employer and trade union representatives. But the people who deserve the accolades in this situation are the north coast employers. Employers are the best people to create and sustain jobs. I point out, as I have done on a number of occasions in this House, that the north coast has probably the largest number of small business operators per capita of any area in Australia. I know New South Wales has the largest number of small business operators per capita of any state, and the north coast has certainly the highest of any region within New South Wales. So this region probably has the greatest number of small business operators anywhere in Australia.

What would Senator Tierney like to say to the employers who have created some 25,600 jobs in the year to March? The region is far from reaching the unemployment levels of the Great Depression. Far from it—the region is growing rapidly in terms of both population and economic growth, a factor that Senator Tierney seems to wish to disregard. Our tourism sector continues to grow, particularly the ecotourism sector. Exciting opportunities are being explored in the Byron Bay region in multimedia, and there are the knowledge and skills in that area to develop a major multimedia industry. It could even become an industry leader.

There are many exciting possibilities in terms of industry development in the region. It is about time the perpetual knockers of the region, and in this case some coalition supported wannabes, started to wake up and smell just one or two of the roses. It is important that the community as a whole and the government work together to keep the region moving. I am certainly committed to doing that. The negativity uttered by raving senators like Senator Tierney, and for that matter some local conservatives talking down the region, does not achieve anything at all. It is about time some of the local National Party apparatchiks and others around the region woke up and faced some facts about, firstly, unemployment and, secondly, some local bungling from the former government.

Before I go into that, I wish to point out in the few remaining minutes that I have to speak that I understand Senator Tierney will propose a motion to the Senate with regard to some of the figures I have quoted. The figures that I have quoted are those put out by both DSS and ABS. There is a difference between the ABS and the DSS figures. They have to be compared very carefully. The ABS figures take the standard that is set down by international labour organisations so that we can compare ourselves on an international basis. The DSS figures obviously are those which come from the local offices. There are substantial differences between those, and I will point out just one or two of those.

The ABS series includes unemployed persons whose spouses are working, irrespective of income, whereas the jobsearch allowance and the newstart recipients are subject to an income and assets test for themselves and their spouses. The ABS series also includes persons being paid a pension but looking for work. For example, a sole parent in receipt of a sole parent pension looking for work would be included in those figures.

The nature of the difference means that they have to be compared very carefully. Two of the major things Senator Tierney does not seem to want to recognise at all is that the DSS figures he has quoted also include those people who are working part time and that the population is growing on the north coast—by some five per cent or six per cent over the last 12 months.

Another fact that seems to be disregarded is that the participation rate has increased substantially. In other words, more people are seeking to re-enter the work force on the north coast. Overall, I think Senator Tierney had better have another look at the integrity behind some of his comments. In the small amount of time that I have left, I would very much like to point out that in some of the bungling—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance today is with this federal Labor government and its inability and unwillingness to deal with the complexities and inefficiencies inherent in Australia's centralised wage fixing award system. Australia's centralised system of wage fixation and labour market regulation is one of the most complex and overregulated anywhere in the world.

PARA.TAB: Currently there are approximately 2,500 federal awards in force, varying in length from 10 to 300 pages. The awards are full of examples of inefficient and outdated work practices which have interfered with the ability to transform the workplace into a flexible and competitive environment. Australia can no longer afford to maintain an uncompetitive labour market.

Awards have traditionally been overprescribed in terms of content and coverage because of their protected legal status, enforced by the Industrial Relations Commission, and the bargaining strength of trade unions. However, there have been recent improvements to the system, such as broadbanding of award classifications, development of training and skill models, and provisions for career structures.

Unfortunately, there are still numerous award complexities yet to be addressed. The most obvious are: too many award classifications; excessive penalty rates, special conditions and allowances; outdated, poorly written and overlapping clauses; overlapping state and federal jurisdiction; rigid and outdated work practices; and expensive administration.

An examination of federal awards reveals the problems associated with the complexity of award provisions. The metal industries award 1984 is a benchmark award that influences many national wage increases through the flow-on effect. It is arguably the most complex and fought over of all federal awards. Some of the statistics for the MTA 1984 award are as follows: there are 288 pages; over 200 penalty/special rates, excluding non-cash payments such as clothing, tools and food; 340 different award classifications; 26 basic pay rates; coverage of 63 industries or workplace classifications; nine unions are respondents to the award; and coverage of more than 400,000 employees in over 10,000 different enterprises or companies.

The metal trades award terms of reference have extensive scope and coverage. Many of the 288 pages relate to employee classifications, wages and working conditions. There are numerous mandatory award conditions that include: boiling water at meal times; drinking water, which must be wholesome and cool and dispensed by bubble taps or other suitable drinking fountains; seats for females, in addition to adequate toilet seats; a notice board and the positioning thereof; and special allowances for damaged spectacles.

These provisions add unnecessary bulk to an already lengthy document. Although many of the conditions are reasonable, the great majority could be satisfied under various occupational health and safety statutory regulations. If needed, additional requirements could be included at the enterprise level that were specific to the individual enterprise.

Some of the more complex features of this award are sections that have been added on to previous clauses, covering aspects such as special rates and conditions in different states and industries. These variations were made to allow for regional differences and for special circumstances. However, their effect has been to add unnecessary complexity to wage rate calculations.

The best example of unnecessary complexity is clause 37, which refers to special provisions for various districts, industries, plants, et cetera. This clause covers 20 pages and lists separate rates of pay, penalty rates, allowances and employee definitions for different states, territories and enterprises. An employer who has plants in more than one state would have to calculate multiple wage variations for each enterprise.

Another example of excessive variation in the MTA is the debacle over Boxing Day. According to the award, Boxing Day is a public holiday in all states except South Australia where it is Proclamation Day, except for Whyalla where it is Boxing Day. It is provisions such as these that make the award excessively lengthy and unnecessarily difficult to decipher, particularly for the small employer.

Small employers find it difficult to ascertain their award obligations in an easy and concise manner. The use of enterprise specific awards and/or certified agreements would greatly reduce many of these unnecessary complexities. Under such a system, award provisions would include only those relevant to the individual enterprise. Employers and employees would then be free to tailor an agreement that best meets their needs and would better reflect an employer's capacity to pay.

The Metal Trades Award also fails to take into account multi-skilling of employees. The classification structure is rigid and, with few exceptions, does not allow for one worker to perform multiple tasks. Broadbanding of base wage rates has made the base rate calculations simpler, but the 340 different award classifications remain and each has various allowances attached. With increasing demands on modern business for more multi-skilling of employees, outdated and inefficient award structures desperately need to be changed. Unions have been reluctant to support changes to award classifications because many fear this will lead to competition for membership and the end of exclusive coverage rights.

Further examples of award complexities include the fact that the length of federal awards varies greatly from 10 to over 300 pages. The reason for these variations is largely due to the extent and coverage of each award. In many instances, the more variations contained in an award the greater its extent, coverage and complexity. This would indicate that many awards, particularly those more than 50 pages, need to be examined for excessive content. For example, the Transport Workers Award 1991 is approximately 225 pages long and covers workers in most states and territories. It has 14 base rates and more than 60 special allowances. The award has been amended 141 times.

The Graphic Arts Award 1977 has numerous examples of too many subclauses regulating working conditions and wage rates of employees. Clause 42 covers 24 pages of work conditions, including the size limit of screens employees are to use. Clause 33, production of drawings, strictly forbids payment of wages for piecework and only permits an hourly rate. There is no allowance in this award provision, clause 33, for flexible wage payments and/or incentives for piecework. While clause 33 protects minimum wage entitlements, it rejects the possibility of over-award payments based on the productivity level of individuals.

Many mandatory working conditions and federal awards are covered under state law in various health and safety acts. Some awards have resolved the problem of concurrent powers by giving state statutes precedence over federal awards. Clause 44 in the Metal Trades Award gives the South Australian Industrial Safety, Health and Welfare Act 1972 overriding jurisdiction over industrial award provisions. It could be argued that award provisions relevant to state or federal statutory regulations, such as occupational health and safety, should be removed from awards and enforced under the appropriate statute. This would greatly reduce the complexity and length of awards while placing the enforcement of uniform conditions in the hands of the relevant professional authorities.
Various awards have outdated clauses that are yet to be changed. Some examples of existing award provisions are:

SPEECH.PARA: Every man shall have half a pound of meat a day in his allowance.
Each person is entitled to half a pint of free milk when bronzing/dusting machinery for 2 hours or more in the morning or afternoon.

That is contained in clause 48(i) of the Graphic Arts Award 1977. There are also examples of difficult to understand and legalistic clauses that make award interpretation cumbersome. One such example is contained in clause 28(c)(i) of the Graphic Arts Award, which states:

Should an employee to whom this subclause applies have less than twelve months' employment with his employer, the employer may, notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this subclause (a) hereof, pay that employee pro rata wages calculated on the basis of one-fifth of his pay specified in subclause (a) hereof, for this period of employment which includes the period of close down.

Many organisations maintain that the award system should be reduced to a simple level. They believe that provisions should be made for basic hourly rates, holidays, equal pay for males and females, and simple basic award conditions. They also believe that the majority of working conditions in the workplace should be negotiated on an enterprise level. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the fourth, fifth and sixth reports of the committee for 1995 relating to the refurbishment of Australia House, London; the construction of a new laboratory complex for CSIRO Division of Food Science and Technology, Werribee, Victoria; and the redevelopment of housing for service families at HMAS Cerberus.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The committee's fourth report for 1995 relates to the refurbishment of Australia House, London. The proposal includes the implementation of a staged program of internal refurbishment providing tenancy conditions which meet the requirements of occupational health and safety; the replacement of outdated and obsolete equipment; and office accommodation which meets current data and communication needs. The proposal also includes the refurbishment of areas surplus to High Commission requirements for leasing to state governments and other agencies. The committee has recommended that the work proceed at an estimated cost of $14.25 million at May 1994 prices.

PARA.TAB: Australia House has been Australia's showcase in central London since it was officially opened by King George V on 3 August 1918. Peak occupancy occurred during the post-Second World War immigration boom. However, continuing staff reductions since that time have resulted in surplus space in Australia House.

Australia House is Australia's oldest overseas mission and a London landmark building classified by English heritage. The building was constructed between 1913 and 1918 using substantial amounts of Australian timbers and marble. It is the oldest originally occupied chancery of any foreign mission in London. Over the years various parts of Australia House have been renovated on an as-required basis but no comprehensive renovation program has been undertaken since it was completed, although the public areas have been maintained at a high level.

Whilst the exterior has been comparatively well maintained, the interior condition is variable, and many of the building services are at the end of their safe and useful life. At the request of the committee, the Overseas Property Group examined various options for the use of the sixth floor, which will be left vacant due to the movement of communications facilities to the third floor.

The committee has concluded that, on the evidence provided to it from the Australian High Commission in London, the sixth floor of Australia House is not suitable for conversion to provide long-term residential accommodation but is suitable for transit accommodation or office accommodation. The committee has therefore recommended that the sixth floor should be converted for use as transit accommodation or office accommodation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you made inspections yet?

—We have had the inspection. We were going to put the high commissioner in there, but we thought better of moving him out of Stoke Lodge. We thought some transit accommodation might be needed. Members of parliament visiting London might stay there for one or two nights for an appropriate fee, but we will not get into a debate about it.

PARA.TAB: The committee's fifth report for 1995 refers to the proposal to relocate the Victorian based activities of the CSIRO's Division of Food Science and Technology from Highett to the Werribee technology precinct. The proposal is part of a program for integrating food research activities in Victoria. The new facilities will be constructed in an area immediately adjacent to those of the Victorian government's Australian Food Research Institute.

The complex has been designed recognising the need to develop a close working relationship with the Australian Food Research Institute. Buildings have been sited to encourage staff interaction between the two organisations. The proposal, which has been recommended by the committee, is estimated to cost $10.1 million at September 1994 prices.

CSIRO advised that remaining at Highett was not considered to be sustainable because of the continued fragmentation of research for the dairy industry whilst occupying different sites, because the increasing costs of support activities are detracting from research funding, because of the potential for reduced support from the Dairy Research and Development Corporation, because of the need for a capital injection of approximately $5.8 million for refurbishment of the laboratory and because some facilities at Highett are cramped and even with a half-life refit the continuing location of the laboratory at Highett will isolate it from other food activities at Werribee and reduce industry focus and support.

While there was widespread support for the proposal from the Victorian government and industry groups, the CSIRO division of the Community and Public Sector Union raised concerns regarding the proposal, particularly the impact on the research program. The committee, having carefully considered all the evidence presented to it, is of the view that relocation to Werribee is the most viable long-term option.

The committee believes that co-location at Werribee with the Australian Food Research Institute will lead to advantages in research collaboration and in reduced infrastructure costs through the sharing of common facilities such as the library, canteen, auditorium and workshops. In addition, relocation to Werribee offers the opportunity for collaboration with a wide range of both public and private research bodies which are, or will soon be, established in the Werribee area. The committee is also aware that the Dairy Research and Development Corporation has offered CSIRO a grant of $4 million towards equipment at Werribee.

While the committee accepts and understands the reluctance of staff to relocate to Werribee and also agrees that the relocation will have some temporary adverse impact on the research effort, the committee believes that the relocation will have a positive long-term impact on the work of the laboratory. In particular, the project provides opportunities to develop a coordinated research and development centre for the food industry.

The third report of this hardworking and very busy committee which I have tabled deals with the proposed redevelopment of housing for service families at HMAS Cerberus. By way of background, HMAS Cerberus is a significant and expanding Royal Australian Navy training establishment located at Western Port. There are currently 554 families located both on board HMAS Cerberus and ashore in the surrounding area. The proposal which the committee examined is aimed to partially redress the imbalance in housing available on board compared with ashore by increasing on board housing from 109 to 152 in accordance with the Defence Housing Authority mission to provide defence personnel and their families with good housing consistent with community standards.

The scope of the works examined by the committee is the provision of an additional 55 houses on new and revised lots, the provision of 45 houses as replacements for existing substandard houses, substantial upgrading or replacement of 10 existing older brick houses and the retention of 27 existing houses which require less substantial works.

When referred to the committee the estimated cost of the proposed redevelopment was $14.2 million. In recommending that the redevelopment should proceed, the committee has concluded that there is a need to replace or modernise existing on-board housing at HMAS Cerberus to match contemporary standards and expectations. Many of the on-base houses are well below acceptable community standards.
