In terms of the overall scope of the project, the committee has concluded that it is soundly based, the extent can be justified on the grounds of reduced cost penalties associated with the payment by Defence of isolated establishment allowances, it will enhance personnel efficiencies, and it makes good use of available land.

A number of design features were commented upon during our inquiry and the committee therefore believes that the Defence Housing Authority should continue consultations with the Tenants Consultative Group concerning the provision of features and fittings which will enhance the habitability of the houses.

It is planned that the housing area at HMAS Cerberus may be excised from the base sometime in the future. The committee has therefore recommended that before this goes ahead it will be necessary for the sewerage system serving the housing area to be connected to the Hastings system independently of the base. I commend the reports to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts I present Report 336—Public business in the public interest: an inquiry into commercialisation in the Commonwealth public sector.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I welcome this opportunity to table the 336th report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which is entitled Public business in the public interest. At the outset, I would like to thank the members of the committee secretariat for their sterling efforts in support of this inquiry. In particular, I would like to mention Grant Harrison, our committee secretary, and those staff who worked closely with the inquiry—Lorraine Hendy, Cliff Lawson and our tireless inquiry secretary Sarah Hnatiuk. Sarah has since left the secretariat to join the staff of the House of Representatives environment committee, and on behalf of the committee I wish her well in her new job.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to take this opportunity to express the committee's thanks to Lorraine Hendy, who is leaving the secretariat after a period of five years of excellent service to the committee. Certainly in the time that I have been with the committee Lorraine has always been there and worked extremely hard. She is moving to another committee, the employment, education and training committee, I understand. On behalf of the committee and personally I wish Lorraine well in her new position.
I will turn to the report now that I have said all our thankyous. These occasions are always a good opportunity for us to acknowledge the good work that our parliamentary secretariat staff provide.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Background to the Inquiry.

PARA.TAB: The report is the result of the committee's inquiry into the commercialisation of public sector operations, which began nearly two years ago. In setting up the inquiry the committee was responding to concerns at that time about the operation of certain government business enterprises, GBEs, particularly the monopoly businesses of the Federal Airports Corporation, FAC, and the Civil Aviation Authority, CAA. The committee was also aware of a series of reports by the Auditor-General about difficulties with the introduction of commercialisation in departments of state.

The committee decided to limit its inquiry to examining commercialisation in GBEs and business units in departments of state, and to focus on the efficiency and effectiveness of commercialisation and corporatisation, particularly in the FAC, the CAA and the Department of Administrative Services.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Efficiency and effectiveness, and the framework for commercialisation and corporatisation.

PARA.TAB: The committee took evidence from 14 of the Commonwealth's 19 GBEs and five of the nine departments which have business units.

We concluded that commercialisation and corporatisation have been successful in increasing the efficiency with which GBEs and business units deliver goods and services. This increased efficiency and effectiveness reflects the fact that, generally speaking, appropriate frameworks for commercialisation and corporatisation have been established.

The framework that has been established for the operation and oversight of GBEs has proved functional, and was finetuned with the issue of new guidelines in 1993. The oversight arrangements will be locked in and extended to cover government companies as well as GBEs with the passage, hopefully within the next month or so, of the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill. As you may recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts has played a central role in the development of this legislation—first recommending that it be prepared in 1989 and then considering the bill in detail in report 331, which was tabled in September last year.

In contrast to GBEs, business units in departments of state are more recent creations and the framework for their operation is less well established and is still being developed. The committee believes that the Department of Finance should be taking a more prominent role than it has up to now in assisting departments to set up their business units. It should be putting more effort into monitoring the problems that arise in the course of commercialisation and identifying and disseminating best practice.

The committee also noted that business units in departments of state are currently disadvantaged by the requirements that being part of a department of state imposes. Given that corporatisation provides increased flexibility of operation, the committee has recommended that corporatisation should be extended to successful business units.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Key issues in commercialisation and corporatisation in the Commonwealth public sector.

PARA.TAB: The committee examined many aspects of the operation of GBEs and business units, more than I can cover in my speech here today. I have therefore selected three topics of importance on which I wish to concentrate. They are:

SPEECH.PARA: .safeguarding the public interest functions that were once required of what are now government businesses;
.the need for GBEs and business units to have clearly defined, non-conflicting, commercial objectives; and
.whether the arrangements for ministerial oversight of government businesses are fully appropriate.

PARA.TAB: In choosing to concentrate on these topics, I do not wish to give the impression that other matters were not considered—because they were, quite considerably. The committee's report also covers, for example, the accountability and financial regimes that apply to GBEs and business units, their performance in competing with the private sector, and the impact that commercialisation has had on staff.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The public interest: community service obligations.

PARA.TAB: Over the years the government has become involved in providing essential goods and services when they were not available under reasonable circumstances from the private sector. When the provision of these goods and services is commercialised, charges are levied for them which may be too expensive for the consumer. In this case, the consumers' access to these goods and services has been safeguarded by the government imposing community service obligations—better known as CSOs—on the relevant GBEs to supply what is necessary.

The committee examined the system by which CSOs are identified, costed and funded, and has recommended that more attention be given to defining CSOs so that the social outcomes that the government requires are precisely known, and the methods of costing and funding them are clear. This observation applies whether the CSO is being delivered by a government-owned business or by the private sector.

The committee also believes that consumers and their representatives should be more involved than at present in helping to identify new CSOs and making changes to existing CSOs. In addition, consumers should play a larger part in monitoring the delivery of CSOs and assessing how well they are meeting needs. However, if consumers are to have a meaningful input into the definition and monitoring of CSOs, they will need to have better information about the goods and services provided as CSOs than is available at present.

Another avenue for monitoring the efficiency and effectiveness of CSO programs is through performance audits. The committee believes that there are strong arguments for the Auditor-General, who is at present effectively barred from carrying out performance audits on GBEs, being able to examine the delivery of CSOs. Scrutiny of the operation of CSO mechanisms by the Australian National Audit Office may bring substantial improvements to the efficiency with which CSOs are delivered.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Focusing on commercial performance: avoiding conflicting objectives.

PARA.TAB: One of the prerequisites for commercial success when parts of government departments are commercialised is that they are able to focus single-mindedly on their commercial activities. Thus, when a government business is commissioned to perform a social function, it is important that the commercial focus of the business is not unnecessarily blurred by its social responsibility. Conversely, it is equally important that the commercial activities of a business do not impinge on its social welfare functions.

Some of the now commercialised sections of government departments formerly had policy and regulatory roles, as well as social welfare responsibilities. With the introduction of commercialisation, these policy and regulatory roles need to be removed from these businesses and transferred to other agencies.

Although it was frequently quoted to the committee, it was not clear that the full implications of this principle of separating different functions had been grasped and that adequate steps had been taken to implement it. The committee acknowledges that the government's businesses now no longer have regulatory functions in areas where they compete with the private sector.

However, the experiences of the CAA have drawn attention to the problems that can arise with the combination in the same organisation of a commercial function—air traffic control—and a regulatory function that does not have a commercial focus—air safety. The committee found that this situation has led to confusion among the CAA's clients and within the organisation itself. The committee welcomes the government's decision to establish an Aviation Safety Authority separate from the commercial arm of the former CAA, and has recommended that the government review the operation of all agencies with a similar combination of commercial and regulatory functions, with a view to separating the functions.

There were two other businesses that came to the committee's attention where the potential for a conflict between different objectives appeared possible. One such business is the legal practice of the Attorney-General's Department, which provides legal services to the government on both a commercial and public interest basis. The other business which is perceived as being caught in a conflict of interest is the Australian Surveying and Land Information Group—Auslig—with its large public interest function and a smaller commercial one. In both these instances, there may be a case for separating the functions.

In some circumstances, it may not be possible to separate different functions. With such cases, very clear guidance must be provided on structures that can be set up to minimise conflicts of interest and to manage any conflicts that do arise. It may be appropriate at times to provide an independent review of areas where apparent conflicts of interest are causing concern.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Oversight of government businesses.

PARA.TAB: Prime responsibility for the oversight of a GBE's performance lies with the minister responsible for the industry sector in which that GBE operates. In carrying out this responsibility, the responsible minister—or portfolio minister—liaises closely with the Minister for Finance on the financial aspects of the GBE's performance. In this arrangement, the portfolio minister has a diverse range of interests—for example, he or she is interested in the financial performance of portfolio GBEs, sets policy for the industries in which the GBEs operate and ensures that appropriate regulation is in place. By analogy with the considerations that I have just raised in relation to the CAA, the legal practice and Auslig, it appears that such an arrangement may expose portfolio ministers to a conflict of interest.

The committee was interested to learn during a visit to New Zealand that, in that country, a different system for GBE oversight has been established. In the New Zealand system, responsibility for policy affecting state owned enterprises rests with a different minister from the one who is responsible for their financial performance. In fact, the New Zealand Minister of Finance and the New Zealand Minister of State Owned Enterprises are joint shareholders of all state owned enterprises.
At first glance, the committee felt that the New Zealand model had much to commend it. Compared with the Commonwealth's arrangements, this model appeared:

SPEECH.PARA: .to allow more consistent monitoring of GBE performance;
.to promote more efficient identification and dissemination of best practice; and
.through their separation from policy portfolios, to enable state owned enterprises to concentrate on their commercial performance.

PARA.TAB: The committee explored these points with a number of Commonwealth agencies and GBEs and found little support for any of them.

SPEECH.PARA: .The agencies argued, with a consistent voice, that there should not be too great a focus on the commercial performance of GBEs. For example, a sole focus on commercial performance of the CAA's air traffic services might jeopardise its emphasis on safety and erode public confidence in the safe operation of Australia's air traffic services.

.They argued further that, with the Commonwealth's current arrangements, the strategic direction for each GBE is set by negotiation between the GBE's board and the responsible minister. This minister is said to be knowledgeable about the circumstances under which the GBE operates in a way that would not be possible for a minister who had responsibility for all GBEs.

.Furthermore, it was pointed out to the committee that the involvement of the Minister for Finance in GBE oversight provides a check on the portfolio ministers, and any conflict between them can be brought to the cabinet and resolved there.

PARA.TAB: The committee concluded that at present there is no compelling evidence that major changes need to be made to the Commonwealth model of GBE oversight. While the New Zealand system of GBE oversight has worked well in that country, so too has the Commonwealth model in Australia. Government businesses, central agencies and portfolio departments all reported to the committee that they were satisfied with the way in which the current arrangements are working.

I refer briefly to the question of whether the government should be involved in business at all. The committee accepts that it is appropriate for the government to be involved in a range of commercial activities. For example, it is appropriate for the government to operate businesses so as to provide services that are not available from the private sector and to foster the development of emerging markets. By being involved in business, the government can also maintain the sort of expertise needed to facilitate the work of the private sector through joint ventures, export enhancement and technology transfer and develop effective monitoring and regulatory regimes. The judgment of precisely how involved the government should be is difficult and is subject to change over time.

The committee notes that in recent times the government has moved to sell a number of its GBEs. In fact, that has been a matter of some debate this week. The program of asset sales is based on considerations of whether the public is best served by owning these businesses. Some of the considerations are: whether significant competition already exists in the market in which the GBE operates; whether increased market exposure would bring improved performance; whether the enterprise would benefit from those sorts of strategic partnerships and capital injections that can be negotiated in the marketplace; and whether social objectives are still dependent on public ownership.

The committee believes that the government's commitment to a continuing examination of its involvement in commercial activities is appropriate. I note in passing that the Auditor-General is currently conducting a performance audit into the efficiency and effectiveness of the procedures used in the sale of Commonwealth assets. Given the magnitude of the returns expected and already achieved from the asset sales program, it is important that the sales process be conducted as efficiently as possible. The committee awaits the Auditor-General's report with some interest.

The committee believes that government businesses have greatly improved their level of performance since the introduction of commercialisation and corporatisation. There is evidence also that they are determined to improve further still. In this they will be assisted by the recommendations contained in the committee's report, particularly those which call on the government to update the operating framework for government businesses, to clearly define, cost and fund CSOs, and to avoid imposing on government businesses conflicting commercial policy and regulatory functions. A positive response to these recommendations will ensure that public business will indeed be conducted in the public interest. I commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—As vice-chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I am pleased to support the remarks made by the chairman, the member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott), in his tabling speech this morning. The committee's inquiry into public sector commercialisation was very broadly based and there were many issues which arose in the course of the inquiry, as the chairman explained.

PARA.TAB: I also pay tribute to the secretariat of the committee—Grant, Sarah, Cliff and Lorraine particularly. The effort they put in was well beyond the call of duty in many instances. While I concur with the conclusions and recommendations in the report, I will make some general comments about one of the areas which has been covered by the chairman and which the committee examined. I am not quite as comfortable as the chairman is with the conclusions in relation to ministerial responsibility for the oversight of government business enterprises.

The committee notes in the report that responsibility for the overall commercialisation framework and for individual government businesses is less centralised in the Commonwealth sphere than in some Australian states and New Zealand. In New Zealand, for example, the crown company monitoring unit within the treasury oversights the planning and reporting processes for all state-owned enterprises and advises the Minister for Finance and the Minister for State Owned Enterprises, who are joint shareholders.

This arrangement differs from the Commonwealth model where the shareholder for the government is the relevant portfolio minister, who consults the Minister for Finance on major matters affecting GBEs within the portfolio. The New Zealand model appeared at first glance to have some advantages over the Commonwealth's arrangements, such as allowing more consistent monitoring of GBE performance across portfolios, promoting more efficient identification and dissemination of best practice, and separation of commercial operations from policy and regulatory arms of the portfolio enabling GBEs to concentrate on their commercial performance. That, after all, is the reason they are there.

Subsequent evidence submitted to the inquiry led the committee to conclude that the single minister model used by the Commonwealth has generally worked well and that there is no case for changing the present oversight arrangements for Commonwealth GBEs. Personally I have a real problem on the basis of accountability with the potential for conflict of interest when the policy maker is also the regulator. Therefore I make the observation that, consistent with the evolving nature of public sector commercialisation and corporatisation in Australia, the door should be left open for ongoing evaluation of the centralised oversight arrangements operating in other jurisdictions. This would ensure that our own arrangements remain relevant over time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Certainly one of the more interesting tasks that I have had the pleasure of being involved in since coming into this place in March 1993 has been not only to be a member of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts but also to participate in the inquiry resulting in this report entitled Public business in the public interest: an inquiry into commercialisation in the Commonwealth public sector. It is important that the parliament, as the custodian of the taxpayers' dollars in this country, be cognisant of how those dollars are expended, how the public business is conducted.

PARA.TAB: A number of matters for consideration surfaced in this report on the efficiency, effectiveness and appropriateness of government business enterprises, and the provision of community service obligations should be clearly identified. I do not think there is any argument from any quarter that we have reached best practice in GBEs. There certainly is room for improvement. There is always going to be room for improvement up to the point when the government makes a decision to maintain ownership of a GBE or to sell it and privatise it.

The process that a lot of the GBEs have gone through in some departments has been quite traumatic as far as the culture of the staff is concerned. Staff may have worked in a Public Service situation for the majority of their lifetime and all of a sudden they are like rabbits in the spotlight—they are exposed to the rest of the world to see exactly how they are operating and whether they are in fact operating efficiently. A lot of people in different organisations have taken to this concept quite well and taken up the challenge, as it were; others have not. We did find that in the inquiry.

Two very important elements of this report that should be continually reviewed in policy settings by this government and future governments are, as alluded to by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay), the area of community service obligations—how they are provided and how they are funded—and the ministerial oversight of GBEs. CSOs are a very important element of government activity. That is going to become increasingly so in future years as all governments of whatever political persuasion in this country and countries around the world head down the path of corporatisation, commercialisation and ultimately privatisation of non-core activities of government however they are seen by the particular government, of whatever colour, of the day.

In the centre of all that, it does not matter who is in power; there has to be a commitment by government to identify what community service obligations are going to be provided. That is the very first element that must be put at the top of the list—the government must identify what it is going to provide. Then it must identify how it is going to provide it. If we have an agency within a line department that is providing a community service obligation and that has moved out to become a GBE, and if the government of the day wants to continue to provide that CSO, the government has to identify it and has to expose separately in that GBE's budget how it is going to be funded and how it is going to be paid for. Even to the extent that it is identified as a budget item in the Commonwealth budget, the government must identify how it is going to be provided.

So at that point there is no problem in moving on. If that GBE is then sold off to private enterprise, to the private sector, that CSO is still identified as being provided by that organisation and paid for out of the budget. It is a very important element of what is happening in public policy today, and will continue to be so.

The other important element that has been highlighted in this report is the aspect of ministerial responsibility. I did not have the opportunity to go and have a look at the New Zealand model, although we did get all the information about it. I still have an element of doubt about the evidence we received from our line departments in that regard. I note that the chairman said in his speech:

SPEECH.PARA: The committee concluded that at present there is no compelling evidence that major changes need to be made to the Commonwealth model of GBE oversight.

That comment was made in relation to what is happening in New Zealand. Whilst I support the report, I would strongly recommend that the government continually monitor that. What has happened with the CAA is a perfect case in point of the possibility of a conflict: if one minister has the commercial responsibility, as well as the policy making or the regulatory responsibility, for a GBE, and gets into a political bind at any given point in time, certainly a conflict will arise. It is an area that must be continually reviewed. I highlight that to the government in this report.

PARA.TAB: In closing, I support all the recommendations in report No. 336 entitled Public business in the public interest. I should not finish without complimenting the staff who have supported us in putting this report together. They have done a hell of a lot of work above and beyond the call of duty. It is a very important document that will be referred to by a lot of governments in the future. I know that it will be used as a reference document by governments overseas. I commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—We are here today to discuss briefly the recent report No. 336 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled Public business in the public interest relating to the question of commercialisation of the Commonwealth public sector. As a member of that committee, I would like to start off as everyone else has done before me by thanking the staff—Grant, Cliff, Lorraine and Sarah—for the hard work they have done. It was a report that I think I described once during the closing hearings as `bigger than Ben Hur'. The report is some 350 pages long and has taken almost two years.

PARA.TAB: There is a lot in the report to digest; there is a lot in there for government to take action on. I will keep my comments today to a couple of issues—one of them is not Professor Hilmer, which was often an item of discussion at the committee—which are community service obligations and government involvement in business.

Community service obligations, as has been noted by other speakers, was a major consideration at the inquiry. Briefly, identification, funding and the costing of CSOs will be key issues as we move further down the track of commercialisation of government business enterprises, and also in some respects towards privatisation. It concerns members from all sides of the chamber, because when we are talking about community service obligations they often relate to rural and remote communities as well as to the less well off in society. It is an issue of grave concern to many of us. I have had real concerns over recent years with the movement towards greater efficiencies in government operations—which I support—but one of the impacts of that can, on some occasions, be a situation where community service obligations are, to an extent, diluted and otherwise interfered with. That can have real and lasting implications for the communities that we all come here to serve. We have got to look at that very carefully.

The committee has recommended that we, the government and the parliament, need to work seriously and hard on the identification and the costing of those CSOs. We need to be very clear about what is being provided and what is seen to be the actual community service obligation, to ensure that that is maintained, whether it be in the private sector or in the circumstances of a commercial government enterprise. We have to make sure that those things are clearly delineated and put in a position where there is no doubt.

If governments of any persuasion take a decision to remove or to alter those CSOs, my view and I think the view of the committee was that that should be clear and open and available for debate within the public arena. The government of the day which might do that should be judged accordingly on the basis of what it has done.

Another aspect of concern about CSOs was that on some occasions—and I think the example that many of us spoke about was Australia Post—it may well be that a community service obligation is difficult to cost and to define in a detailed fashion. Nonetheless, every effort should be made to ensure that those definitions are there and that it is recognised that they are an important aspect to be provided through these organisations.

On the question of government involvement in business, which was one of the areas where there was some discussion on the committee, I think it is fair to say that all members of the committee agreed that there was a need for government involvement in business in particular circumstances. I guess it is fair to say also that, though there was some difference of opinion as to how far those circumstances go—I note the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) is smiling at that comment—government does play an important role in providing business opportunities. We should not allow a situation where on all occasions matters are flogged off without relevance to the real social need that some of those businesses can provide.

Government should stay in business and provide services where they are not available from the private sector. It should assist in the development of markets, joint ventures and other involvements with the private sector and ensure that there are effective monitoring and regulatory regimes. The other issue I raise there is that it is also important in many areas for government to maintain expertise for its dealings with the private sector. For example, a necessary aspect in tendering arrangements is the need for expertise from the government in its dealings with the private sector in the provision of service. I worry a little bit on some occasions that the government is moving down a track where we are losing some of that expertise. Defence is an example.

I commend the report to the House. I congratulate the members of the committee and the staff for the excellent work that was done on this inquiry. I think it is a good study of what has been done and what can be done in the field of commercialisation. It is an area that is current and relevant to the operations of government and parliament in Australia. It can be taken on board and used to good effect for all of the community.
