DEBATE.TITLE: INTERSTATE ROAD TRANSPORT AMENDMENT BILL 1995Cognate bill:INTERSTATE ROAD TRANSPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 8 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe The Hon N.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr O'KEEFE
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments proposed in the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1995 and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1995 will give effect to the national heavy vehicle charges developed by the independent National Road Transport Commission to apply to vehicles registered under the federal-interstate registration scheme.

PARA.TAB: Heads of government agreed in July 1991 to the establishment of the NRTC to develop nationally consistent charges and regulations for vehicles over 4.5 tonnes. The NRTC released its heavy vehicle charges determination in June 1992. The Road Transport Charges (ACT) Act, which gives effect to the charges in the ACT from 1 July 1995 and sets the model for other jurisdictions, received royal assent in May 1992. It is essential that inconsistent regulations and charges which continue to impede improvements in the efficiency of the road transport industry be changed to achieve a nationally uniform operating environment. While agreement has been reached by state and territory ministers on the heavy vehicle charges, some states continue to be reluctant to implement them.

The proposed amendments will mean that FIRS vehicles registered in states where national charges have not yet been introduced will have access to the national charges. In the interests of achieving national uniformity, FIRS will apply to only vehicles over 4.5 tonnes and charges will no longer be able to be paid by instalments. Money collected from these registration charges will continue to be returned to state and territory governments for the maintenance and upkeep of roads. I now turn to the provisions of the bill.

The principal amendments will remove the option to pay a registration charge based on actual distance travelled and the option to pay registration charges by instalments. Further amendments will remove the references to motor vehicle and trailer charge monitoring devices. At present these devices are used to determine the actual distance that a vehicle has travelled in order to calculate the actual distance amount. It is worth noting that reliable distance-only measuring devices are not currently available in Australia. These changes reflect the arrangements for registration charges determined through the NRTC process.

Consequential amendments are required to the Interstate Road Transport Charge Act 1985. The proposed amendments will include the registration charges for various vehicle types as a schedule to that act. The implementation of national charges for heavy vehicles is a crucial step in the reform of the road transport industry.The proposed amendments demonstrate the federal government's commitment to the harmonisation of heavy vehicle charges and regulations and its recognition of the importance of the road transport industry to the economy. The onus is now on the states and the Northern Territory to act on their commitment to implement the charges from 1 July 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: INTERSTATE ROAD TRANSPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: The amendments proposed in the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1995 will apply the national heavy vehicle registration charges developed by the National Road Transport Commission to vehicles registered under the federal-interstate registration scheme. By implementing the national charges for vehicles registered under FIRS, the Commonwealth is honouring its commitment under the heavy vehicles agreement and promoting the harmonisation of road transport charges and regulations. This is important in facilitating efficiency improvements in the road transport industry. I now turn to the provisions of the bill.

The principal amendment will provide the national registration charges developed through the NRTC process as a schedule to the act. The amendments also provide that, where a vehicle falls within two or more vehicle types for the purposes of the charges, the registration charge will be the higher or highest of the charges applicable. The amendments further provide that the amounts of registration charges may be altered by the regulations. Such an alteration must not increase or decrease the amount for the previous year by more than five per cent. The amendments are to come into force from 1 July 1995. The net budgetary impact of the amendments will be nil. This bill should be read in conjunction with the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1995. I commend both bills to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the federal opposition to respond to the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill, being debated cognately this morning. In so doing, I indicate from the outset that the federal opposition will be supporting the bills, for the very good reason that we believe this is an important part of the micro-economic reform of the road transport industry—a reform long overdue; a reform which will deliver considerable advantages, both financial and bureaucratic, to the road transport industry. The peak body of the road transport forum has been campaigning for these reforms for quite some years now. I believe there is a clear and substantial argument for the implementation of these reforms.

PARA.TAB: It is important for people to recognise that we are dealing with a series of reforms which will establish national uniformity for our road transport industry, whether dealing with registration charges, which is the subject of the debate this morning, or with uniform regulations for the carriage of dangerous goods, which we dealt with only a few weeks ago. We have made other changes to the act in this parliament over the last 12 months. The purpose of these reforms is to ensure that the road transport industry in Australia is not being overwhelmed with a whole raft of different laws that apply in different states.

The road transport industry has had to comply with regulations in Queensland that are different from New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia and the Northern Territory. Because of that, road transport operators have been left with a bureaucratic maze to weave their way through in order to ensure that a truck that is legal in Queensland, as it initiates its journey to Melbourne, is not made illegal as it goes through New South Wales and into Victoria and back again as a result of all of the different rules in those states. The process we are now involved in is designed to make sure that a truck carrying an item from Brisbane to Melbourne does not have to go through three totally separate regulations. This legislation will make it easier for them and certainly will reduce cost.

The bills we are discussing today relate to registration charges for road transport operators. Looking simply at the issue of registration charges, there are winners and losers. New South Wales road transport operators will be big winners as a result of a national registration charge. If you are a Western Australian road transport operator, it could be argued that you will be a loser because the registration charge for your vehicle will go up.

However, I would put it the same way the Road Transport Forum itself puts it. That is, the industry as a whole is a winner as a result of these changes taking place. As a result of all these changes taking place, for the first time in the history of this country we will have one set of charges, one set of rules and one set of regulations for the road transport industry right across Australia.

New South Wales road transport operators will be advantaged by the introduction of this change. A bogie-drive tri-axle semitrailer, which would be described as the typical road transport vehicle on our highways, currently has a maximum registration charge of $8,650. This will be reduced to $4,000. So they are going to be advantaged considerably.

Western Australian road transport operators will be disadvantaged. In looking at the same vehicle, a bogie-drive tri-axle semitrailer, its registration costs will go up from $2,980 to $4,000. So Western Australia is quite obviously concerned about the implementation of this particular aspect of the NRTC process.

Again, I make this fundamental point: there will always be winners and losers on individual aspects of these changes. But, in my view, and in the view of the Road Transport Forum, at the end of the day every single road transport operator around Australia will end up being considerably better off. These changes being put through the parliament at present, as they have been over the past 12 months and as they will be over the next 12 months or so as further bills come before the House, will implement the philosophy of having a national road transport system with uniform laws, regulations and rules.

This is the process we are engaged in. It will make it a more efficient industry for road transport operators to work in. It will also make it fairer, because a consequence of having different regulations and standards in different states is that people have been able to rort the system. For example, New South Wales road transport operators have been able to register their trucks in South Australia at a much lower cost than the cost of registering them in New South Wales and have still been able to operate their trucks in New South Wales. They have been contributing much less to the cost of road maintenance in their state than would otherwise be the case.

You could be paying $8,500 to register a semitrailer in New South Wales. If you registered the same semitrailer in South Australia, you would be paying $2,980—almost a saving of $6,000. The problem then is that, once you have registered your semitrailer in South Australia, it only requires the sending of a cheque once every 12 months to have that semitrailer reregistered.

In New South Wales, where they have been trying to do the right thing for a long time now, if a semitrailer is to be reregistered it is a requirement that it be properly checked to ensure that the trailer and the prime mover are in a proper and safe condition. That is not the case in South Australia. You simply send your cheque in and it gets reregistered. The truck could be in the worst of all possible conditions—the brakes may not work, bits and pieces could be falling off, the lights may not work. All the things that pose a threat to the travelling public could apply to that truck if it is registered in South Australia, yet it can continue to be reregistered.

This process will ensure that, if you are registering a truck in Australia, the same criteria, charges and rules for registration and reregistration will apply in every state. Operators will not be able to rort the system by going to a state that has a lower standard, thus destroying the safety standards that have been established in other more responsible states. That is what this whole process is about.

Unfortunately, this process has had a few stumbling blocks thrown in its path. As anyone who understands the relationship between Commonwealth and state governments would realise, getting states to agree to do things in their own states that are different from what has been done in the past is not always easy.

A few minutes ago the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport (Mr O'Keefe) pointed out that there are problems with the implementation of this legislation in Western Australia and the Northern Territory. The Northern Territory says that it will implement this legislation when every other state in the Commonwealth has. Western Australia says that it is not enthusiastic about this legislation because it means that its road transport operators will have to pay more.

However, after a long period of opposition to this in Western Australia, the Western Australian Minister for Transport has said, as I understand it, that he does agree with the philosophy of this legislation, that he does intend to implement it in his own state and that he is working through a process to ensure that intrastate operators in the state of Western Australia are not adversely affected financially as a consequence. It is up to him to find a legal and constitutional mechanism that enables him to do that. I am sure that, at the end of the day, Western Australia will implement this legislation. We will therefore see a uniform set of rules applying in Western Australia, as will apply in other states.

The parliamentary secretary failed to point out that his Labor colleagues in New South Wales are not exactly living up to the promises that they made just prior to the New South Wales elections in March. Interestingly enough, a few weeks before the elections in New South Wales, the NSW Livestock Transport Association held its annual conference. It invited to the conference both the then government minister for roads, Ian Armstrong, and the then shadow minister for transport for the Labor Party, Brian Langton. Each of them was posed the same question: `Will you or will you not implement the national registration charges as proposed by the Commonwealth government by 1 July 1995?' Ian Armstrong, the then minister for roads in the New South Wales coalition, said that they would not because they were concerned about the loss of revenues that the state would experience. However, he said that they would do it at some stage in the near future but not by 1 July. Brian Langton, representing the Labor Party, said that they would implement these uniform registration charges by 1 July 1995.

To substantiate that case, the then Leader of the Opposition, Bob Carr, wrote to the RTF coordinator, Andrew Higginson. In his letter, Bob Carr said that the state Labor Party would implement these charges by 1 July. In his last sentence, he said that `as a first step Labor will ensure that national charges are introduced in New South Wales from 1 July 1995'. That is now not the case. Since the election of the Labor Party to government in New South Wales, it has backed away from that so-called ironclad commitment in writing made by the then Leader of the Opposition, who is now the Premier of New South Wales. It has said that the Labor Party will introduce this legislation in its own state to establish national charges if and when other states do exactly the same. It has now backed away from its ironclad commitment made in writing by the then opposition leader, now Premier, Bob Carr.

The parliamentary secretary failed to point this out in his speech. It needs to be pointed out because it highlights that there is a lot of toing-and-froing in all of this. At least the Minister for Transport in Western Australia, Eric Charlton, has been consistent in his concerns about this and has done his best to overcome the problems. Over the last year or so, the Liberal and National parties in New South Wales have also been consistent in what they have been saying.

We have just seen some double-faced actions on behalf of the Labor Party in New South Wales, which is disappointing to say the least. I hope the Road Transport Forum and its members in the state of New South Wales take this cause up with the Minister for Transport in New South Wales, Mr Langton. It is quite obvious that he has seriously misled them, as has the Premier of New South Wales, on this very important matter.

Some other issues are worthy of mention in the course of discussing this bill before the House. I refer to the issue of fuel excise for the industry. It all relates to a system of charging the industry for the damage that it does.

The National Road Transport Commission process has established that a user pays charge for the road transport industry would equate to the 18c per litre fuel excise which is currently collected. The industry is prepared to pay its way. It recognises that if the NRTC says that it is going to cost 18c a litre to recover the costs incurred as a result of its trucks driving up and down the roads of this country then it is prepared to pay. But the industry asks the obvious question: `What about the rest that we pay that does not go towards covering the cost of the damage that we do to the roads?' At present road transport operators are paying 32.5c per litre in fuel excise.

The NRTC says that the industry is actually incurring a cost of only 18c per litre yet the government is charging it 32.5c per cent litre. The Road Transport Forum and the road transport operators around Australia are saying that they want the 14 1/2c difference in their pockets. They would like to see, and they would have expected to see by now, the government come forward with a proposal to charge them what it costs to operate their trucks on the road and anything in excess of that rebated to them in whatever form.

The road transport operators are very disappointed because the government in Canberra has not done that. They believe that they are being overtaxed and overcharged. Indeed, it is quite true that they are being overtaxed. The average semitrailer operator in Australia pays about $66,400 in taxes and charges to the state and Commonwealth governments. That has been increased dramatically since the last election. This government increased the fuel excise by 5c per litre in the 1993 budget which added something like $6,000 a year to the cost of operating an average semitrailer.

Quite rightly, road transport operators are saying, `This is an outrage. We do not want to be charged any more than we should be charged. We believe it is fair to expect us to pay for the damage done to the roads by our trucks, but we think it is unfair to pay any more than that.' I think that is a fair argument that they put. They are still paying 14.5c per litre in excess of what it costs to cover damage done by their trucks to the road system so they are legitimately asking this question.

The other point road transport operators make is that they would like to see more money spent on the roads. I am sure that would be the wish of everybody if we lived in a perfect world. Certainly, this government is not being fair in its outlays for roads in Australia. Some $840 million is allocated for roads in the budget released this week by the Treasurer (Mr Willis). That is half the amount the government indicated in the budget papers prior to the last election that would be allocated towards roads. It was stated in the 1992 budget papers that some $1,600 billion would be allocated towards roads. In the 1995 budget papers we find that only $840 million is allocated towards roads.

Road transport operators are saying to themselves, `We are paying an increased amount in fuel excise and we are paying an increased amount in charges and yet less money is being allocated towards roads.' I think this is another argument that is legitimate for them to put. Therefore, I believe the government should be addressing the matter. It is not, at present, addressing it in a way that would satisfy the road transport industry. If the road transport industry is to indicate its satisfaction with the government's performance then it would like to see this inequity—that is, the fact that it is paying more and more in fuel taxes to the Commonwealth government and getting less money back for road funding—addressed, as, indeed, most motorists would.

When this government came into power 12 years ago the fuel excise was 6c per litre. Today the fuel excise for leaded fuels is 34 1/2c per litre and for unleaded fuel and diesel it is 32 1/2c per litre. According to the budget papers, in 1982-83 road funding was $150 million and in 1995-96 road funding is $840 million. If we take into account the effect of inflation we can see that the Commonwealth government has got a lot more out of the motorists and road transport operators than it has returned to them for road funding. These issues need to be addressed by the government. It has not been doing it satisfactorily. I know that my colleague on the other side of the House would like to get up in a hurry—

TALK.START.PARA: —Untrue.

—I hope it is untrue for your sake but we do not want to hold you up any longer than necessary. I have two other things to say. The parliamentary secretary referred to distance measuring devices in his speech. There is no device known at this stage that we can rely on to accurately measure distance without somebody rorting the system in the process. A couple of years ago in Wollongong I attended a conference of road transport operators to which a person from New Zealand had come across. The New Zealand government had introduced a system whereby truck operators paid according to the distance they travelled. All this did was lead to a new industry developing where people illegally sold hubometers. Shonky road transport operators bought hubometers and put them in the wheels of their truck, indicating a much lower mileage than had been travelled by the truck and therefore incurring much lesser charges for the truck's operations. This is possible with any of the devices known at present.

PARA.TAB: If you have a distance measuring device for road transport operators it is possible for people to rort it. That is why in the end, I believe, charging road transport operators on a distance basis is never going to be quite fair. Honest people will adhere to it properly and pay according to the amount of distance they travel but dishonest ones will find it easy to cheat the system. Therefore it creates an inequity between honest and dishonest people that puts the dishonest operator at a financial advantage over the honest operator. This is something that the Road Transport Forum legitimately puts forward as another reason why these sorts of charges should be applied—it does away with the opportunity for people to cheat the system.

In the discussions that have been held over time with the road transport industry the commitment has been given that these charges will be refined over time. We look forward to that process occurring. I am sure that as time goes by and we get some experience up on the clock it will be discovered that there are things we can do better in terms of these national registration charges. We may be able to do it in a different fashion that is fairer and cheaper. We may even be able to do it at a lower cost. Hopefully that will be the case. We look forward to seeing the government fulfil its commitment of refining these charges over the next 12 months and in the years ahead to ensure that it implements these things in the most efficient and equitable fashion possible. In the process the government should consult with the industry to ensure that it has chased up every possible avenue to provide the industry with the most efficient and fairest form of charges that will apply to the industry.

If those things are done and we continue down this process and if Western Australia, New South Wales and the Northern Territory implement these aspects of the bill, then we will end up with a road transport industry that can look forward to lower costs, fewer bureaucratic difficulties and a more efficient system to work within. If those states do not do that, then we will have a problem on our hands that will lead to greater inefficiencies and greater costs being incurred on the industry unnecessarily. So the federal opposition, the Liberal and National parties, will be supporting this legislation because it is an important part of the micro-economic reform process. We recognise the arguments put forward by the Road Transport Forum as being valid and we will support these two bills, as we have other bills that have been put forward in this regard over the last 12 months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the comments of the shadow minister for transport, the member for Hume (Mr Sharp), in expressing support for the road transport legislation, but let me take him to task over his comments on roads. They are nice, easy words and it is a nice falsehood to peddle around Australia but your constituents in the industry are not that stupid when you talk about funding for roads. The honourable member for Hume and his colleagues know very well, as I know, that at the 1991 Premiers Conference an agreement was made on the sharing of road responsibilities. That agreement provides that every cent of the costs associated with building and maintaining the national highway system, which has since been extended considerably, is to be borne by the national government. That system functions today.

PARA.TAB: The costs for building and maintaining other than local roads are to be borne by state governments. The costs for building and maintaining local roads are borne by local government. In the carve up of finances that are available, federal government, as I said, meets every cent of the cost of building and maintaining the national highway system. The money that the states used to get for arterial roads was transferred into the general revenue grant. That gave the states—and this is what they sought—much greater flexibility to use that money as they wished. That arose as a result of an initiative from the state transport and road ministers, not from this government. So the states have that right and that responsibility.

Local governments similarly receive a grant each year. It goes directly to them and is identified as being for local road use but does not require that it be used only on local roads. Again, that gives more flexibility to local government. So let us put paid to the falsehood that the member for Hume and some of his colleagues try to peddle around this country. It is a falsehood which is insulting to the intelligence of those in the industry and in government agencies who know something about it.

I have a little more to say on this. When we come to arterial roads or major roads, other than national highways, states in effect have three bites of the cherry. Firstly, they have a share of general revenue that they get from federal government—and a major proportion of that general revenue from federal government is collected through excise on fuel. So they have a share of the federal fuel excise. Secondly, they now all have their own fuel franchising levy or a levy which in different ways and means they can raise on the sale of fuel—that is, their own or the equivalent of their own excise. So they have a share of the federal excise and they have their own charges. Thirdly, and additionally, they have a share of the general revenue grant from other purposes. So, with their wisdom and knowledge of state road systems, they can use as much or as little of those three sources of funds as they wish. It is their decision.

I suggest to the honourable member for Hume and his colleges opposite that they should be talking to their National and Liberal party colleagues in the state governments, convincing them that, as state governments, they ought to be spending a greater proportion of their revenue on road building and road maintenance. My dear colleague the member for Hume understands what I am saying; he knows it is correct and smiles in agreement. But I just say to those opposite: you can peddle that line for so long, but you will run out of steam after a while and lose all credibility.

The purpose of the two bills before us—the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1995 and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1995—is to amend the Interstate Road Transport Act 1985 and Interstate Road Transport Charge Act 1985 in accordance with national charging and regulatory amendments being developed by the National Road Transport Commission. The acts provide the legislative framework for the federal interstate registration scheme for vehicles that are engaged in interstate trade and commerce. Those registration costs go to meet some of the costs associated with the usage and wear of roads.

The amendments in themselves reflect the charges developed by the National Road Transport Commission and agreed to by the Ministerial Council for Road Transport. The Road Transport Charges (Australian Capital Territory) Act 1993 gives effect to these charges in the ACT and sets the model for other jurisdictions to pass through complementary legislation. The changes, as proposed, are to come into effect from 1 July 1995.

The amendments provide for the removal of the option to nominate the actual distance amount as the amount of charge to be payable in respect of registration, and the removal of the option to pay the registration charge by instalments. The amendments remove references to motor vehicle and trailer charge monitoring devices used for the purpose of calculating the actual distance or actual distance amount. The amendments replace the actual distance amount and the imputed distance amount for the calculation of the registration charge with an annual registration charge set out in the schedule to the act. They also take effect from 1 January 1995.

I recall—and I will refer to this again later—that, when in 1985 we brought in this landmark legislation, there was great representation from the road transport industry to have fitted to vehicles a measuring device to measure the distance travelled by a vehicle. Many did not want a flat charge. That was too hard, it was unfair—it was a charge irrespective of usage made of the roads.

Many of them argued that the only fair way to do it was to have a hubometer fitted to the axle. We were assured that they could be provided in a form that would be tamper proof—that is, so no-one could fiddle with them—and that that was the way to go. We accepted that advice and yielded to it, but experience has shown that it was not the way to go. The hubometers were not tamper proof. It is like the old story with legislation in this place: immediately we legislate to correct an improper practice, another army of lawyers goes to work to find another loophole in the law. Obviously, that is what happened here.

Under the 1991 intergovernmental agreement on road transport, the Commonwealth, states and territories agreed to the reform of heavy vehicle charges by 1 July this year. That was reaffirmed at the Australian Transport Council in October 1994. It is disappointing to note that only the ACT, Victoria and Queensland have indicated definitely that they will implement from 1 July this year.

The government and the industry will continue to encourage all jurisdictions not to delay action until 1997-98, because these important reforms are needed urgently. Not only will the amendments result in more than 50 per cent of heavy vehicles achieving lower charges than they do now, but they will at last, after decades of neglect, bring in to some parts of Australia common national rules for mass and loading, common national in-service standards, common road worthiness standards and, for more latter times, improved productivity for B-doubles and other heavy vehicles.

I find it almost incomprehensible that, given that we started the reform of the road transport industry in 1983 and given that there was unanimous agreement between transport ministers to set up the national road freight inquiry—the industry had to be addressed—almost 12 years later some of the states are finding reasons why they should not carry out their obligations and implement the measures we set out to achieve in 1983-84.

I hope that there will be sufficient public pressure to bring those states into line. We understand that there will be some changes to their financial arrangements and sources of finance, but governments have had to adapt to those changes in the past in respect of many other issues, and that is the case here. The overall benefit is so great that this country cannot afford to continue to be hampered and held back by the impediments that arise from inconsistent regulations and standards across the states.

In October 1994, the ministers made a further commitment to progress with the agreement and work towards a common date of commencement. They now say that all the states and territories were not ready to implement on 21 April this year. Some progress has been made, but there is some distance to go and we have to push on with that.

At the Australian Transport Council meeting in April, ministers reaffirmed their commitment to the implementation of that package of initiatives. I have listed those key reforms that are to be implemented by July. They include the common national rules for mass and loading, the common national in-service standards, the common road worthiness standards and the improved productivity for B-doubles.

When I introduced the Interstate Road Transport Bill into the equivalent chamber in Old Parliament House on 11 September 1985, I said that the importance of road transport could not be overemphasised. I said that it was landmark legislation and another element in what we were developing—it was in the early stages at that time—in a national set of transport objectives. Those objectives included, firstly:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the development of safe, efficient transport systems for the movement of goods and people both within Australia and in international trade—
secondly—
. . . providing the opportunity for all Australians to have reasonable access to transport services for employment, business, recreational and other needs—
and thirdly—
. . . implementing these aims in the most efficient and socially effective way.

Those objectives remain. They are even more important today than they were then. Considerable progress has been made by successive Labor governments since, but we need to have cooperation from the states and territories, because they carry out the registration and supervision of the industry in each of their respective states and territories.

PARA.TAB: I refer to pages 21 and 22 of the May edition of Truck Australia. Far be it from me to praise performances in the past, but I recommend that article to you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I know that you are interested in the trucking industry. I recommend that you read those two pages. The article makes the point that we learn to speak with one voice.

The article covers the history of the Australian road transport industry—how fragmented it was at that time and how our government helped bring that industry together. The associations were all brought to the one table. They were also brought together to the national inquiry that I referred to earlier with the state and territory governments. There was a realisation that the industry, the governments and the customers had to get together around the table to develop a better industry, to improve its performance. We are some 12 years down the track from that event. As I said, progress has been made but a lot more progress has still to be made.

Over the past 20 years—I am partly referring to the national transport planning task force report and to the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics information paper No. 38—we have seen the domestic freight transport task in Australia more than double. It is expected to grow at a relatively fast rate. Therefore, it is essential to Australia's future progress that we accelerate the development of an integrated national transport system.

That system should embrace all forms of transport—road, rail, sea and air. It is essential that we work towards that objective. That means putting aside the wasteful and, what I find, obstructive arguments about the merits of one system versus another. As a parliament we have to concentrate on the building of better relationships, linkages and interfaces between road, rail and sea. For too long we have had sectional interests hiding behind partisan debates about road versus rail, for example. The recent national transport planning task force found:

SPEECH.PARA: On the major intercity corridors, investment in rail is not expected to have any significant effect on investment needs for roads. Even if rail could capture the entire growth of intercity freight, this would delay timing of economically justifiable road projects by less than 5 years. It would reduce Australia's carbon monoxide emissions by less than 0.25% and road accidents by an estimated 0.3%.

I hope that puts the relationships of road and rail in a better perspective. Those figures underlie the need to develop a total transport strategy with priority being given to maximising the efficiencies, the linkages and the interfaces. It is not so much the need to build more; it is more a case of making what we have work better, particularly at the interfaces where road meets rail and where road and rail meet the sea.

PARA.TAB: There has long been the argument about road and rail, but rail has always had natural advantages arising from cargo type, quantity, timeliness and distance in about 40 per cent of the transport market. Similarly, road transport, for similar kinds of reasons, has had a natural advantage in about 40 per cent of the task. Yet decades have been wasted squabbling about competitive advantages and disadvantages in respect of the residual 20 per cent of the freight market. That diverted attention away from the overdue improvement of the 80 per cent of the transport task that was possible: the 40 per cent of rail and the 40 per cent of road. The inefficiencies of that 80 per cent are to an extent being addressed in this legislation—specifically, the 40 per cent in respect of road.

It is regrettable, as I said earlier, that with the passage of this legislation for interstate road transport there are still some states dragging the chain, despite having that four years notice of the need for reform and of the commencing date. Inconsistencies between states in road transport regulations will remain a major impediment to greater efficiency. As the national transport planning task force found, inconsistent regulations are both a cost burden and a source of frustration for the transport industry. To those states that are dragging the chain I say: so much for your trumpeting on the issue of micro-economic reform.

When we look at the overall issues and try to get them in proper perspective we find that there are many misconceptions about the role of transport in our economy and the nature of the transport task performed by each form of transport. Whilst this bill deals exclusively with interstate road transport, we need to look at transport as a whole to put those issues in their proper perspective. There are three ways we can look at it: on a weight basis, on a tonne per kilometre basis or on a transport sales value basis. If we look at tonnes carried, we find that, according to the report, 1,337 million tonnes of freight were moved in Australia in 1991. Seventy-four per cent of that weight was carried by road, 23 per cent by rail, three per cent by sea and 0.01 per cent by air.

To look at how far those tonnes were carried, we turn to a tonne per kilometre measurement. On a tonne per kilometre basis road carried 33 per cent; rail, 32 per cent—so they are about the same; there is just one per cent difference—sea, 35 per cent; and air, 0.01 per cent. Then when we turn to the dollars, the value of those transport sales, we find that in 1988-89, which are the latest figures available, the value of the transport market was $13,850 million. Road gained 73 per cent of the market; rail got 19 per cent of the market; sea, six per cent; and air, two per cent. So on the weight and tonnes carried, road clearly dominates. But they each have similar performances in the tonne per kilometre measurement.

Those figures reflect that road performs most of the shorter distance intrastate-intraregion task. The flexibility point-to-point pick-up makes road the most appropriate vehicle to use. Rail, where large tonnages over long distances are involved, has that natural advantage so it picks up its share. Similarly, air is of growing interest and importance, and sea, with three per cent of the weight or 35 per cent on a tonne per kilometre basis but only six per cent of the share of the market in money terms, has other long distance advantages and is the most energy efficient form of transport.

Overall, road is moving around 1,000 million tonnes of freight a year over an average haul of 90 kilometres. This is another of the misconceptions. When you mention trucks people think of big interstate rigs. But the reality is that the average haul of a truck is 90 kilometres. The interstate trucks carry an important part of our transport task but the vast majority of trucks are involved in carrying short distance cargoes.

Also the report showed that the market shares of each mode are affected by the ability of transport operators to build on the individual characteristics of each form of transport and make those into selling points. The basic conclusion that comes out of the BTCE report in 1994 is that the prospects for substantial change in market shares of the forms of transport is limited because each mode offers particular advantages and suits particular market segments. As I conclude on those points, I come back to the point I began with, which is that each form of transport has particular advantages.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the second reading debate on the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1995 and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1995 to contribute to this very important subject. Of course, for a nation desperate for export dollars, road transport and road networks should obviously be a priority area for debate in this parliament.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the amendments to the Interstate Road Transport Act 1985 is to remove the option for the owner of registered vehicles to pay a registration charge based on distance travelled and to remove the option to pay the registration charge by instalments. The amendments to the Interstate Road Transport Charge Act 1985 set out registration charges for vehicles under the federal interstate registration scheme. The shadow minister for land transport, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp), has said that the coalition supports the passage of these bills, which I note have industry support.

I would like to talk a little bit about fuel taxes because, quite obviously, the motorists and the transport industry pay a substantial contribution each year through fuel taxes to Commonwealth revenue. Although the revenue to be raised by this legislation is relatively modest—an estimated $15.3 million in 1995-96—it is important to remember that these collections are just one of numerous charges that are faced by the road transport industry.

In addition to paying federal or state registration charges, heavy vehicle operators are also faced with a plethora of other taxes, including tax on the fuel they use and sales tax on their vehicles. They and the Australian motorists are concerned at the very low proportion of these taxes that is spent back on the nation's roads.

The 1995-96 budget, the one that the Treasurer (Mr Willis) brought into this House on Tuesday evening, will continue the record of low road funding levels and is further evidence of the government's neglect of Australia's land transport infrastructure. Over recent years, the Labor administration here in Canberra has cut federal road funding from two-thirds of the fuel tax that is paid by the motorists and by the road transport industry to a mere eight per cent of total fuel tax revenue.

If you believe in the user-pays principle, you would have to say that there is certainly not a user-pays principle applied to taxing the road transport industry or the motor vehicles used by the families of this nation. Of course, it is just too convenient a tax to collect. The government has got fuel tax collectors at fuel bowsers all over this nation. The motorists and the transport industry have been too easily hit by this tax. We on this side of the House would like to see a fairer share of that tax revenue going back into the nation's roads.

Road charges and the fuel tax apply to both urban and rural based road users. However, the federal government has virtually abandoned our rural roads. Out there in rural Australia—whether they are primary producers or tourism operators—they are paying their fuel taxes, but are not getting the money coming back into the road infrastructure. The government has abolished funding under the national arterials program, the provincial cities and rural highways program and the state arterial road program. Notwithstanding that, people out there on those rural roads today are still paying their fuel taxes as they pull up to the bowser and contribute once again to the coffers in Canberra.

The only direct funding going back into our rural road system is now confined to Australia's national highway system. The national highway system forms only 2.3 per cent of Australia's road system but receives 100 per cent of federal road funding.

Roads are of great importance to the economic development of this nation in that they facilitate access to markets for our primary products, our secondary products and our mining industry. Primary industries and mining account for 30 per cent of the export wealth of this nation. Roads are also extremely important to the tourism industry. Tourism is now contributing 10 per cent of export revenue to this nation.

Roads are of major importance to this nation. No longer do many of our major rural roads receive any direct Commonwealth funding, which is the issue I want to address. Roads which have been abandoned and no longer receive direct funding by the Commonwealth under the Labor administration include the Pacific Highway—and we have seen many tragic accidents on that road, and I am sure you, Mr Deputy Speaker Newell, as the member for Richmond, would well understand that—and the Great Western Highway in New South Wales; the Calder Highway and the Princes Highway in Victoria; and in my own electorate the road from Goondiwindi north, the Leichhardt Highway, which extends across the electorates of the member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell) and the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) right through to Charters Towers. Another road in the electorate of the member for Capricornia, the Dingo to Mackay route, also falls into the category of roads for which the Commonwealth has abandoned funding.

Rural and regional communities in Australia have good reason to ask what is going on. They are taxpayers by virtue of the fuel pumps all around this nation, but they are not getting the money coming directly back into these roads. The roads I have just mentioned are all in provincial and regional Australia. The government has abandoned funding to these roads. These communities pay fuel tax like everyone else, yet the roads they need to transport their goods to market on, the roads tourism operators need to operate on and roads needed for the safe transport of rural families are, obviously, not federal priorities under this government.

I want to touch on road funding efficiency. While the government is very efficiently extracting money from the long suffering road users of this nation, it is not nearly as committed when it comes to spending that money efficiently. I think that should concern all members of this parliament, because at the end of the day the money that is appropriated from the taxpayers' pockets should be spent as efficiently as possible.

Two inquiries have shed light on the wasteful way in which the federal government manages its road funding. The first of these was in a House of Representatives standing committee report on road construction and maintenance entitled, appropriately, Driving the road dollar further. Nothing could be more important from the parliament's point of view than to see taxpayers' money spent efficiently. This report by the House of Representatives standing committee found that the federal Department of Transport had no effective procedures in place to ensure that federal funds provided to state, territory and local governments were used efficiently for road purposes.

This report was completed in December 1993. It is to the great shame of the government that there has still been no government response to this report's recommendations. I wonder what the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) has been doing since 1993. A parliamentary standing committee has reported to the parliament and we are still awaiting a response from the minister. Apparently the minister does not see it as a high enough priority to respond to a parliamentary committee. I would have thought that the efficiency with which the parliament appropriates money and spends taxpayers' money would have been a high enough priority for the minister to look at and respond to.

The government's administration of untied funding for local roads is also criticised in the report. It is about time the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe), whose portfolio covers untied funding for local roads, got his act together and responded to the matters that are raised in the report which affect his area of responsibility. The Deputy Prime Minister has recently issued a great many reports on urban planning and on other issues. It would be nice if he took the time to respond to these issues which are so critical. One of these is the administration of the untied funding to local roads. The Deputy Prime Minister has been very good at commissioning reports. It is obviously much easier to commission reports—spending more taxpayers' dollars—than it is to respond to those reports. I urge the Deputy Prime Minister to respond to those parliamentary committee's findings which date back to 1993.

Local roads are the lifeblood of Australia's rural communities. Without roads we will not achieve any decentralisation of this nation. They are important to the people who live in rural Australia. They facilitate the safe access of families to schools. What could be more important to us than seeing the school children of this nation travelling on safe roads in rural Australia? In my own electorate of Maranoa there are many roads that are local roads, parts of national highways and parts of highways that were once funded by this federal government but have now been abandoned in relation to funding. These are roads where school buses travel daily taking the next generation of Australians safely to school—roads that are so often hazardous roads. That is why people in rural Australia place great importance on safe and trafficable roads. School and education are fundamentally important things that people living in rural Australia place a great deal of emphasis on.

We find that the 1995-96 budget continues the Labor Party's dismal record in providing general purpose funds for local councils. This severely limits councils' ability to fund essential services such as roads—and safe roads. In rural Australia the drought and the current economic climate have impacted on the resources of ratepayers. They are left to fill the void that this government has created by its failure to continue to provide an adequate level of general purpose grants to local governments to enable them to share equally, or to share in a more equitable manner, the great federal tax revenue pool.

If we look at general purpose grants, we will find that, in real terms, this year's budget will return fewer dollars to local governments for general purpose grants than when the government came to office in 1983. At the same time, other areas of expenditure have increased substantially under the Labor Party.

Federal general purpose funding for local government was one per cent of total federal tax revenues in 1983. That figure has fallen to 0.67 per cent of total federal tax revenue in 1995-96. I think that illustrates the fact that this Labor Party is not committed to local government in this nation. It is not prepared to give local governments a fair share of the tax revenue that the Commonwealth receives annually from the taxpayers of this nation.

Of course, local government in this nation is the closest tier of government to the people. I would have thought that, if you are committed to the people of this nation, a fairer share of tax revenue would be given to local governments to ensure commitment to people at a local level.

The worsening condition of our local road network is a consequence of a federal government which has quite clearly abdicated its responsibility to Australia's third tier of government. That is clearly indicated by the fact that one per cent of total tax revenue went to local governments in 1983 and only 0.67 per cent will go to local governments in 1995-96.

The other report which I referred to earlier was the Auditor-General's report entitled The national highway: lifeline of the nation, which was delivered in December 1993. This report identified the very considerable savings that could be made by the government in managing the federal road program. It identified that savings of up to $21 million in project management and administration costs could be made. It identified savings of up to $8 million in general administration costs which could be made. It also identified savings of up to $50 million which could be made through improved maintenance techniques, and better cash management practices would also save another $4 million. The Auditor-General's report shows that there is $83 million of potential savings that could be made as a result of a more efficient use of national highway maintenance funding. However, these issues still remain to be addressed. These savings could well be used to provide much better and safer roads across Australia.

In concluding, because I notice the time is running out, I would like to say that, whilst we on this side of the House will be supporting the bills before the parliament, I would ask the Minister for Transport to think again about those regional and rural road funding programs which he has abolished. I would also ask him to look at those parliamentary reports which quite clearly identify areas that he must respond to sooner rather than later. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just in opening my remarks, I remind the House, as I have before, of my extensive involvement in the trucking industry in the past. I established a major north-west trucking concern as a cooperative to service the consumers of the town where I then lived in Carnarvon. When I say `established', I do not want to take all the credit, because there were others involved, but I was certainly a very active participant and, in fact, provided trucks to make up the service. I was able to convince the then state minister of transport to allow double bottom road trains to operate south of Geraldton and add to the efficiency of handling freight, which is so significant to people who live away from the rail system in particular.

PARA.TAB: I am no stranger to this particular debate. I have participated in it time and again in this place. I am interested to see that we are now moving away from the various distance monitoring devices which I have criticised time and again in this place—and, might I add, to such people as the now retired member of parliament Bruce Baird, who had a total fixation on tachometers. I put them in trucks as a management tool and watched drivers manipulate them overnight so they could take the prime mover off their rig to visit their girlfriend in a town about 50 miles away. The simple fact was that they were a joke. They were not even useful as a management tool, and we had a government totally committed to them. Every time I wrote to Bruce and said, `Listen, for goodness sake save yourself and your constituent drivers some money,' I never got a reply.

It has been a rather stupid fixation, which I guess in the end resides with the departments involved. When one looks at the contribution of the trucking industry to the cost of living of Australians, it is just outstanding to see how, as a sort of non-tariff barrier, certain state transport departments have used the licensing system both through the prohibition of certain licences and through stacking their costs to prevent the road transport industry from efficiently competing with state owned railways. It is all here in the documentation we were advised to read.

It is interesting that in New South Wales, which is still to make up its mind about this particular legislation, for such an efficient vehicle as a VW—and I do not know why there is a difference on maximum mass—the licence fee can be $14,700. The recommended licence fee under this particular legislation is $5,250. For many years, certain states, including Western Australia, have charged substantially less than that—in fact, $3,530.

It is easy to look at the trucking industry and say that it is some sort of monster that goes around frightening people and beating up our roads. The other aspect of it expands rapidly with people such as those whom I represent who live in the less populated areas of Australia at increasing distances from the centre of supply—and do not think the centre of supply is necessarily the nearest capital city.

There was a time for many decades when a firm in Western Australia called Mills and Ware produced all our biscuits in the port city of Fremantle. It was taken over by Arnotts and, after many years of operation under Arnotts' management, it has since been closed down. Today, Western Australians are more than likely to get their biscuits from Brisbane. It seems an awfully long way to cart some biscuits, and they frequently travel by roads. Therefore, Western Australians have a great interest in the cost of road transport, be it intrastate or interstate.

Every time you increase the cost of operating a truck, it is quite clear that that cost will eventually filter through to consumers. This parliament, along with state legislatures, has an absolute responsibility to ensure that the trucking industry is not hampered by legislation to provide safe—and I underline the word `safe'—and efficient services.

When talking about road damage, there is the continuing myth that the larger the truck the greater the damage. In fact, the maximum size combination that is mentioned in this legislation, which I would refer to as a triple bottom road train where the licence fee proposed is $8,500 per annum, puts the least pressure on the road per tonne of goods moved because it is using one prime mover to shift what would be roughly three 20-tonne loads.

The prime mover on a semitrailer is a very substantial part of the gross weight of the vehicle. When we consider that the same weight component can be used to cart three times as much product in semitrailers that are substantially lighter, our gross mass on the road, which is what does the damage, per tonne of goods carried is less. So the larger rigs are beneficial. Of course, people say, `They're dreadful things, they frighten you and they're very hard to pass.' So are three individual semitrailers driving along the road, particularly if they tailgate, which is to be condemned. The conservationists may approve of tailgating as a fuel saving mechanism. The simple fact is that, if people in smaller vehicles get behind a large semitrailer, they will find that their foot comes back about an inch on the accelerator. The semitrailers have a huge suction capacity.

Nevertheless, individual semitrailers are much more dangerous on the road than are three linked-up trailers. Of course, we need to take into account traffic density. Even in Western Australia, we need to consider that the town of Carnarvon or something of that latitude is about the level at which a triple bottom semitrailer can operate.

I wish to make a point about these configurations. I think the current Minister for Transport in Western Australia, Eric Charlton, is to be congratulated. He occupies the upper house seat contiguous with my electorate. He is a member of the National Party. We have had our arguments from time to time, but I think Eric Charlton has carried out his duties as transport minister in a very exemplary and courageous fashion. He decided to run a trial allowing double bottom road trains to move into what one would call a metropolitan area from a break-up point, which was probably 20 kilometres outside the metropolitan area.

We had all the locals going bad. They thought it would mean that every second motorist was going to get run over. The state government conducted a trial which eventually operated over 500 movements. I just happened to be driving in my car on the day that Mr Charlton announced that the trial had been successful and that he was going to allow under strict control the continuation of this practice. I will give you the reasons why in a moment.

When Mr Charlton made this announcement, one of his opponents, a female councillor from the Swan Council, rang up to say how dreadful it was that Mr Charlton had made this decision because she and her committee had been unable to observe the operation of these road trains. They still did not know what a threat they represented to the community. What she was really saying was that they had been operating 500 movements and she had not seen one of them. Obviously, they could not have been too dangerous to the people.

Why should we try to keep this rig together? I ran a business at a time when there was not such an enlightened view. We originally had to break up the road trains at the town of Geraldton, 300 miles north of Perth, and later at a point known as Muchea, about 30 miles out of Perth. It used to cost us one-third of the gross return of that extra trailer to shift it that last 30 miles. We had to pay someone to come out and do it. These blokes had to build up their own rigs or our driver who had just driven 600 miles—maybe 1,000 miles from further parts north in Western Australia—had to take one trailer into town, unload, drive back and then go through the process of hooking it all up again. We used to pay someone else to do it and it would cost us one-third of our revenues for that trailer for the last 30 miles. We had to charge someone for that.

That is the reason why people do their best to get these rigs as close as possible. Might I add that within this charging system there are other configurations which are nearly as long as a double bottom road train and which to my knowledge have been operating around the Perth metropolitan area for the last 30 years and no-one has even known they were there.

I am attracted to this proposal because it attempts to give a uniform and what would appear to be a basically reasonable charge structure to all sorts of configurations. It particularly sends a message to New South Wales and, to a degree, Victoria that using licence fees as a non-tariff barrier to efficient road transport is grossly improper. Victoria made headlines when it decided that it would license B-doubles. Anyone would think they had spiked wheels and they were going to run over people. There was absolutely no argument. A B-double is such an innocuous piece of road equipment compared with a triple bottom road train. It was a joke. There was absolutely no reason in the public safety interest to say that those sorts of vehicles should not be on the road.

So the first thing is that this legislation, being nationally uniform, does contribute to reducing those costs. One of the reasons it cannot be fully implemented is New South Wales and its new government. I do not know what it is about Labor governments—they say one thing before the election and do the opposite after it. We have Mr Carr, who made an absolute commitment to this scheme, backing away from it before he said thank you to the electors for electing him. The reality is that they are doing it because they are going to lose this non-tariff barrier and, they believe, some revenue. Yet the Road Transport Forum has told them they will probably increase their revenues simply because of all those who had escaped and gone to operate a trucking business in another state where they could license at lower costs. On the east coast, with these sorts of movements, you can practically not do a delivery.

For instance, as you, Mr Deputy Speaker Andrew, who have just taken the chair, would know, the traffic between South Australia—or certainly its very productive eastern areas—and the western areas of Victoria in stock carting and other things is huge. People operating large rigs on the east coast are almost by definition interstate carriers because their business is always across somebody's border. So it is very good news in that regard.

My concern, and it is also expressed by the Minister for Transport in Western Australia, is that the charges to be implemented are still substantially higher than those charged in Western Australia—and, I note, in the Northern Territory, which seems to have a lesser concern—and we in Western Australia are concerned about that. I have to say that the railway system we have, which is being made efficient and competitive under the Court government, is still not equipped to make those parcel deliveries. It does not, I might add, in any part of Western Australia, particularly my electorate which is totally reliant on road transport for its daily requirements. The rail system has quite properly been focused on bulk carting, which is what it is good for, and it struggles even in that regard.

I point out to people constantly that the last time I did the figures the rail system in my electorate was shifting 1,400 tonnes of product per annum per kilometre of rail system. The iron ore operators in the north-west shift something like 80,000 tonnes of product per kilometre of their rail system. This gives some idea of how expensive rail infrastructure is in remote areas where the demand just does not exist, even when four to eight million tonnes of grain are being produced a year. It is peanuts in talking about the task that railways can accommodate and it is where the truck is more efficient, particularly when there are door-to-door type deliveries.

While we accept these charges, I note that the Western Australian government is still looking at its options in terms of being able to rebate some of this additional money that would be collected back to trucking operators. This would not be for trucking operators but for their consumers. I say to anybody who suggests that the road transport industry pockets all these little paybacks that the industry is just so competitive that it is difficult even for owner drivers to make a living. There is no doubt that they are working at the margin—and the most competitive margin.

Consequently, we have got a situation where any substantial increase in licensing fees for trucks would affect the consumers in my electorate. When one looks at the vastness of Western Australia and the distances involved in serving the great mining communities in our north-west, then the cost is very significant. It has got to be resolved. Basically, I think everybody recognises the advantages of uniformity, particularly in allowing the most efficient rigs to operate within states and to have them all marked out, as they are here, so nobody can have special rules for special vehicle combinations. That is the advantage of this arrangement, but it cannot be allowed to damage the welfare and the financial viability of businesses throughout Western Australia.

In that regard, I also support the remarks of the previous speakers from this side. They complained bitterly about the inadequate amount of money that is being provided from the federal coffers for road construction within Australia. Road infrastructure is and will remain a responsibility of the government. It is an infrastructure that services people in many ways.

Let me point out the contribution of Western Australia to the national export economy. Somewhere less than 10 per cent of the population is producing about 30 per cent of the country's export income and a huge percentage of GDP relative to numbers. Therefore, it is very important that Western Australians be encouraged to continue to carry the less productive sectors of Australian society in this day and age. Road infrastructure is one of their major requirements. It is silly to keep saying that the providers have to pay for it when they are returning such a massive dividend to the national economy.

In a more general sense, licence fees are an appropriate way of contributing to road infrastructure. In rural or remote areas, road infrastructure is primarily a transport service. Within metropolitan areas it is a convenience. There are too many vehicles on the roads on certain days of the week, and that puts massive demands on the cost of roads. In a metropolitan area, narrow roads are not sufficient, and so there are flyovers and, in more densely populated capital cities, one road built on top of another. That is a lot more expensive than getting out the grader and flattening a bit of bush.

The reality of that situation is that people who want a three-car garage—we are going past the two-car garage—have to pay an up-front fee for the services that are put there, whether or not they use them. I live in a house in the metropolitan area. The bit of road outside my property was completely rebuilt recently. It was designed in such a way that it cannot be used effectively because it has roundabouts and everything else.

Those sorts of things are very expensive, yet they mean that a truck cannot get down the road—and that access might just be handy from time to time for the delivery of furniture or whatever. These things would have cost a fortune on a per kilometre basis, yet they only service 20 or 30 motor cars, some of which only come out of the garage on a Sunday.

Vehicle licensing, particularly of the `family car', is something that should be structured on the basis of the infrastructure that has been created and which might seldom be used by those vehicles. It is sensible that that be done. On the other hand, trucks are out on the roads every day of the week. They use the roads all the time and they pay fuel tax on a minute-by-minute basis, practically 24 hours a day—certainly 20 hours a day. That is the component that is not being returned in sufficient quantity. That tax was originally introduced for the purpose of building our roads and our road infrastructure. It has become a major point of collection. It is downright foolish in the context of Australia to tax transport at the levels we do. We only fine our own producers.

Mr Deputy Speaker Andrew, you have heard of this example. Orange juice from your district is transported on a truck that pays $2,000 a week in collective taxes, while your Brazilian competitors bring the stuff in by international sea transport at no such tax levels and dump it right on the doorsteps of Melbourne and Sydney. The people you represent have to transport 700 kilometres by taxed road to achieve the same thing. It is no wonder they are struggling to compete in an international context.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mrs Crosio) read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to make a number of amendments to immigration and ethnic affairs portfolio legislation. These amendments to the Migration Act 1958 give effect to the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration—report on Asylum, border control and detention—temporarily extend the duration of the migration agents registration scheme, provide for changes to the incoming passenger card and make other minor and technical amendments.

PARA.TAB: The joint standing committee report made a number of recommendations in regard to the release of persons who arrive in Australia without authorisation. Amongst other aspects, the committee expressed concern—in its recommendations 10 and 11—that there should be a capacity to consider release in instances where the period of detention exceeded six months.

Many of the committee's recommendations have already been implemented. This bill implements the government's response to recommendations 10 and 11 of the report by providing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs with a non-delegable and non-compellable discretion to determine that a person is an `eligible non-citizen'. Such persons are then able to apply for a bridging visa which authorises their release from detention. The power to make such a determination must be exercised by the minister personally.

If the minister decides to exercise the power, the minister must table a statement in each house of the parliament setting out the determination and referring particularly to the minister's reasons for considering that the determination is in the public interest.

Part 3 of the Migration Act 1958 provides a comprehensive registration scheme to regulate the conduct of migration agents. This part of the act is subject to a `sunset clause' whereby the registration scheme will cease in September 1995 after having operated for three years. The proposed one-year extension of the scheme until 21 September 1996 will allow the government time to consider and respond to the forthcoming report by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration on its review of the scheme, and provide time for the passage of any legislative changes. The committee's report is expected in June 1995.

Section 506 of the Migration Act 1958 stipulates that regulations are to provide for the giving of information on a passenger card. Subsection 506(2) requires that all non-citizens travelling to Australia, unless exempted, must answer the questions on the passenger card. Subsection 506(3) requires that certain questions are to be included on the passenger card.

The proposed amendment to subsection 506(3) will allow greater flexibility with passenger cards and will assist the streamlining of entry of passengers into Australia. It will remove the present obligation to ask questions relating to all the matters provided in subsection 506(3) of all people completing the passenger card.

Current legislation requires the Commonwealth to provide English language tuition to holders of certain types of visas. The amendment to the Immigration (Education) Act 1971 seeks to exclude from the entitlement persons who hold permanent visas through having satisfied the principal applicant criteria for class 816 or class 818 entry permits—under the Migration (1993) Regulations. The adult migrant english program, AMEP, provides tuition in English as a second language, ESL, to migrants from non-English speaking backgrounds. Tuition is provided to a functional level sufficient to facilitate employment and to achieve personal settlement goals.

On 1 November 1993 the government announced changes to provide access to permanent residence to—amongst others—better qualified asylum seekers and persons who held, or were eligible for, concessional temporary entry permits; providing humanitarian extensions of stay for people from Sri Lanka and the former Yugoslavia and certain persons who held, or who had undertaken study towards, higher educational qualifications. Such persons could apply for class 816 or 818 entry permits.

When approving the introduction of the new classes, the government considered that principal applicants would need to demonstrate a capacity to communicate in English or to have an English language proficiency sufficient to have undertaken or completed studies in Australia. Therefore, those persons should not have any need to access AMEP.

This amendment will both exclude those seeking access and discontinue access to those already receiving tuition. Departmental records at early May show that of almost 6,000 principal applicants approved so far, around 400 persons have accessed the AMEP.

The Migration (Delayed Visa Applications) Tax Act 1992 was introduced at the same time as the Migration Reform Act 1992 as part of a package of measures designed to improve the effectiveness of Australia's control of its borders and the regulation of the entry, detention and removal of people who have no entitlement to remain here. It was intended that the tax—payable by certain persons who obtain a visa having previously been unlawful in Australia—would act as a disincentive for people to become unlawful for long periods. The legislation was not intended to raise revenue.

It is the government's view that the objectives of the Migration (Delayed Visa Applications) Tax Act 1992 are being effectively achieved through other legislative and procedural mechanisms. Since the introduction of the Migration Reform Act 1992, only very limited classes of visas are available to be granted to persons unlawfully in Australia at the time of application. Unlawful non-citizens face mandatory detention and removal by force of law and bear the responsibility for associated costs.

Other initiatives implemented in the Migration Reform Act 1992 have progressed and streamlined compliance mechanisms. Additionally, increased investment in the compliance area has resulted in a significant improvement in a number of key indicators of compliance with migration laws. Against this background, the objectives of the Migration (Delayed Visa Applications) Tax Act 1992 are no longer regarded as necessary for the successful achievement of compliance strategy.

Repeal of that tax act is proposed with retrospective effect to the date of its commencement. The numbers of applicants liable for the tax are few. Retrospective repeal would ensure that no persons would be liable for the tax, and is considered the most equitable course of action. It is proposed that any debts payable under the act be extinguished and that a refund provision be provided. The projected revenue loss is negligible. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1995, I find it extraordinary that we have had before the parliament this year legislation on migration on five separate occasions. Again, we are making quite substantial amendments to the legislation in this area. I am sure all of us who considered Senator Robert Ray's codification of the Migration Act would never have contemplated that legislation dealing with migration entry to Australia would assume the complexity and difficulty that one often associates with taxation laws of this country. I want to take the opportunity to deal with several matters in order. Each of them is quite separate and will be dealt with separately.

PARA.TAB: The first issue relates to amendments to detention procedures, as was made clear by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mrs Crosio). The amendments that we are dealing with arise from the consideration of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration report entitled Asylum, border control and detention. It was not the first occasion on which the committee on migration had dealt with matters associated with detention. The committee first had given consideration, in one of its earlier reports, to the whole question of refugee entry and the unauthorised entry into Australia of asylum seekers.
