Of course, in the committee report where these matters had been addressed previously, a very considered rationale for the regime of detention was made explicit. It was asked that the matter be addressed again at the beginning of this parliament, and that is why we had the joint committee examine the issue of detention.

It is important to consider the particular amendments that are before us in the context of the committee's very detailed examination of this issue. If the second reading speech—which is really quite brief—perhaps coupled with the explanatory memorandum and speeches that might be made in this place, gives some guidance as to the way in which the particular provisions in this act are to be considered, then one might very well get an unbalanced view of the way in which this matter has been addressed. I want to take this opportunity to draw attention to the committee's very severely circumscribed set of proposals which the government has adopted for dealing with this issue.

The amendments that we are dealing with are designed to deal with a very narrow range of circumstances, to provide relief for those people who have been dealt with harshly as a result of clear and manifest administrative failure. The non-compellable discretion that is being given to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in a certain very specifically prescribed set of circumstances was developed in this form because the committee believed that there was a clear rationale that should—subject only to these exceptions—always be followed for detaining unauthorised border arrivals.

The committee's report sets out very clearly in chapter 4 the rationale for detention of border arrivals. At the beginning of that chapter, certain evidence that was given by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs was quoted with approval because the point that needed to be understood was this:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . consideration of the question of detention cannot be seen in isolation from related matters of entry processing, entry controls and the whole cycle of processing people seeking entry and stay in Australia which, of course, includes the removal or deportation of those who cannot sustain claims. Our approach to each of these impacts needs to be clearly balanced, including the way in which each element impacts on the other if an effective and efficient approach is to be pursued.

The rationale and discussion went on to make it very clear that this was not a punitive measure but was a measure designed to ensure that the efficacy of our system of migration entry is to be maintained. The committee reviewed the experience of Australia in dealing with asylum seekers and border arrivals, and it dealt with the difficulty in locating and removing failed asylum seekers. I wanted to put before the House a quote which, again, comes from the department. It says:

The Department's experience in the past in locating and removing failed asylum seekers does not lead us to a sanguine view of the level of compliance we can expect with the requirement to depart once the decision making process had been exhausted, nor for that matter does the experience of other countries. For these reasons, I am not satisfied that an alternative approach to that now applied would work.

We have a situation where, if we are going to be able to effectively deal with the issue of unauthorised border arrivals, if we allow those people to enter into the community we cannot then expect to be able to write to them later and ask them to turn up. We cannot expect that, if they fail our tests for asylum, they will simply present and say, `We are happy to go now.' The experience is quite to the contrary.

PARA.TAB: This report details all of that. We canvassed the arguments in favour of detention, particularly on the issues of entry control; the arguments against mandatory detention; and the question of how long people should be maintained. We looked at a whole set of issues relating to various mechanisms and conditions for release. We looked at arrangements that might be otherwise used, including bonds and sureties. We looked at community sponsorship schemes and at the experience abroad.

We are very conscious that here in Australia we have water borders which make control much easier. The numbers entering Australia are such as to make it possible for people to be taken into detention and maintained with a reasonable expectation that the costs will not be unmanageable.

We looked particularly at situations in places like the United States, where they have attempted to put in place release programs. People build up very high expectations as to the way in which these programs might work. But our review of the experience in relation to the operation of pilot projects, particularly in the United States, was that they were only appropriate given the very special circumstances operating in America, where they had much larger numbers than we do, or where they were dealing with people whom, very often, we would allow into the community and deal with in the ordinary way. I refer to people who enter Australia legally, have visas and later mount claims for refugee status. In the main, that is the same situation that they were trying to deal with in the United States of America.

Our ultimate concern in this matter is that we need to have a rational and sensible detention policy. We should recognise the wide range of circumstances that people face when they come to Australia. We should be capable of properly assessing the claims of people who are in need of protection, and be able to quickly accommodate them and settle them in Australia. Coupled with that, we need to have the capacity to remove from Australia, quickly and sensibly, those people who are trying to manipulate our compassion, where there is no bona fide reason for accepting that they have a need for protection.

The committee mounted some criticisms of the way in which the department of immigration, coupled with the involvement of the courts, had handled a lot of the early asylum claims. We recognised that people had been detained for very long periods of time. We did not regard that as being satisfactory. The committee's view was that we must have prompt decision making. I want to draw attention to a couple of comments from the report, because it is important that the committee's rationale be on the record and understood.

In considering issues relating to the most appropriate border detention regime, the committee said that Australia does have a sovereign right to determine who may enter and the conditions under which people are able to settle in Australia. The committee came to the view:

SPEECH.PARA: That those who arrive in Australia without authorisation or with invalid authorisation should be detained upon arrival. To do otherwise would compromise Australia's system of immigration control. In addition, detention of unauthorised arrivals ensures that the community is not exposed to unknown or undetected health or security risks. In the Committee's view, Australia's immigration control system must be upheld and it is important to ensure that immigration to Australia cannot be achieved simply by arrival.
We went on to say:

During the inquiry, there was general agreement with the principle of detaining unauthorised arrivals while their identity and background are determined, and to allow lodgment of their claims to enter and remain in Australia. The consensus in submissions was that detention in such circumstances is appropriate, with two to six months being the suggested time frames. It was the need to extend detention beyond a relatively short time frame which was challenged by community and advocacy groups.

It was in that context that the committee came forward with this very specific set of proposals which recognised the need for fair and expeditious processing of applications, that litigation should be minimised and that unauthorised border arrivals who claim that they are refugees should have prompt determination of their claims, including administrative processing, administrative review and any legal appeals. We proposed that that ought to be done within six months but, in cases where that was not possible, where people were held beyond six months, that the minister be given a discretion—a non-compellable discretion; I make that very clear.

PARA.TAB: We said that the minister would have to consider very specific matters, including age, health, and experience with torture and trauma, which would allow for release. Health, character and security checks would need to be satisfied. The likelihood of somebody absconding is an important issue that has to be addressed, as are the extent to which people have been timely in pressing their own claim for refugee status, the extent to which they have cooperated with the department in considering their claims, and whether or not adequate support arrangements would be available if they were released into the community.

We also said that Australia's international obligations have to be considered. We set down very specific provisions that we believed ought to be followed in relation to bridging visas: the requirement for people to report regularly, to reside at a nominated address, to notify the department if there were any changes, and to depart, or present for removal, if they were refused refugee status.

I offer those comments to give force and effect to the nature of the recommendations that were brought forward and to ensure that those who look at these matters are very conscious of the view of the parliament on this matter as expressed by its parliamentary committee. Anyone who has any doubts and who in reviewing these matters might try to push the minister should be aware of the extent to which the parliament has a view that these matters need to be very carefully controlled.

It has been made clear that the joint committee is conducting an inquiry into the migration agents registration scheme. It is considering its draft at this stage. The bill lifts for one year the sunset clause that had been included to ensure that there was a review of this matter. We think that the proposals here are reasonable. The scheme has been operating for only 2 1/2 years and the jury is out on its adequacy and effectiveness and the need for such a scheme. The report is something that the government obviously needs to have in considering the matter.

The third issue relates to, I guess, departmental convenience in the issue of passenger cards. The passenger card is one of the security measures used to protect our borders. People have to fill it out when they are entering or leaving Australia. The act now specifies the questions that have to be asked in relation to a citizen's health, criminal record, purpose of visit, unpaid debts and other matters. The bill is designed to remove those very prescriptive requirements and to give the department carte blanche, subject to publication in the Gazette, as to the form that these new passenger cards might take.

My colleague Senator Short in another place has sought information from the department about the way in which the department envisages these matters being addressed. Obviously, there is some sensitivity about passenger cards and the nature of the questions that are asked. I imagine the parliament might be very well concerned if future tourists to Australia, and Australians coming and going, when filling in passenger cards were asked questions relating to health. I am only surmising what issues might be addressed, but, with the concern about AIDS, a question could be asked about sexual preference. I would want to see the parliament consulted about any passenger card dealing with such a sensitive issue.

I note that at the moment there is no requirement for this matter to be referred back to the parliament. Before this matter is concluded in another place, we will be seeking advice as to whether or not it is envisaged that the notice that is to go in the Gazette would in some way be covered by the Disallowable Instruments Act and be a matter that would require further parliamentary review. If it is not, and the nature of answers to questions that my colleague in another place puts gives us reason for concern, then this is a matter that we may want to press in the other house. It really depends to a degree upon the extent to which departmental officers are able to complete the briefing, which I understand has not yet been concluded, on these particular issues.

I find the repeal of the Migration (Delayed Visa Applications) Tax Act extraordinary. The act was designed to have provisions in place to give people some encouragement, incentive, to come forward at an early stage and regularise their status. Also, we decided to put a tax on them for each year that they delayed coming forward.

However, the department now tells us that it has become apparent that this intention has not been achieved through this amendment to the tax act. In fact, what it has probably done has been to put off people from coming forward, and it has probably led to Australia's being host to many more illegal immigrants than might have otherwise been the case.

This bill now seeks to repeal retrospectively the tax act. It says that any tax that has already been collected will be refunded to the taxpayer. I am not sure that that is an appropriate term for somebody who has been an illegal entrant but, nevertheless, it will be refunded. The advice we have received from the department is that nobody has yet paid this tax.

The parliament was put to the trouble of legislating in this area, with certain assumptions being made in relation to behaviour, by people who were long experienced in these matters. It is extraordinary that these people did not know that the legislation might have adverse consequences and achieve an objective which was diametrically opposed to that which they were seeking to achieve.

I find the arguments in support of this quite unconvincing, and I daresay my colleague in another place will press this issue. It does reflect on the nature of the advice that the government has received in this area if it seriously believed that this would work. We were asked to accept it in good faith and the experienced people who offered this advice now tell us, `We have got to take it away.'

The final matters relate to the Immigration (Education) Act. People would know that the large number of asylum seekers who sought protection in Australia after the Tiananmen Square massacre, and many others from other parts of the world, who ended up in queues to lodge applications for protection was very much an outcome of the way in which the government handled these matters, and particularly the involvement of a former Prime Minister in the decision making process.

Before the last election, the government had left open the question of what might happen with unresolved asylum seeker cases, particularly the large number of students who were given preferential rights to protection in Australia without substantial inquiry as to the nature of their claims—which is what happened after the Tiananmen Square massacre. As the situation had gone on for years where the government failed to address the issue, we saw in November 1993 certain decisions taken to regularise the status of those who had been dealt with in this way.

The government announced in 1993 that it would provide access to permanent residency in Australia for the PRC nationals who were here at the time of the Tiananmen Square massacre, that being under class 815 entry permits; certain better qualified asylum seekers and nationals from Sri Lanka and the former Yugoslavia who were temporarily resident in Australia, provided they met certain criteria, that being under class 816; and some highly qualified students undertaking postgraduate studies in Australia, under class 818 permits.

Certain criteria were set down for those applications, which people had to meet. All applicants were required to meet health and character standards. Under the 816 and 818 conditions all principal applicants had to be aged less than 45 on that date, they had to be visaed to travel on or before 12 March 1992, they had to enter Australia before 1 November 1993 and they had to have sought refugee status, or Sri Lankan or former Yugoslav humanitarian temporary entry permits, before 1 November 1993. In addition, the class 816 applicants needed to meet English language and post-secondary education standards and the 818 applicants needed to have postgraduate qualifications.

These are the two classes that we are talking about—large numbers of students seeking to regularise their status and people who would not normally have qualified for migrant entry, being granted concessional entry to Australia in circumstances in which others would fail and so getting a significant advantage, and being allowed through the door. Yet all we said was that they had to meet certain English language or certain educational standards.

Let me just say about those who hold postgraduate qualifications that in order to get those qualifications they have to meet certain English language tests. So the English language tests essentially apply to both groups. We ask the class 816 students to come forward and be tested, and presumably we pass them. We have had a whole lot of students who have got postgraduate degrees and have passed the test in English, and what do we find? After they have been through that, they apply for and have a statutory entitlement to 510 hours of free English language tuition at the taxpayers' expense. How is it that people that the government has tested are able to access free English language courses? Why do they need it? What is the competency of the people who test them and allow them to enter and to stay—unless it was done with a nod and a wink—if they demonstrate a need still to come back and get free English language tuition? What does it say about the department? I do not like to blame departments for these matters. What does it say about the government that made these decisions that the department had to administer?

In this case, what we are doing is now repealing an entitlement to free English language tuition. We are told that 100 people have already accessed such classes. Presumably, some who are already part of the way through their courses might have their access now revoked when this is passed, but we are also told that they will not be required to refund the cost of the course. I find the whole thing inexcusable, and I am sure other members of the parliament see it likewise.

It reflects very much upon the way in which the government rushed these matters through and the way in which it did not consider the consequences of its decision to allow such entry. It also says a great deal about the way in which the tests were carried out if, as I said before, those people who were being tested—and who had to demonstrate that they had adequate English language competency to be able to stay—achieved a pass, but were then able to establish that they needed further English language tuition in the special programs that we have for new arrivals.

Migration legislation is important and there are some outstanding issues that have to be resolved, particularly in relation to the passenger card, as I mentioned. When this legislation is considered in another place, we will flag whether or not further amendments might be necessary. In the main, the bill does not meet with any opposition and, in this place, we will accede to its passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —As indicated by the previous speaker, the member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock), this legislation is largely supported by the opposition. The first measure follows from the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration entitled Asylum, border control and detention in February 1994. I had the privilege, with the member for Berowra and other members, of being part of that investigation, which not only heard a significant number of witnesses but also had the opportunity to visit detention centres at the airports, Villawood and Port Hedland. With the exception of a minority report—from recollection, by one senator—the committee did come to a common position on these matters.

PARA.TAB: Despite the consistent campaigns by a number of church groups, welfare organisations and a significant sector of newspaper commentators who take an interest in this policy area, the committee did come to the conclusion that any release from detention should be very strictly limited, and the member for Berowra went through a number of those qualifications which the committee suggested should govern any action by the minister to allow release, because the committee was of the view that people advocating a very liberal approach to release of detained illegals were unrealistic in their analysis of what happens.

Such people came before us with concepts such as that we should let people out on bail or on bond, et cetera. The reality out there is that large numbers of people who are going through our refugee process do not give a stuff about the requirements of our legal system. They essentially want to stay here regardless, and experience has shown that very few of them wish to participate in that legal process once they start getting bad news. According to a statistic cited on page 153 of that report, 27 per cent of people do not seek a review of the decision once they receive the first negative.

So what we have from the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus), who was operating—as is indicated—from suggestions of the committee itself, is a very restricted area of release. It entails that it should not be reviewable, that it should not be compellable; the minister does not have to release these people and he cannot be compelled by the courts. But there is a degree of parliamentary oversight in so far as there is a requirement for a tabling of those decisions when he does make them.The requirement also means that it is a prescribed type of person, and there must be a degree of departmental responsibility in what has led to the prolonged period of detention.

So, essentially, the granting of the bridging visa is very much constrained by the parliament's and the government's view that the public interest demands that in large the detention policy be continued and that it be based on sound public interest grounds. So the first provision in this legislation is that after a period of six months the minister has the right to release a number of people if he so chooses.
Turning to some of the conclusions of that committee in this area, it also said at page 152:

SPEECH.PARA: In the Committee's view, sufficient consideration has not been given by community groups to the varied and significant costs which would be associated with supporting persons in the community, particularly if that support was required over a long term. Such costs not only would comprise the basic costs of food, clothing and accommodation but also would include capital and maintenance costs . . .

One of the points of concern of the committee was that all these groups who were running around saying we should release everyone after five minutes were really not so keen to come forward themselves and say that they would financially look after these people if they were released. They were essentially saying that the Australian taxpayer should do it. So that was one of the matters that affected the committee's conclusions.

PARA.TAB: Similarly, at page 153, the committee—and I have mentioned this briefly before—was concerned with absconding, and that is the reason it has been basically in support of detention with very restricted early releases. The thrust of the committee's view is on page 153 in paragraph 4.172 where it says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a high rate of absconding amongst unauthorised border arrivals would result in unauthorised arrival being perceived as providing ready access to long term entry. Such a perception would undermine Australia's system of immigration control. Without any significant evidence to suggest that absconding would not be a problem, and indeed current evidence to suggest that Australia already has a substantial problem with persons who are in the community and who did not depart Australia after being refused refugee status, the Committee is not convinced by reassurances that absconding is unlikely to arise or that, if it did arise, it could be overcome through the use of community support networks.

The committee then went on to look at the kinds of things that should be considered with early release: whether the applicant had a special need on the basis of age, health or previous experiences such as torture and trauma; whether the applicant had satisfied appropriate health, character and security checks; the likelihood of absconding; reasonable basis for the applicant's claim for refugee status, et cetera. So that is the first part of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: The issue of migration agents is under current investigation by the committee, and it is fair to say that, whilst there is a largely bipartisan approach in this area, there is probably a different emphasis on the different sides of the House. I for one would be very supportive of the continuation of the regulation of migration agents. Analysis has shown that this area has been subjected to a large amount of fraud because people who are very desperate will do anything to stay here. If lawyers or others who operate in this migration agent area say to those people that for $10,000 they will fight their case and win, those people are prepared to pay anything. Quite frankly, in those circumstances one would not blame them.

Essentially, the committee is still discussing the matter. There is a wide variety of questions: whether the current legislation has reached a point where it actually works against migration advice groups and community non-profit organisations; and whether they have been hit too hard in the requirements to actually get their staff regulated. People have to travel many kilometres these days to get staff. There is also the issue of whether, in attempting to counter fraud, deception and ineptitude in the industry, we may have hurt some groups.

Another question is whether we establish funds which are similar to those in the ELICOS area. In that case, people offering English classes to foreign students have to pay into a fund to protect people against companies going down the chute. Similarly, in this situation there is a question of whether we should set up funds to protect people from a person being debarred from the industry. Apparently, there are loopholes in the current legislation which mean that, once registered, agents cannot give advice to individuals, but they can give advice to family members. There is also the issue of giving advice to people overseas.

There are a lot of issues in this area. At the moment, both sides of the House disagree on the substantial point of the legislation in this particular area. In the case of the government, the emphasis is on saying that this area needs strong regulation; that there is a need to deal with the problems in the area; and that this legislation is merited by the experience of refugee groups and various claimants. On the other hand, there is probably a view on the opposite side of the House that over-regulation does nothing. The compromise is for the current sunset clause, which would have ended this legislation on the regulation of migration agents in September 1995, to be extended.

I move to the question of English language classes for people such as those who stayed here because of events in Tiananmen Square, people from the former Yugoslavia and people from Sri Lanka. As has been noted by the honourable member for Berowra, that is of concern. Essentially, we are offering status in this country to people who supposedly have a certain level of English ability. That is one of the reasons why we are taking them in. We are not taking them in because they necessarily have any other characteristics, but mainly because they come from countries that did have, and which continue to have in some cases, significant internal problems leading to discrimination, murder and torture.

At the time we said that we wanted these people to have some English language qualifications. However, what we have now is a situation where apparently, out of 6,000 people, some 432 have offered themselves for English courses. Those classes are costing about $1,000 per term per person—and that is the cost to the Australian taxpayers. So there is, indeed, a loophole that must be closed with regard to these people having access, as visa cases, to English classes.

Unless the government acts, as it is now, there is a threat that more people will access the system. The cost of those classes so far, just for two terms, is theoretically around $860,000. That is a significant sum. It has been estimated that if you took the average number of people accessing English classes as are in the groups admitted so far, then another 280-odd would be accessing this government and taxpayer largesse. As I say, it is necessary to do something about this loophole.

There is an argument that some of the people who were admitted because of their tertiary qualifications actually went through courses that did not require the same level of English as was required in the testing for access under this visa system. There is a substantial problem there. It is preposterous that those people, whom the Australian public let in through a fairly liberal—by international standards—refugee humanitarian policy, are doing that. As the member for Berowra has commented, to some degree the admission of the Chinese was a departure from Australia's general line of non-discriminatory refugee policy. It is the third significant departure. There was the Lebanese concession, the Vietnamese boat people, and now the Tiananmen Square group. They have all been substantial departures from our policy.

These people were given the advantage of not being individually examined. They were given an advantage which large numbers of other people around the world would have liked to have had. Despite this advantage, we now have a large number of these people deciding that Australians can pay for their English classes. I commend the decision of the government to make sure that this loophole is closed.

Another matter worth considering briefly is passenger cards. I find it difficult to swallow the view that we have to be too concerned about the intrusiveness of the Australian public in regard to people filling out forms. There is apparently a concern that we are in some way invading the privacy of the passengers coming to this country. Whilst we must be mindful of the reality that tourists get less attracted to a place if they are hassled too much, there is also the argument by the department that many of these questions are answered when they fill out the original visa application.

One would not want to put too much emphasis on the argument that we should in some way be worried about being too intrusive when we are asking a group of people about criminal matters and carrying out health checks. In some cases, there could be changes in those circumstances since the time they filled out their visa application. The opposition has said that it has some concerns about the possible extension of the provision in this regard. That is an aspect of the legislation that the government will have to address.

Whilst on the question of privacy, I want to briefly talk about the decision of the High Court in the Minister of State for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs v. Teoh. This is typical of the issues creeping into this policy area. The High Court is seemingly of the mind to take on the role of the elected representatives of this country. I would be the last one to decry our signing international conventions, but it does seem that once we sign some of these conventions the High Court manages to put very contrived arguments which extend the original intention of this country when it signed those conventions. At times it goes well beyond what I think would be the commonsense view of the purposes of those treaties.

This case involves the deportation of a person who was found guilty and convicted of a number of drug offences. The High Court came to the conclusion that the decision maker had not put enough emphasis on the future of the children. We really should question whether Australia should be held to ransom by this sort of contrived, extended argument by the High Court that, because we have signed an international convention for the prevention of cruelty to children, that allows some guy convicted of a variety of drug offences to stay in the country because his children might be affected by his having to leave. The Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) has been critical in recent times of similar decisions by this court. The High Court stated in this case:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . ratification by Australia of an international Convention is not to be dismissed as a merely platitudinous or ineffectual act, particularly when the instrument evidences internationally accepted standards to be applied by courts and administrative authorities in dealing with the basic human rights affecting the family and children.

For the High Court to hold this country to such an extended requirement of administrative decision making is absolutely ridiculous. When we look around the world and see the large number of other signatories to these sorts of conventions and the way they operate, it is really going too far to say that that in some way binds us to keep every drug dealer in Australia if their children would in some way be affected by their deportation.

PARA.TAB: I indicate my support for this legislation. It seeks to give a reasonable right to the minister to release early from detention some very specified and restricted classes of people. It is pleasing to see the legislation closes loopholes in regard to access to English courses in this country by people who quite frankly, on any objective analysis, should not be accessing those courses. It covers a few other matters of a minor nature and those provisions are largely supported by the opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1995 and commend my colleague the member for Reid (Mr Ferguson) on raising the matters that he did. I begin by taking up the issue he raised at the end of his contribution—the determinations of courts and people using the rights they might have acquired and taking those rights to the nth degree. I recall some years ago that we needed to change the citizenship act. Honourable members will remember, and I am sure the honourable member for Reid will remember, that those of us with electorates with large ethnic communities used to have occasions often where people would come to Australia on a visitor's visa, overstay the visa, disappear or whatever and make a claim to stay in Australia. In the meantime they would have a child born in Australia. In those days you could acquire citizenship by birth in this country whether or not your parents were citizens or permanent residents. So the child would become a citizen, the parents would be prohibited illegal immigrants and the advocates would go around claiming that the parents should be given permanent residence on the basis that if they were not the rights of the child who was born here, whose parents were the illegal immigrants and who was now an Australian citizen by birth, would somehow or other be interfered with.

PARA.TAB: After a lot of soul-searching the government changed the law to provide that you only acquired citizenship by birth if one or other of your parents was either a citizen or a permanent resident. That was a loophole that we had to close. I agree with the member for Reid that often the courts, when looking at some of these cases on a one-by-one basis and not being aware of many of the rorts and ramps that are used by people attempting to stay in this country, tend to take a far too benign view of what people's rights are. Neither the member for Reid nor I would want to deprive people of their rights but you also have to consider the rights of all those other people who apply to come to Australia.

Every year we get over a million applicants. We take about 100,000. So one in 10 actually gets from the beginning of the queue to the end of the queue on the other side of the customs barrier at an airport around Australia. If we are going to find these people who come into the country with the intention of trying to rort the system, then the government and the courts should come down very heavily on them. Their rights have to be balanced against the rights of all those decent people who applied, failed to have their application accepted and then accepted that. The ones who turn up here and then demand that we do something for them are a bit beyond the pale.

The people who prey on those people are also being considered in this legislation. Part of this bill before the House involves the migration agents registration scheme, which was introduced in 1991 by the then minister, Gerry Hand, following a number of complaints by members both in this House and to the minister himself. As the minister foreshadowed at the time, the migration agents scheme is now being reviewed by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration. As a result of that review, this bill seeks to extend the time in which agents can register because, as members will recall, there was a sunset clause in the bill which would have had effect in 1995.

Many members here will recall that I have long been an advocate of the rights of migrants who, being new to this country and sometimes with poor English language skills, are a particularly vulnerable section of our community. In particular in the past I have been concerned by the operations of certain disreputable people in the migration agents industry. I should add at this point that those people are few, a minority in an otherwise very professional industry.

However, back in 1985, as the chair of the caucus immigration committee, I drew the attention of the House to problems surrounding the operations of migration agents and the need for some form of regulation. I reiterate: the crooks in the industry are few but their impact has a far-reaching effect and, in some cases, causes irreparable harm to people's lives.

At that time and since I have had many people come to me after finding that their applications either had not been lodged by these so-called agents or had been lodged incorrectly and they had been charged exorbitant fees. Finding sometimes that they were illegal residents in this country, these people, in their desperation and naivety, handed over even more money to these disreputable agents—people like the notorious Solan Baltinos, who formerly lived at Burwood and ran a very shonky organisation called the New Settlers Foundation.

Some members will recall that in 1989 in this chamber I named Baltinos and detailed some of his exploits—and exploits they were. Mr Baltinos was particularly adept at taking people's money but doing nothing for them. I said that Baltinos was `a person to whom the old Australian term "bludger" would certainly apply'. He was a bludger then and I have to say he is a bludger now. If ever there was a bludger in Australia, it is Solan Baltinos.

There were revelations in the press that Baltinos took donations from people, knowing that he could not do anything for them, of between $475 and $1,300 or $1,400. He made promises that he could get them permanent residence status—promises he was never able, or indeed never intended, to fulfil. One article in the press revealed that Mr Baltinos flaunted gold bars and wads of cash, and boasted to his son of his ability to get migrants' money `before their tears had turned cold'.

His son revealed in an interview a conversation with his father in which his father said, `Remember this, Nick—get the money off them before the tear dries in their eye. Desperate people find the money. If they haven't got it, they'll go to brothers-in-law or parents. They'll get the money. They'll find it. Don't you worry. You can ask them for anything.' It is exactly the type of pariah that Mr Baltinos was that the migration agents registration scheme now protects new migrants from.

A central feature of the scheme, as it was set up, is the complaints mechanism backed up by the powers vested in the board to issue warnings, to suspend or deregister agents and to refuse applications for registration. This mechanism provides protection for clients by ensuring that agents who do not meet professional standards are excluded from practising commercially. I understand that Mr Baltinos was such an up-front person he was never stupid enough to apply. The old adage we used to see in shops, `Don't ask for credit because refusal will often offend,' would certainly have applied to Mr Baltinos.

The government's principal objective in setting up the scheme was to improve standards of professional conduct and quality of advice in the migration agent industry. The establishment of the scheme recognised at that time that the industry was insufficiently organised to make full self-regulation a feasible option. Can you imagine garbage like Baltinos attempting to regulate himself? The scheme was established after extensive consultation and work with the industry, voluntary migration agencies and the legal profession. The concept of a `partnership' with the industry is the underlying philosophy of the scheme, and is reflected in its development, structure and operation.

From September 1992 to the end of September 1994, 2,517 people had applied for registration and applications were being received at the rate of about 40 a month. Of those, 40 were withdrawn, 169 were refused, 65 did not renew their registration, seven were invalid and one applicant was deregistered. From the 169 applications refused registration, 149 had been refused because they lacked sound knowledge of migration procedure; four were refused because they were not people of integrity; 11 were refused for both of those reasons; and five were refused because they did not meet threshold criteria, such as being an Australian citizen. The number of agents at the end of September 1994 stood at 1,692, with 166 applications under consideration.

A central feature of the scheme was the introduction of a complaints mechanism to provide protection for clients to ensure action could be taken against agents whose poor advice or whose professional standards were unacceptable. Included in that is the criterion of overcharging for services performed.

Many members in the past would have dealt with some of these agents before the industry was regulated. Indeed, some members of the legal profession took exorbitant amounts of money from people but did nothing more than write one letter for them and then send them along to see their federal MP or senator, who actually did do the job of trying to achieve what these people wanted.

I think the complaints mechanism is one of the most important parts of this legislation. It is complemented by the opportunity for people to lodge objections before the registration of an agent can take place. All complaints against registered agents and those who apply for registration are referred to the Migration Agents Registration Board.

While the scheme and how it operates are currently under review by the joint standing committee, there can be no doubt in my mind that it is working well to ensure that the Solan Baltinoses of this world are not able to prey freely on the very vulnerable people whom we are all in this parliament to represent. I think the legislation has worked well. When the committee reviews the legislation, I think it will come to the view that the legislation was very much needed.

I commend these amendments to the House. I thank the House for the opportunity to make some comments on what I see as a very important piece of legislation that was introduced some time ago in an attempt to register migration agents. I hope that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus), when dealing with the review that is done by the committee, will ensure that we continue to look after these people. Admittedly, they are often in dire circumstances and they are willing to take any chance they can to stay in Australia—and no-one would object to that.

The member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) and I represent electorates which include people who have come from truly terrible circumstances, and those people come to see us. If we could give out permanent resident visas, we would probably give nearly every one of those people who come into our offices the chance to have one.

Some of the Immigration people who work in these foreign countries have a very arduous job. I recall that some years ago, when I visited Thailand, I went to the Vietnamese refugee camps on the border of Thailand and Cambodia. There were thousands of Vietnamese and Cambodian refugees in these camps. Immigration department workers from Australia, Canada and the US were processing many of them. I sat through a number of interviews with a young woman from the Australian immigration department who was handling many of these cases. People would come in and she would talk to them. Some of them would get approval, and some would not.

On the way back to Bangkok in the car that afternoon, I said to her that it must be a terrible thing to have to make the choice. She said that it was the hardest job she had ever had in the department. Parents would come in with little kids, and she would look at the parents' application and know that they would not make it, but she would look at the little kids and think, `How can I not try to help you?'

I think those Immigration workers are some of the best representatives the Australian government has around the world. There are people in some parts of the department who do not do a very good job, and I have made remarks about that before. I must say that, after being in that camp with that young woman on that day, I was impressed greatly with the work done by the people from Immigration.

You cannot blame people who try to get into Australia and then, when they get here, try to manipulate the system so they can stay. But that is why we in this parliament have to be vigilant in ensuring that there is fairness in the system so that the same rule applies to every person who gets on that long queue—whether it is in Asia, the former Yugoslavia or Lebanon, when the war was on there. We should deal with them as fairly as we deal with those people who manage to get here and jump the queue.

If we cannot show that there is some integrity in the system at this end, we are just encouraging people to jump the queue all the time. One way of ensuring that there is integrity in the system is by ensuring that criminals like Boltinos are not there to raise people's expectations and maybe cause them to do things that might bring the system into disrepute. I think the registration of agents has gone a long way towards doing that.

I think the registration of agents took too damn long to happen, considering that there was provision in the immigration legislation for registering agents who acted outside of Australia. I think anyone outside of Australia who charged more than a dollar for advice to a person to come to Australia had to be an agent. But we did not register people who did that here in Australia. That led to a disreputable underside of the industry.

Some people will take a bit of offence at this, but I think it needs to be said. I have a twinge of doubt about the ability of people who were senior officers of the immigration department to become agents. While those people might do that quite properly and above board, it does tend to imply to people who are trying to stay in this country and who come from regimes where governments are, to say the least, often quite corrupt that as Mr X and Ms X were senior officers of the department before they became agents they will have all sorts of contacts within the department that can help them. I think there is something to be said for the American provisions—it might be the British provisions—that state that some time has to elapse between when you leave public service and when you enter a related type of industry, either lobbying the government or acting for people with the government.

I think there is a need in this very sensitive area for the right thing not only to be done but also to be seen to be done. Former senior people in the field of immigration acting as agents can give the impression that they have some inside knowledge and that their clients can get some inside running that others cannot. The committee might consider whether there should be some separation time between when people leave the Public Service and set themselves up in these kinds of jobs. I look forward to the report the committee will bring down on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I very strongly support the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 5). I think it is moderate and also overdue. One of the main benefits of this bill is that it will give the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs the discretion to determine whether a person is an eligible non-citizen. This is a result of the recommendations of the report on Asylum, border control and detention by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration.

PARA.TAB: I think this provision is a very useful addition. We have previously had the situation of people with very clear moral claim simply being precluded by the legislation. For instance, under the old act it was not possible to do anything about a person who was an unlawful non-citizen upon entering the migration zone, no matter how valid the case.

It was not possible to do anything where a non-citizen made an application for a protection visa after he or she had arrived in Australia. Here again, it is very sensible to have the ability to allow that to happen in certain cases. It was also not possible to do anything where a non-citizen had been in immigration detention for a period of more than six months after the application for a protection visa was made. I think that particular provision has to be treated with utmost discretion. I would certainly hope that any minister would do so.

There is a catch-all term in one of these provisions—where the minister thinks that the determination would be in the public interest. I have some difficulty with that because `what is in the public interest' is such a nebulous concept. I recall a previous minister for immigration pointing out that during the early 1970s there was a mass influx of what was clearly a criminal element into Australia from southern Europe. These people were actually detected by the department. Their non-entry was recommended by the department but that was overridden by the minister.

The minister of the day quite clearly and single-handedly established what was to be an element of criminals that put a great burden on Australia. That responsibility resides on any minister where you have this catch-all term about the minister determining what would be in the public interest. That is something which I think the parliament will have to keep under very close scrutiny. I am not opposing that provision being in the bill; I think there are clearly cases where it should be in the bill. I am just saying that the parliament will have to keep a very close eye on that particular provision.

I want to mention a few things about the actions of migration agents. I would like to echo the words of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay). I think some of the most incompetent people and charlatans have been found in this area. It is quite true that the average federal politician, no matter what side of parliament he is from, can effectively do and does do everything that a migration agent does, and does not charge. In my own office, which has a very busy migration workload, we find people coming to us repeatedly with expectations blown out of all proportion by migration agents and we find that these people have very often paid migration agents considerable sums of money for incompetent, inept advice. In some cases it has been a straight rip-off.

I am not sure that the registration of migration agents is overseeing them strongly enough. I might add that I thought the number of agents in Australia in 1994 was over 1,500. The previous speaker—I am indebted to him—said it was 1,692, which is far more than is necessary in my view. I am glad to see that we are making stronger efforts to control the numbers, although I am not sure that we are going to have the facilities to administer and oversee them well enough. I still find that people coming through my office have been getting very bad advice in this area.

The previous speaker talked about public servants going from the Public Service, the immigration department, straight into the consulting area. This concerns me as well. I feel that it sends the wrong sorts of signals to people. If this applies to members of the Public Service, then it applies even more so to ministers. I feel very uncomfortable when ministers go from a sensitive portfolio into the area of consulting because, with the best will in the world, it brings with it connotations which are very hard to refute. I say that with some sadness, because the minister involved was a man for whom I had a very high regard, although I had many arguments with him.

I want to address a few words on immigration as a policy. It needs to be stated over and over again that the only ground for any migrant coming to Australia is net benefit to Australia. If it is not a net benefit to Australia, then we should think very carefully about it. We may decide after thinking carefully that there are overwhelming compassionate grounds, and I accept that that is likely to occur.

One of the problems is the emotive nature of the refugee issue. Australia has a very good record in regard to treatment of refugees. Per capita, it has probably done better than any country in the world. I believe the flow of genuine political refugees to Australia today is minimal.

Most of the people approaching us for refugee status today are economic refugees. No matter how compelling their story of personal misery or personal suffering is, Australia cannot solve the world's economic refugee problem. Simple arithmetic should point this out. Were we as a nation to take 100 million people out of China or India, it would not make a scrap of difference to those countries—not a scrap—but it would give Australia a living standard somewhat akin to that of Bangladesh. That is not the future I want for my children. I believe the major responsibility of every government is not to the world but to the citizens of its own country.

I reaffirm very strongly my belief that immigration should be based entirely on net benefit to Australia; if there is no net benefit, then you simply do not do it. This will cause cries of `shock' and `horror' from some quarters who will tell me that the family reunion program is unassailable. I say it is not, and it must be reviewed. In the long term it will be reviewed but, in my view, it should be reviewed at the very earliest opportunity.

One of the reasons that the number of refugees in Australia has been allowed to rise is the growth of what I call the guilt industry. I get sick to the back teeth of reading numerous articles in the media and of hearing people in this parliament from time to time talking about the guilt that we share in Australia because of our treatment of migrants—of foreigners—and of our indigenous population.

I echo the words of ex-Senator Walsh. When we do this we usually put it back not on ourselves but on the unspeakable British. Senator Walsh was a man who grew up, according to his own book, in a family with a well-developed Anglophobia. He said that, by the time he was 20, he had realised that the British were certainly no worse than any of their contemporaries and, in many cases, much better. I think that is true.

Actions must always be judged by the era in which they happened, not by the standards of the day. If you judge the actions in Australia by the standard of the times, they were remarkably enlightened. You can always find in our history individual incidents which we should be rightly ashamed of but, overwhelmingly, I believe we have a proud history. It is certainly not one for guilt. I see a very erosive quality in this guilt which threatens our whole survival as a nation.

I have recently returned from the Ukraine. While I was there, I was reminded that on the shores of the Crimea Greek cities that had existed for a thousand years had just disappeared—just ceased to exist. If people think that this nation, as we know it, need necessarily be here in a hundred years time, they are wrong. It will survive only if we are committed to its survival. I affirm that the guilt industry undermines and saps the will of Australia's confidence in its national integrity and its sovereign right.

Let me repeat: the only reason for immigration should be net benefit to Australia. That sounds callous, but I believe that in Australia governments' responsibilities are to the people in Australia now. The migration industry is a well-developed industry; in Australia it is linked to the multicultural industry. The multicultural industry knows that its survival depends on an ongoing flow of migrants; it has to have new fodder.

From my own experience of migrants—I have an electorate full of migrants—their overwhelming view is that they want to be Australians. It is not migrants that are supporting the ethnic industry; it is the attitudes of people in government and academia that support this element in society that seeks to socially engineer and to manipulate. I think they are a scourge, and they must be opposed very strongly.

Unfortunately, people who try to oppose them are branded with the racist tag. I reject this out of hand. Today there is a much more accurate definition of a racist. I have given the parliament the benefit of this definition and I am happy to do it again. A racist is anyone who wins an argument with a multiculturalist. We should bear that in mind.
I support this bill. It is belated, but I think we are starting to realise the problems that we have put in store for ourselves and that we will have to address.

The arrival of illegal migrants in Australia affects my electorate probably more than any other electorate in Australia because of my very large coastline. Illegal migrants is an issue we are going to have to confront because it will be a growth industry. Australia is an attractive country. My recent month in Europe, albeit half of it in the former Soviet Union, has convinced me that Australia has a quality of life that does not exist elsewhere and a quality of life that extends down to ordinary people. Mind you, the quality of life in Europe if you are rich is very good, but for most people the quality of life in Australia is unrivalled. This is a great country. We have an absolute responsibility to future generations to make sure that it stays that way.

We must reject out of hand the social engineers who want to change the nature of this country. If governments do not heed this warning, they will be thwarted inevitably at the polls. At the moment we have a bipartisanship in relation to immigration. Bob Hawke said that one of his great triumphs was to conspire with the ACTU and the Liberal Party to get immigration and multiculturalism off the agenda. While his motives may have been good, that decision was wrong and silly. We need constant and ongoing discussion on these vital issues. If the people of Australia were consulted—and they have not been—you would find the policy of immigration would be overwhelmingly rejected. It would be sent where I believe it should go—to the dustbin of history. I believe that policy has already done enormous damage.

I am very pleased to see that Franca Arena, a woman who only a few years ago stood up in a conference and denounced me, is a latter day convert to the dangers of immigration. She has spoken out very strongly about ethnic language radio stations. Ethnic language radio stations are an anathema because they basically stop the integration of people in Australia. While there are elements in the community that seek to stop integration, for the future of Australia integration is essential.

I support very strongly that policy. If there is no national language, there cannot be any national goal or consensus. I believe the words of Franca Arena must be heeded by the government. I will certainly be pushing to make sure that the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) is aware of the vast concern that is felt throughout this country on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 5) which is before the House. In particular I welcome the amendments to the Migration Act 1958 which give the minister a discretion to declare a person who has been held in detention for more than six months following a visa application to be declared an eligible non-citizen so that he or she may be released from detention. That aspect does allow some discretion in humanitarian cases. The legislation certainly sets out those cases where some discretion is allowed for release from detention: the applicant's health, character and related matters.

PARA.TAB: I have always been a supporter of the government's policy on asylum seekers. A lot of criticism is made against the government's position on asylum seekers by organisations like the Catholic Church. Its position, I believe, is sometimes reasoned, but the government takes a position which is the only position that can be taken in these matters.

I also want to talk about the integrity of the visa system. I notice in the legislation that the Migration (Delayed Visa Applications) Tax Act 1992 will be repealed retrospectively. I note that the government's position on that issue is that other mechanisms can be used to achieve the same ends. Maintenance of the integrity of the visa system is important to my electorate of Leichhardt in Far North Queensland. The public is concerned, certainly in my electorate, about the number of illegal immigrants. The tourism industry is a very important industry in my electorate. There is no doubt that in the tourism industry a lot of people are working on both temporary entry visas and working holiday visas. I have already made comments in this place about the need not only to maintain the integrity of the visa system but also to rigidly enforce those regulations that are currently in place.

There is also concern about illegal immigrants—people working without working visas. When walking up the Esplanade in Cairns it is quite obvious that a lot of people who are working in the tourism industry are not Australian nationals. Unfortunately, there is a lot of suspicion in the Cairns population that some of those people are illegals. Certainly the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has at most times been vigilant in enforcing the regulations, but it is very significant that certain measures announced in the budget will target ensuring that those regulations are enforced.

The government has announced an employer awareness campaign and has allocated $709,000 to continue this campaign during 1995-96. The minister says that the campaign has already had a marked success. The number of employers who check the work rights of potential employees has increased by 71 per cent. Some 53 per cent of employers are now doing the right thing. There is a concern, nevertheless, that there are not only overstayers but other people working illegally. More than 16,000 people working illegally in Australia were located last year.

As well as funding the employer awareness campaign, the government has authorised additional information sharing between government departments and has endorsed prosecutions against illegal workers. The sharing of address information between the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs is a key element in these changes. I must say that I welcome that.

The arrangements allow the Taxation Office to supply the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs with the addresses of people whom the department has identified as being in Australia illegally. I would like to see greater liaison between the Taxation Office and the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in relation to those people who are here legally but are on either working holiday visas or temporary resident visas.

We do have a tax file number system. As I have said previously in this place, there have been allegations of people rorting the system, especially the working holiday visa system. If we could somehow use the tax file number system to ensure that the working holiday visa system is enforced—in other words, people stay in only the one employment for three months—then I think we will have a much more effective enforcement of the whole visa system.

The government made an announcement in the budget of a new category of business entry visa, and I welcome that. There was some nonsense put forward by coalition spokesmen that we were somehow introducing a new tax because we were charging people $35 under this new category of business visa. There was some ridiculous suggestion that that $35 would somehow operate as a disincentive to people to come to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it is a tax.

—Your definition of tax is very different from mine. I guess when you get on a bus you think you pay a tax because you pay some sort of administrative fee. I am afraid that your definition of tax is very different from mine. Any suggestion that a $35 fee would be a disincentive to someone coming to Australia is completely ridiculous, especially given that for a long time under the previous system the charge was $140. So you could say, if it is a tax, that we have reduced the tax.

PARA.TAB: It is of concern to me that there are continuing calls for what is called the liberalisation of the visa system. It is of particular concern to me because I represent an area where a high number of non-Australian residents are working on visas in the tourism industry. There is no doubt that the industry could not survive without Japanese tour guides. I am concerned that Australian citizens and Australian residents have an opportunity to participate in that industry. Because of the casual nature of that industry, unfortunately, constituents come to me and say that they have difficulty getting shifts as a result of the presence of people on working holiday and temporary resident visas.

For that reason, and that reason alone, we have to be very careful about calls for further liberalisation of the visa system. I concede there may be a day—when we have proper career paths in the tourism industry, when we have people trained in Japanese, Korean and Taiwanese who can take up a vast share of the available jobs in the tourism industry—when we will be able to talk about liberalisation. Until that point comes, we have to look after Australian citizens. We have to look after the next generation. In my electorate that means looking after the tourism industry.

We are encouraging young people to learn Japanese. Korean will be important in the near future. We have flights from Korea just starting to come into Cairns. That is very welcome, But the tourists will need tour guides. It is very important that we encourage people to work in the tourism industry and provide jobs for them. The only way to do that is to make sure that the integrity of the visa system is maintained and that the existing rules, which are fair rules, are enforced.

It is welcoming to see that the immigration department is doing its job and is continuing to do its job in enforcing the visa system. It is welcoming to see that money has been allocated in the budget, especially to crack down on illegals. In the public's mind, these things are confused. It sees some people working in the industry and hears talk of rorts.

The public is concerned about that. There are suspicions about people working as illegals—that is, without any visa at all. Unfortunately, the public has a feeling that nothing is being done and that local people are not getting a fair go. That is something that I, as the representative of Cairns in the far north, certainly do not want to see. That is why I am emphasising today, and have done so previously in this House, that the current integrity of that visa system must be maintained.

This bill is good legislation. It has bipartisan support. I congratulate the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) on doing an excellent job in an area which gets a lot of unwarranted criticism from humanitarian agencies and the Catholic Church. I am not saying that those people do not criticise the government without the utmost integrity but they have to realise that, in that area, the government is taking the only option.

In relation to asylum seekers, the other option the government could take would be to have an open immigration policy—a policy which would basically allow anyone to come in without any checks or balances. If the government does not take that position, there has to be a disincentive for queue jumpers. That is what the government has implemented in its policy relating to asylum seekers, and it is in compliance with Australia's international human rights obligations. As I said, Senator Bolkus and the government should be congratulated on their approach. I support the bill before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams Mr D.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1995 makes five principal changes to the migration laws in prospect. The bill seeks to amend certain detention procedures to implement recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration. It seeks to extend temporarily the migration agents registration scheme pending the outcome of an inquiry into its operation. It seeks to add flexibility to the questions which can be asked on passenger cards of visitors to Australia at their port of entry. It proposes to remove the requirement for the government to provide English language training to certain categories of visa applicants. Finally, it repeals retrospectively the Migration (Delayed Visa Applications) Tax Act 1992. It is only in relation to that last matter that I seek to raise issues today.

PARA.TAB: The problem of people living and working illegally in Australia is a significant one. These people are visitors whom Australia has welcomed and who have overstayed their visas. They are referred to by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs as unlawful non-citizens. Australia issues tourist, student and temporary resident visas to about 2,428,000 people each year. Conditions are attached to these visas, a principal one being the expectation that the people will leave Australia at the end of their authorised stay. A small percentage, less than one per cent, overstay their visa.

According to the latest figures available from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, there were an estimated 69,637 unlawful non-citizens in Australia at 30 June 1994. While most of these overstayers, some 47,800, arrived on visitor visas, a significant number of about 11,700 were students who came to Australia to study. These people were not just short-term illegals or people whose visas had only recently expired. Some 83 per cent, or about 58,000, of the unlawful non-citizens in Australia in June 1994 had been here illegally for more than a year. Some 36 per cent of the overstayers had overstayed their visas by more than five years, and 13 per cent had exceeded their visas by a period of nine years or more.

With concerns about the level of unemployment among Australians who are here lawfully, it is important that the problem of unlawful non-citizens be tackled appropriately. The Australian social security system is already carrying a significant burden. This means that it is important that any jobs which are available in Australia be filled by people who are legally in the country and who are making a contribution to the economy by way of payment of income tax.

The immigration legislation provides for the removal from Australia of people who are no longer here legally and who are taking no steps to obtain a visa. In the financial year 1993-94, 16,392 unlawful non-citizens were located. Of these, 1,438 had applied and failed to obtain asylum in Australia. In the same period there were 8,870 enforced departures made up of 825 deportations and 8,045 supervised departures. The largest single national group of unlawful non-citizens located in the relevant financial year was from the People's Republic of China.

The continuing concern about the unlawful non-citizens who work while in Australia is illustrated by a study of the illegal overstayers who were located during 1993-94. Some 31 per cent of the total number of unlawful non-citizens admitted that they had been working. They had worked in jobs as diverse as magazine editing and computer programming, as well as the more traditional areas of fruit picking, factory working and taxi driving. Of those located in the previous year, some 37.4 per cent said they had been working, while the figure for the year before that was 51.9 per cent.

Clearly, the task of identifying, locating and dealing with these unlawful non-citizens does not come without some charge, an expense that is borne by the Australian taxpayer. The cost is not a small one. The program with responsibilities for locating and dealing with unlawful non-citizens had a budget in 1993-94 of $35.5 million.

This is all by way of background to the proposal in the bill before the House today to repeal the visa tax act. The visa tax act was introduced by the then Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, the Hon. Gerry Hand, in November 1992. In the explanatory memorandum which accompanied the visa tax bill, the government stated that the visa tax act would impose a tax on an application for the grant of a visa or entry permit to a non-citizen who had been unlawfully in Australia for 12 months or more. The tax was payable by the applicant and had to be paid before the person could be granted a visa or entry permit. The amount of the tax was to be $3,000 for each completed year of unlawful status.

The visa tax act also provided for the indexation of that amount for the years after 1992-93. An unlawful non-citizen who was subsequently granted refugee status would be exempt from the tax. There was a provision in the visa tax act which empowered the immigration minister to exclude the tax where the minister determined that it would cause extreme hardship to compel payment.

In his second reading speech, the then minister explained that the visa tax act was part of a package of migration legislation reforms which would provide more effective measures to detect and remove non-citizens who are unlawfully in Australia. The then minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The tax is intended to serve as an incentive for persons to come forward at an early stage to regularise their status, rather than remaining unlawfully in Australia indefinitely.
He went on to say:
The prime objective is to deter people from remaining in Australia unlawfully rather than to raise revenue.

The provisions of the visa tax act did not come into effect until 1 September 1994 when the Migration Reform Act 1992 was implemented. It has thus been enforced for a period of less than nine months. By the provisions of the bill before the House today, the government seeks to repeal the visa tax act and to do so retrospectively. What this means is that the repealing of the visa tax act will be backdated to the date of the commencement of that act. In other words, the government wants to wipe the act from the statute books as if it had never been there at all.

PARA.TAB: All this compels me to ask the government: why repeal an act that has been enforced for only nine months? In the explanatory memorandum that was tabled with this bill, we are told that the number of people liable for the tax is minimal. But, according to the department's own figures, in June last year about 58,000 people who were unlawful non-citizens had outstayed their visas by more than a year and were therefore in the category caught by the visa tax act. I put aside for the moment the question of the way the government is using tax legislation—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 3.00 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The member for Tangney will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that the Managing Director of the Commonwealth Bank has said that variable interest rates will rise across the board because of new taxes and charges on banks introduced in the federal budget and that the banking industry estimates the increases will cost about $200 a year on a typical home loan? Given the Prime Minister's record of attacking home owners with high interest rates, why is the government now attacking home buyers with deceitful tax rises and forcing up variable interest rates even further?
—Managing directors of banks would say that, would they not?
—You own the bank; you appointed the managing director.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!

—The Leader of the Opposition knows about the massive level of profitability in the Australian banking industry. He also knows about the amount of resentment on the part of borrowers of those profitability figures. He also knows about the resentment on the part of people with savings and trading bank accounts of those charges which they have to bear.
—You have done nothing.
—I warn the member for Mitchell.

—He knows about the virtual monopoly position those four banks have in the banking system by virtue of the bank licences extended to them by the Commonwealth. We have said in this budget that there is a need to tighten fiscal policy, but, again, we have to be careful where the load falls. In this case, given the enormous shift in the profitability of banks, it is entirely appropriate that some of the load should fall on the profits of the banks. This does not need to be reflected in any change in mortgage rates. To do so would only maintain those profits at those extraordinarily high levels. To maintain those profits at those extraordinarily high levels would simply mean that the banks are taking the best from the recovery and putting very little back.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition should also be aware that a number of banks have reduced their fixed interest mortgage rates in the last two weeks—the National Australia Bank is one and Westpac is another. We have seen the bond markets reduce the long-term bond rate by around a percentage point in the last week, with a further fall yesterday.

The reason is that the financing task of the Commonwealth government will fall from $21 billion last year to $6.2 billion this year.
