There will be a turnaround of around $14.8 billion in the Commonwealth's gross borrowings—the largest single year reduction in the budget financing task on record. That is why, given that the demand for Commonwealth bonds is going to fall so sharply—a $14.8 billion reduction, from $21 billion—if there are fewer bonds around the price of the bonds will rise and therefore the interest yield will drop. That is what has happened in the last week. That is why the long-term bond yield has come down by a percentage point in the last week. That is the big indicator of interest rates in the economy. That is the purely market set indicator of interest rates.

What it also means, with those lower interest rates and the Treasury's forecast of growth over the next three years, is that it gives the complete lie to the claim of the Leader of the Opposition that there were five minutes of sunshine. We know now that there are going to be at least six years of sunshine—

TALK.START.PARA: —That really hurt you, didn't it?
—Like a lot of distortions and lies, when they are put in the wrong place they need to be put back in the right place.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition has had a rotten couple of days. First of all he got a budget back in surplus. He got the best unemployment figures today in four years. I mean, it would break his heart. When there is good news around, for him life is hardly worth living. The old Chicken Little and Henny Penny routine is about to be booed off stage. On top of that, last week he let the GST genie from the bottle. But above all that are all the mantras. There is the sage-like conservative mantra of saving: be good, be diligent, save—all that stuff—savings, the family and the deficit. Who has delivered the largest savings change in his parliamentary history? The government. Who has delivered more support and gained further support in this budget for families? The government. Who has had the biggest turnaround in the deficit in his parliamentary lifetime? The government. All the mantras he believed in, all the things he did not do, have been delivered by the government. Is it any wonder he has had a crook couple of days?

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Employment, Education and Training inform the House of the data released today on the Australian labour force? What implications does this data have for the government's Working Nation objectives?

—In a word, the figures that came out today on the labour force are fantastic news. They are fantastic by any measure that you want to put to them. Not only do they confirm that the government's policies are working but that what has been produced over the last month is another 90,000 jobs, 80,000 of them full-time. There has been a five per cent growth in employment over the last 12 months, the unemployment rate is now down to 8.3 per cent, the long-term unemployed numbers are coming down even further, the labour force is expanding, and the participation rate has gone up by 0.4 of a per cent, which shows that the supply side measures, in particular those associated with getting the long-term unemployed back into the work force, are working extremely well indeed.

PARA.TAB: What we have done in this recovery is to open up the employment growth for everyone. We said that we would not leave the long-term unemployed behind, and they are not being left behind. Across the country the news is replicated all around the place. For the first time in more than four years the unemployment rate has fallen below 10 per cent in every state, which means that South Australia and Tasmania are importantly picking up advantage in employment terms from this recovery. From the trend statistics, if one wants to say these are just another aberration, another month, on top of the past 23 months that they have been making the same call, the trend figure shows the continuing decline in the unemployment rate.

What does the opposition say about this? Every month we have seen a press release put out by the shadow minister. If we go back over the months we find that he said on 27 May last year that he looked forward to holding me `personally accountable for the contribution to the unemployment tragedy'. Well, hold me accountable. In June he said: `Government's job target looks shaky.' In July he said, `Unemployment up', in November, `Full-time employment weakens', and on 9 February this year: `Unemployment up, fewer full-time jobs in January.' On 6 April he picked up the line of the Leader of the Opposition about `the little sunlight for job seekers'.

I will tell you what: in the last two years there have been 640,000 beams of sunlight for the people who have been beneficiaries of this jobs growth. It is nonsense to talk about five minutes of economic sunlight when this government has been producing employment growth that you said could never happen and which your projections said we would never achieve.

But with all of those press releases over the past 12 months, did we get one today from the shadow minister? No, no press release. The news is too good. He cannot even bring himself to welcome that news. I guess what we will get from him—I see him anxious; I hope he gets up and asks me a question—and what we will probably hear him say will be, `This can't last.' They have been saying it for more than 12 months—`This can't last.'

The problem for them is that it is lasting; the employment growth is lasting. Our commitment to getting to five per cent unemployment and these contributions to it do demonstrate that the government's policies are working and will continue to work. The point I made yesterday in response to his question, when he asked how we could still forecast that we would get to our target, is confirmed by these figures. You might like to predict all you like and base those predictions on projections and forecasts. We will stand on the results—and the results today are truly significant.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I preface my question by reminding the Prime Minister that he has increased taxation on small businesses; he has increased their interest rates; he has been responsible for a record number of small business bankruptcies; and he and the Minister for Industrial Relations have burdened them with an arthritic industrial relations system—

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my right!
—which has been attacked even by your mate Bob Carr! I therefore ask the Prime Minister: how do you really justify your ivory tower claim made today on Brisbane radio station when you said:

QUESTION.PARA: So if they're feeling the pinch they ought to say, `Small business is not for me'—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—But it even gets better—

QUESTION.PARA: because it's never going to get any better. I mean, this is as good as it ever gets.
I ask the Prime Minister: what earthly hope has mainstream Australia really got, when its Prime Minister thinks now is as good as it is ever going to get?

TALK.START.PARA: —The context of that remark is that when the economy is growing at around five to six per cent—as it was in the last 12 months—and at two per cent inflation, that is about as good as it ever gets.
—Four per cent.
—That is right. I have been here for nearly 30 years; I cannot remember it in my time here. He has asked the question; he cannot remember it. Mr Speaker, you have got to go back.
—Look how bad it is.
—Order! The member for Berowra!

—Even back in the 1960s I do not think there was any conjunction of circumstances where we had five to six per cent growth and two per cent inflation. What needs, I think, to be understood in this country is that there are about 800,000 to 900,000 people in the small business sector. But, at the margin of that, you have people moving in and out of employment into business, single businesses or unincorporated businesses—
—Like piggeries.

—No, that is a corporate business. That flow of people in and out of those businesses takes place at a time when we have seen, at the margin of the economy, it is the most propitious time for people to make that shift.

PARA.TAB: If people think they cannot make it work in that environment, the prospect is that they are going to be going back to that part of the labour market whence they came. But for businesses where there is real potential and growth, the government has done these things for small business in the budget. Firstly, it has taken the pressure off interest rates, which matters perhaps the most. Most small businesses are not incorporated, so therefore their tax rates have not been touched.

The other thing is that the government, as members will have read, is about to negotiate another accord with the ACTU, which again guarantees wage restraint through the period. The things that matter most to small businesses are wages, interest rates and demand. These are the things which the government's budget provides: ongoing growth, sustainable low inflationary growth and, of course, a wage accord which underpins sensible outcomes.

We have also extended to the self-employed the opportunity to take the means tested, matched government contribution to superannuation. As well as that, we have extended the highly successful export access program, which is specifically targeted at small businesses, to June 1995, at a cost of $14.4 million. A lot of the growth in exports has come from the smaller business sector. Supporting that sector in export market development and access is important to it, and that is why we have extended the scheme by $14.4 million.

We have simplified visa arrangements for business travellers and migrants. We have increased expenditure on the Ausindustry extension programs by around $20 million in 1995-96, building on the Working Nation initiative.

When you look at the prospects in a growth economy, which have been there now for three years and which will be growing for another three years on Treasury's estimates, there is a great opportunity for small business. When it gets to these sorts of numbers—growth in the four to six per cent area, with low inflation—it never gets any better. I have been here for 30 years, and I have never seen it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister inform the House what the changes announced in the budget will mean for all Australians in their retirement?

—When every member of this House has left it and been replaced by somebody else, the thing in Tuesday night's budget that will be there supporting the country will be the changes to superannuation. The government has always believed that the superannuation arrangements were the best opportunity we had to give working Australians a higher standard of living in retirement.

PARA.TAB: The other important feature of this is that the demographics of the country are changing—as you would know, Mr Speaker. When the baby boom generation—which you and I belong to—reaches retirement age, there will be half as many again retired people as there are today. About five or eight years after that, there will be nearly twice as many people of retirement age as there are today.

This will put inordinate weight on fiscal policy and the pension scheme as it exists today. Pensioners who are interested in keeping the 25 per cent of average weekly earnings standard achieved under Labor will find a lot of pressure against that without private provision and complementation to the pension.

The government understood that 10 years ago. With the ACTU, we put together the first superannuation arrangements—the three per cent scheme—in 1985-86. We built that to five per cent and then, to get the compliance up, in 1991 the government introduced the superannuation guarantee charge, which will take the level of employer contributions to nine per cent by the year 2002.

In One Nation, we said that we would try to introduce employee contributions along the way to advance the scheme further. In Tuesday night's budget, the Treasurer announced that. He also announced that the government would match the contribution by funding more than the One Nation tax cuts into employees' superannuation accounts.

The consequence of that will be that the nine per cent that we provided under the superannuation guarantee charge will rise to 15 per cent—a mature contribution for the whole nation. It will mean that a couple in their 30s today will find that they will retire on a sum that is three-quarters more than the current pension and their children will retire on a sum that is twice the current pension.

Let me give you the figures this way. A person on average weekly earnings, a person on $33,000 a year today, who was in the scheme to maturity—that is, for over 40 years—would retire with an annuity of $30,000 a year.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is that going to buy?

—It buys what $30,000 a year buys today. These figures do not reflect inflation but are in the dollars of today, in 1995 dollars. That annuity comes from a lump sum of $461,000. In other words, someone on $33,000 a year would build for themselves $461,000. The lump sum of someone on twice average weekly earnings—that is, around $60,000 today—would be $750,000 and their real average retirement income per year under an annuity would be $42,000 a year.

PARA.TAB: Not only will we see this enormous improvement in retirement incomes but we will also see an enormous improvement in national savings. When the government first introduced superannuation there was only 40 per cent coverage of employees. The Leader of the Opposition is always running around saying, `People have got to save.' He was the Treasurer for five years. How come he left me as Treasurer, the government and the member for Gellibrand as Treasurer a system which covered only 40 per cent of employees? Under Labor that system now covers 90 per cent of employees.

The figures on the rise for women are even more dramatic than those figures because women were previously disenfranchised from the system. They got their money, they left when they had a child and that was the end of it. Now they can preserve it to age 55 and they can build these sorts of sums for themselves in their own name, in their own right.

That change is a revolutionary change to savings. The $40 billion that existed in super funds in 1983 is $186 billion today and the Treasury is forecasting it to be $2,000 billion by the year 2020. That is $2 trillion, $2,000 billion—about 30 times our current national debt. I think that puts the weight into perspective.

The Treasury estimates that additional savings from Labor's superannuation policy will be four per cent of GDP. Everybody in the House, I think, accepts that the current account problem is of the order of two percentage points of GDP. It has been from the middle to late 1980s onwards. There is a four percentage point to GDP change in superannuation alone and a four percentage point to GDP change from the shift in budget policy.

That change will occur somewhere over the next 20-odd years. If we just take the change from now to the end of the century, we are probably talking about somewhere between three per cent and four per cent in the next five or six years—a three to four percentage point change in savings to meet a two percentage point problem on the current account. That is why the budget met the medium-term prospects.

This would only have happened, this superannuation scheme, from a Labor government. We are the only people who could build a relationship with the work force and get them to agree to put some of their income away as savings and then fund the One Nation tax cuts, and more, into their employee superannuation accounts. It is like every other great thing—whether it is floating the dollar, whether it is removing exchange controls, whether it is knocking the tariff barrier down, whether it is changing the micro economy or lifting or developing a comprehensive national private savings plan for Australia—it is always Labor, only ever the Labor Party.

Tonight the Leader of the Opposition has a budget reply. Tonight we can hear from the Leader of the Opposition how he would change Australia, how he would change public policy. He has already told us that he will not touch revenue. The shadow Treasurer has told us that they will not adjust revenue. Therefore, the brunt of the whole of his fiscal changes will be borne by cuts in government spending. He should say what he believes the order of those cuts should be. He should tell us how he intends to deal with the current account deficit. He should tell us how he wants to extend opportunity with education and participation in tertiary education and TAFE.

Now, at 7.30 tonight, is the Leader of the Opposition's big moment to tell us where he stands or to tell us rather that it is really only a cacophony of catcalls and distortions, that it is only a cacophony of exaggeration and claims, that he is not only the same person he was in the 1980s but also policy tired and without policy fizz. I am quite happy to conclude the answer by repeating what I said when I started: when all of us have gone, this change will live on to give Australia what it has never had under 23 years of coalition governments—a comprehensive private saving scheme to lift retirement incomes and to dramatically boost national savings.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Given that, as Professor Bob Gregory's research confirms, many longstanding ALP voting manufacturing belts continue to be excluded from the employment and economic gains your government is crowing about today, will you guarantee the redirection of the $1.2 billion savings from the Working Nation program, which is less than a third of the money you have stolen from the people via the Commonwealth Bank, to local governments in the hardest hit regions in Australia to create jobs in community services and capital works? Furthermore, will you also ensure the $24 million of `better cities' money is set aside to upgrade the Upfield railway line in Melbourne's depressed north and that the remainder of the funds is handed over to these local communities to ensure that they receive their fair share of Australia's wealth?

—The fact is, as the Minister for Employment, Education and Training has already announced today, the nation is enjoying tremendous growth in employment. With 90,000 in the last month we have seen a five per cent growth in the last 12 months.
—They have never had it so good, Phil.
—It never gets any better, Phil.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting!

—I think all sections of Australia are benefiting from that, including the west and north-western parts of Melbourne which include the honourable member's electorate and my own. Those electorates are also areas which have above average levels of unemployment and it is certainly important that we address that issue and try to do what we can within available resources to ensure they get a proportionately high level of the funds which are available to address the unemployment issue through labour market programs in those areas. That is what happens.

PARA.TAB: We do direct our funds in terms of categories of people, such as long-term unemployed or youth or non-English speaking persons. We direct our funds particularly to assist groups who are most likely to find it difficult to get back into employment. We also do it on an area basis, so that there are substantial funds, above average funds, for the number of people in an area put into the areas of highest unemployment. In this financial year 1994-95, some $118 million of labour market programs are being spent in the north-western region of Melbourne. That is proportionately a high level of expenditure, and so it ought to be.

That will be higher next year because there are more funds coming into labour market programs, despite the so-called cutbacks in the budget. They were cutbacks off the forward estimates which were well up on the expenditure in 1994-95. So we are looking at increased expenditure on labour market programs, on job subsidies to get people directly into jobs and on training allowances to assist people to qualify for employment. Those expenditures will be considerably higher in 1995-96 than they were in 1994-95 under the Working Nation program that has been adopted by the government last year.

We are very concerned to continue to bring about a decline in the unemployment levels, particularly of long-term unemployed people. It has been a matter of some satisfaction in the last 12 months that those numbers have come down by some 80,000-odd, or about 25 per cent. That is a very considerable reduction in a short period of time. With the latest addition, it is probably an even larger decline; with the latest 90,000 figure announced today in increased employment.

Therefore, we are seeing very much of the sort of thing that the member was talking about in terms of direction of resources to the areas of greatest need. We are not going to be doing the sorts of things that he was particularly asking for. In a sense, he was asking for a rewriting of the budget. He knows what is in the budget, and some of the measures he is suggesting are not there. But what is there is a greatly enhanced effort on the labour market programs, building on the increases in 1994-95, with further increases in 1995-96 to make further inroads into the long-term unemployment area and also into the areas of highest unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer elaborate on part of the Prime Minister's answer to the first question and advise the House what impact the budget will have on the government's financing task in 1995-96?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to do so. As the Prime Minister mentioned earlier in question time, it is the case that the Commonwealth's borrowing program will be considerably reduced this financial year, 1995-96, by the fact of the budget turnaround as announced by me on Tuesday night. What we have seen is a $12.9 billion turnaround, from a deficit of $12.2 billion to a surplus of $700 million. That turnaround means that there is, accordingly, much less need for the government to go to the markets to borrow. It means that the government's financing task in association with repayment of maturing debt—instead of seeking some $21 billion, which was the borrowing task this year—in 1995-96 will be just over $6 billion. So it is a major reduction.

PARA.TAB: The overwhelming part of that reduction of some $15 billion comes from the turnaround in the budget as presented to this parliament; that is, going from a deficit of $12.2 billion to a surplus of $700 million—almost a $13 billion turnaround. That demonstrates the importance of delivering the budget in the way in which it is delivered and has traditionally been delivered. The way in which the budget is set out has a direct significance for the financing task of the Commonwealth, and that reduction in the financing task is itself very significant.

As the Prime Minister alluded to, what it means is that, with a lesser amount of borrowing, we have the likelihood of a higher price for government paper, which means the yields on them will be less and therefore there is reduced pressure on interest rates, because the bond rates will be less than they would otherwise have been with a higher financing task. That is a very important factor. That is the way in which the reduction in the budget deficit and turning it into a surplus turns into reduced pressure on interest rates. That is the way it happens, in association with the fact that the fiscal tightening in the budget reduces the inflationary pressures in the economy. This also bolsters the confidence of investors about inflation in the future. It means that they are less likely to be looking for higher interest rates.

The change in the government's borrowing task is of great significance. The presentation of the budget—in the way it was presented to this parliament; as it has always been—has that direct significance in terms of demonstrating the change in the financing task and the impact on the markets in terms of pressure on interest rates. It is important for the House to understand that.

It also means that we are looking forward to reductions in Commonwealth debt. We are seeing that the Commonwealth net debt, which in 1994-95 is about 19.1 per cent of GDP, will reduce over the forward estimates period to 13.7 per cent of GDP. There will be about a 5 1/2 per cent decline over that period. We are looking forward to reduced pressure on interest rates and substantial declines in government debt. Those, of course, are important and satisfactory outcomes for the nation.

It is also of interest to note that the importance of that is recognised by influential people. We had a demonstration of that this morning by a representative of Moody's, the international ratings agency, who on the AM program had some comments to make about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Speaker: on 9 May last year, just over a year ago, you issued an admonition to all ministers with regard to the length of their replies to questions and pointed out that your carriage of the control of the House required a quid pro quo from ministers with their answers. This is a comprehensive question from the member for Corio, yes, but the answer is now going on to an extended length. I invite you to ask the minister to draw his answer to a close.

—You were right, inasmuch as it was a comprehensive question asked by the member for Corio. The Treasurer has been entirely relevant in his response. As I have also remarked previously, economic ministers, as are others on the other side, in this place are given some discretion.

—I did not think I had been going that long. I think that all that I have said is very relevant to the question, and very relevant to this House and to the nation. I just conclude my answer by referring to the comments made by Mr Truglia from Moody's on AM this morning. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . we are just interested in seeing the overall level of borrowing go down . . .
From our point of view, going to surplus is a good idea no matter how it is achieved. So I think this is an appropriate policy to take under present circumstances.
Quite clearly, from the point of view of Moody's, the fact that we have moved into surplus and that we are reducing the borrowing task is a very important development. He was then asked:
How much of a concern is that current account deficit?
His answer—which I think is quite interesting—was:

Our expectation is, and is proving true, that the Government would not allow such a large current account deficit to be maintained in the medium-term and therefore the Government is making sure that fiscal policy tries to deal with it . . . the best way to try to deal with a current account deficit is to try and reduce the Government deficit. As a result, I don't know what else you could ask the Government to do to try to deal with a current account deficit, the size of which no one had, as far as I know, really predicted a year or so ago.

That I would say is a clear endorsement by Moody's of the budget, of the government's fiscal policy, of the fact that the borrowing task is being greatly reduced and of the fact that this has considerable relevance to addressing the current account deficit.

—Let me get down to the part of the budget which the opposition decided to mutter at: the simplification of family payments to make it easier for families to get assistance and to improve support for family members caring for sick and elderly relatives. PARA.TAB: Such support includes a universal access to health care through Medicare, more than a fivefold increase in the number of child-care places from 46,000 to 253,000, a significant real increase in family payments of over 75 per cent for low income families, a new parenting allowance for parents who stay at home to care for their children—which means that nearly 120,000 families will gain $59 a week—and the introduction of the child-care cash rebate to help parents meet the cost of child care. All of those policies—Medicare, the child-care places, the real increase of over 75 per cent in family payments for low income families, the new parenting allowance, and the child-care cash rebate—are concrete policies to support families.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training and concerns commitments made at various times by the Prime Minister and him to boost higher education opportunities in Queensland. Can the minister inform the House what measures were included in the budget to meet those commitments?

PARA.TAB: Mr Howard interjecting—
Mr Keating interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition and the Prime Minister should conduct their debate later.

—I thank the honourable member for her question because she, together with the member for Moreton and indeed all Queensland members, has been actively lobbying the government to ensure that Queensland gets its fair share of university places. I might say that the budget was very good news for the higher education sector. What this budget has done is build on the commitment of this government over the past 12 years to significantly expand the higher education sector.

PARA.TAB: In the time prior to this budget, the commitments that this government has made have seen university places increased by 70 per cent. This is a massive commitment to ensuring quality in the higher education sector and giving our young people real opportunities to get into universities. This budget continues to build on that investment. In the next three years the budget has committed to provide 5,850 new university places—the great bulk of those are going to Queensland. In fact, 4,200 of them go to Queensland on top of the 500 that we gave at the end of last year.

I was asked a question on a previous occasion in this House as to whether we could guarantee the continuation of the 500 places. Not only are we guaranteeing that; we have multiplied it in a huge way to ensure that Queensland gets its fair share. Queensland is not the only beneficiary because other members in the House who live in growth areas in New South Wales and Western Australia also have the same problem. The budget makes an allocation of places to those states to pick up on the growth in those places.

All of these places have been delivered without taking any away from the other states. There was indignation about this on the other side of the House. The South Australians and Victorians came in and said, `If you are doing it for Queensland, don't take them off us.' The reality is that we have delivered the places without taking any existing places away. I suggest to the House that this is a very significant commitment.

It is not only university places that we are funding. We recognise that if we are going to put more people into universities they need the facilities to be taught in and to be housed in. So there is also money for infrastructure to support these places.

We go further. We have recognised the need to build the research base further within the universities. Research infrastructure funding in this budget goes up 57 per cent over the next three years. We have increased the number of research places. We have done this without any cuts to the higher education sector, with no up-front fees for undergraduate students and with no increase in the HECS debt.

This is another example of: while we are doing it, what is the opposition saying. I will be very interested tonight to see whether the Leader of the Opposition actually tells us what his commitment is to the higher education sector. He is telling us that we have to cut spending. Is the opposition going to cut it in the higher education sector?
Let us hear the policy from the other side. The return to vouchers, the return to fees, the smashing of student unions—that is your policy in higher education.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's a lie.

—Let us hear what your policy is, if you say it is a lie. This government has delivered significantly again to the higher education sector. Little wonder that the AVCC, the national teachers tertiary education industry union, the National Union of Students—all of them, the academics, the vice chancellors, the National Union of Students—have all applauded this budget. They will not be applauding you for your hollow rhetoric of support for higher education. The only way you would do it would be to charge students fees to get it.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. —Echos from the Brisbane stock exchange. He knows and I know what some of those echos are. All this stuff about little stock market tips and the rest—let me just say this. Yesterday we had this completely beat up issue on the part of the opposition as a diversion from the real debate, which it is unable to handle, about the question of whether the Commonwealth government would be able to sell its shares without all of the stockholders in the Commonwealth Bank agreeing. It was a complete furphy, completely and utterly untrue, a complete ruse, a sham, a diversion, completely and utterly irrelevant. But opposition members did their best on that for about 10 or 12 hours and there was always either the gullible or the partisan who took up their cause.
—Is that what Lyneham is?

—No. Well, on this occasion he was a little gullible. I asked him whether he had got it down at Aussie's cafe, and he probably did. He probably got it from one of you lot down there, and it didn't do him any good and it didn't do you any good. The government will need the shareholders' support, when a proposal is put to them, to buy back.
—We were right.

—No, no, for the buy-back proposal—not the selling, the buy-back. The buy-back is not at all central to the disposal of the bank by the government; it is just a modality in the sale. Maybe it is a few years ago since anyone used the word `modality'. Get the dictionary out and find out what it means. I know that these days over there with a diminishing vocabulary you will wonder what it means. It will be open to all shareholders—there is a little tip from the stock exchange—to make a judgment about the Commonwealth's offer, but of course any offer we would make would come after a scoping study conducted by my colleague the Minister for Finance and his department. Therefore, to arrive at any price at which the bank may offer to buy back shares into Treasury and cancel them would be the subject of a scoping study. Therefore, all the shareholders will have their full say.
—And all this is going to happen before the end of the year.

—No, all the shareholders will have their full say. But the key point is that the government will be putting the bank, in two tranches, onto the market at a time which suits the floating of that stock. I hope members of the press gallery have taken note of the fact that that little ruse, that scam, the opposition had running yesterday about the Commonwealth Bank was completely without foundation. I know that most of the wise ones know not to believe a word you say; they will be doubly careful after yesterday's little number.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Minister for Industrial Relations. Minister, I preface this question by acknowledging, with pleasure, the recent announcements regarding accelerated and expanded development at Sydney West airport. Minister, my question is: are you aware of the many current concerns about the effects of aircraft noise from Kingsford Smith airport and the lack of community consultation mechanism? What do you intend to do to address the need for more community consultation on issues such as aircraft that stray from official flight paths, and monitoring of noise levels in affected suburbs, as well as health and safety issues arising from aircraft movements?

—I will deal with this as briefly as I can. However, I should draw the House's attention to the announcement on 8 December last year of a comprehensive package of measures to address the severe impact of aircraft noise on the communities surrounding Kingsford Smith airport. As the House will recall, that package included restricted flight paths; heavy penalties for breaches of these flight paths; a comprehensive noise insulation program, which will now cost $260 million; and a requirement to minimise northerly take-offs and the impact of those take-offs.I can now report that all of these noise abatement measures are in place or are in the process of being implemented.

PARA.TAB: The government on that occasion also foreshadowed the establishment of a broadly based community consultative committee—a committee which would provide the opportunity for the noise affected residents to monitor the airport's operations as well as progress with the noise abatement measures. In line with that commitment, I can inform the House and the honourable member today that the former Sydney airport environment committee will be totally reconstituted to provide wide community representation. The changes will address community concerns about the deficiencies of the old committee and have been formulated after consultation with many of the concerned groups.

On the basis of community input, the new consultative committee will include an independent chairman; seven community representatives, nominated by federal MPs in electorates affected by the airport operations; nine community representatives nominated by state MPs from similarly affected electorates; 14 local government council representatives; the Civil Aviation Authority; the Federal Airports Corporation; the Commonwealth Department of Transport; the New South Wales Department of Planning; the New South Wales Environmental Protection Agency; and three aviation industry representatives.

It is proposed that the new committee will look at airport matters including reports on the noise and health impacts of the airport's operations, the radar tracks of each day's flights to and from the airport, possible breaches of the flight path corridors, the adequacy of the flight path and noise monitoring arrangements, the enforcement of the airport curfew and progress with the insulation and acquisition program. The committee will also afford community representatives the opportunity to question relative authorities about all of the operations of the airport.

In view of the number of affected groups and interested parties, the committee is necessarily large and broadly based. For this reason, it is proposed that a smaller 13-person group, appointed by the larger committee, will meet regularly to receive and distribute reports on all aspects of the airport's operations. The process will be supported by a secretariat within the Commonwealth Department of Transport. The new committee will be required to publish an annual report on its operations for tabling here in the parliament.

Having established the framework, it is now our intention to have the new committee up and running as soon as possible. In this regard, I am pleased to advise the House today that the Hon. Joe Riordan, the newly appointed Chairman of Worksafe Australia, has generously accepted the government's invitation to serve as Chairman of the Sydney Airport Consultative Committee. I might say that, as chairman, Mr Riordan will bring to this position his long history of distinguished service in Australian public life, as both a federal government minister and a very distinguished senior deputy president of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

I conclude by saying that the new consultative committee will afford those communities bearing the burden of aircraft noise the opportunity to closely monitor the airport's operations and a regular opportunity to question those responsible for the operations. I know that all members representing the surrounding electorates—especially the member for Lowe, who has persistently called for the establishment of such a broadly based committee—will welcome its establishment.

They have, in terms of this budget, received an enormous boost to their retirement incomes through the superannuation changes which have been talked about in detail by the Prime Minister earlier today. They demonstrate that, by channelling the second round of the One Nation tax cuts into superannuation funds through matching contributions by the government, in a way which is means tested and capped so as to give maximum benefit to people on lower incomes, the equity—

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order under standing order 145: this was a specific question which was seeking information of the minister about a number of specific things—whether or not a distributional analysis has been conducted; whether it was conducted through the Prismod computer package held by the Treasury; and, if so, whether this crucial information would be released to the parliament. Nothing could be more specific than that, and the Treasurer has made no attempt to answer these questions seeking information from him.
—Order! You have made your point of order. I call the Leader of the House on a point of order.

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: I think there seems to be a misunderstanding on the part of the opposition. —I find that both contributions on this matter are quite appropriate. The honourable member for Menzies raised some issues that the Treasurer might address. The Leader of the House indicated that, when there is a broad preamble, it invites the minister to respond. I know that the Treasurer will.

—The importance of the point I was making is that it obviously means a very substantial improvement in the retirement incomes of lower income people. That improvement is spelt out in detail in the paper `Saving for our future'. I recommend that members opposite have a good look at what is spelt out there and see the tremendous increase in retirement incomes coming for ordinary wage earners in this country through the redirection of the second leg of the One Nation tax cuts into superannuation funds in a way which improves the equity of the superannuation system and, obviously, improves the equity of income distribution in this country.

PARA.TAB: We have not done a model which puts that all in together with the budget measures in respect of everything else, but certainly we can see in that retirement incomes measure tremendous improvement in equity. In respect of other measures, of course there are things which improve very much the position of people on lower incomes, that is, some of the welfare changes as well as some of the tax increases which have been referred to in the question.

There are measures that go both ways, but we have not done a Prismod analysis of that. We have done a major analysis of what it means in respect of the most revolutionary change in retirement income policy in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport. The minister would be aware of the importance of the general aviation industry to rural and remote Australia. Is the minister aware of claims by the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association that the funding arrangements for the new Civil Aviation Safety Authority represent a 60 per cent increase in the avgas excise for general aviation? Is the claim by that association that the general aviation sector is cross-subsidising the major airlines in providing for air safety correct?

—I am aware of the campaign by the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association and, indeed, its new president, the former chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority, Dick Smith. Members on both sides of the House have been inundated in the last couple of days with calls from pilots around the countryside fearful of a 60 per cent increase in aviation duty.

PARA.TAB: At the outset I say that, like everyone in the House, I have a great deal of respect for Dick Smith. He is, after all, one of Australia's leading philanthropists. In his time he has made a great deal of money and he has given away a very large amount of it to Australia's charitable causes. He is at his best when he is being philanthropic. He is at his worst when he is creating fear amongst the members of his association. I have received a forest worth of paper in the last week. I have here individual letters from pilots around the countryside, all as part of this campaign.

I think it is appropriate that I should put the facts before the House. There is no 60 per cent increase in duty on avgas. The present charge for avgas is 17.23c per litre. With the 0.9c per litre increase contained in this week's budget, it will go to 18.1c per litre. That is a fully hypothecated charge. Every penny of that goes to the aviation industry. Of that, 15.7c per litre goes to air services and 1.5c per litre goes to air safety regulation. The 0.9c per litre increase is for aviation regulation and it represents in total a five per cent increase, not a 60 per cent increase.

I also point out to the House that this charge is very low in historic terms. When Dick Smith became chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority in February 1990, the charge was not 18.1c per litre; it was 25.648c per litre. Two years later when he left that post it was at its highest level ever—27.48c per litre. It is now, with this 0.9c increase, down to 18.1c per litre.

It is worth pointing out in answer to the honourable member that the general aviation area pays only a tiny proportion of total air services charges. Indeed, last year 97 per cent of all of the money raised in these charges, $467.1 million, was raised from international and domestic RPT operators. Only $15.4 million, that is three per cent, of the total expenditure, or $482 million, was raised from the general aviation area through the avgas levy. That is a very reasonable impost given that the last report of the directorate of air safety regulation said that 27 per cent of all its time and attention, of all its resources, was used up investigating private and sporting planes in the general aviation area. So the general aviation area funds only a tiny proportion of the total attention that it receives.

I will not be answering each one of these letters individually because that would be a great waste of time and money, but I do think this House should be aware that it is a five per cent increase, not a 60 per cent increase. It is entirely reasonable to fund the strict safety controls we are implementing as a result of the parliamentary inquiry chaired by the member for Shortland and as a result of the royal commission being undertaken by Justice Staunton.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BILNEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—All of us hoped that the end of the Cold War would lead to a new world order of peace and prosperity. Unfortunately that has not come to pass. In particular, the number, the severity and the complexity of humanitarian crises have dramatically increased in recent years.

PARA.TAB: The Australian government, and Australians generally, through Australian non-government organisations, have responded generously and compassionately to these crises. Among others, CARE Australia has played a prominent humanitarian role in some of the world's most desperate trouble spots.

It is obviously essential, and it is the expectation of those who entrust funds to those humanitarian agencies, that the funds allocated to alleviate human suffering in these dire circumstances are used effectively and efficiently. There have, however, been some allegations made about CARE's account-ability for its use of such funds. I therefore initiated an audit of CARE Australia's financial systems in November 1994.

This audit follows up the findings and recommendations of an earlier audit conducted by the NSW Audit Office, which itself recommended that such a follow-up audit be conducted. I expanded the terms of reference of this follow-up audit when Mr Bernard Broughton, a former employee of CARE Australia, reiterated the serious allegations he had made about CARE Australia previously and offered to make documentary evidence available to the auditors, as he had not done when the previous audit had been carried out.

It is against this background that today I propose to table the audit report of CARE Australia prepared by the independent accounting firm BDO Nelson Parkhill. A number of findings contained in the report give rise to concern. Most of the more serious findings of the audit relate to projects undertaken prior to 1991, when CARE was still in its infancy and struggling to develop administrative systems to back up its rapidly expanding work in the field. The report finds that CARE now has an effective control structure in place but still needs to improve certain management practices. CARE has recently commissioned a management efficiency review which I hope will further improve its management. The most serious audit findings concern:

SPEECH.PARA: the acquittal of funding for a 1988-89 Mozambique food aid project, which was overstated by $208,703—I am pleased to advise that CARE has now returned the outstanding funds to the Commonwealth; and the budget presented to Ausaid for the `Health CARE for the Khartoum displaced in Sudan project', which was at variance with the information provided to CARE's counterpart agency in Sudan. The auditors recommend that at least $30,000 should be refunded.
The auditors also found:
that budgets presented by CARE Australia to Ausaid, on occasions, have been overstated;
that moneys raised from the Australian public have, on occasions, not been applied to projects in accordance with the stated objectives of the fundraising campaigns concerned; and
that certain management, contracting and monitoring arrangements—which I will not list now since they are spelled out in the report—need improvement.

PARA.TAB: The Australian government takes the matters raised in the audit very seriously. Such practices are totally unacceptable to the government and I am determined to ensure that systems and practices are put in place to ensure that they do not happen again. In particular, the audit report recommends legal advice be sought in relation to the two most serious findings referred to above, namely, the acquittal of the 1988-89 Mozambique project and the overstated budget for the 1989-90 Sudan project. In accordance with the auditors' advice, I have sought urgent legal advice on those two matters.

Yesterday I received from CARE a response to all of the other recommendations of the audit report. I acknowledge this, and CARE's assurance that it has addressed all the material matters affecting its relationship with the government. In accordance with normal practice, there will be a follow-up audit of CARE Australia in six months time to ensure that appropriate action has been taken on the audit's recommendations.

A number of recommendations in the audit relate to accountability issues associated with publicly raised funds. As members may be aware, this issue is of particular concern to me. I have written twice to Mr Bill Scales, Chairman of the Industry Commission inquiry into charitable organisations in Australia, urging the inquiry to make concrete recommendations on public accountability issues.

Members may also be aware that, in support of the work of the inquiry, I have set up a working group to make recommendations on a voluntary code of practice for the guidance of all non-government organisations which provide overseas development assistance. The development of this code of practice is being fully supported by the non-government organisations. Such a code will ensure that the public can with confidence determine objectively what happens to the funds they donate to non-government organisations. In this way, the code of practice will clearly address concerns expressed in this audit report regarding public accountability.

I need to point out that it has not been possible for the auditors to examine all the allegations made about CARE Australia on 26 February on the Channel 9 Sunday program. For one thing, access to the Nine Network's files on CARE was denied as a result of legal constraints arising from CARE's defamation proceedings in the ACT Supreme Court. For another, many of the Sunday program allegations were subjective or related to the effectiveness of work performed in the field, or to the use of funds from other agencies, such as UNHCR. As such, they fell outside not only the audit terms of reference, but also the power of the Commonwealth to investigate effectively. Naturally, should any further allegations be made concerning the misuse of Commonwealth funds, they also will be fully investigated.

It is an ill wind which blows nobody any good. I hope that this audit has set the foundations for a renewed confidence in the management of CARE and a constructive relationship between it and Ausaid. It is my earnest hope that this report, and the follow-up actions I have instigated, will finally settle this matter. Importantly for that outcome, it is now up to CARE Australia to satisfy its supporters and the Australian public that its operations are in order.

I conclude by emphasising my conviction that the Australian public should feel very proud of the work undertaken by Australian non-government organisations overseas. These organisations, and the Australians who voluntarily serve them, work in some of the most dangerous and difficult areas of the world. They do fine work saving thousands of lives and assisting poor people towards a more decent existence.

It would be a tragedy if publicity surrounding this report undermined public confidence in our overseas aid organisations; it should not. There is absolutely no reason for the public to doubt the dedication of their people or the excellence of their work—which, as Tuesday's budget showed, continues to be supported by Australia's aid agency, Ausaid, to the tune of well over $100 million. I present the following papers:
Follow-up audit of CARE Australia—Report to Ausaid and ministerial statement, 11 May 1995.
Motion (by Mr Bilney)—by leave—agreed to:
That this House authorises the publication of the report to Ausaid on the follow-up audit of CARE Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I note the report to Ausaid on the follow-up audit of CARE Australia that the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney) has tabled today. I thank the minister for the advance copy of it, which I think we received yesterday. The coalition has had the opportunity to read through the report in quite some detail.

PARA.TAB: I must say right from the outset that it is perfectly clear that CARE Australia is an honourable organisation. It is perfectly clear that it is not an organisation which has been acting in a way which is deliberately corrupt or anything like that. In that context, some of the publicity that this whole exercise has received has been a little unfortunate, because it has the potential to undermine public confidence not only in CARE as an organisation but also in other non-government aid organisations. That is something that we on this side of the House would not want—and surely the government would not want—to see happen.

As the minister said, it is also very true that there is a large number of extremely dedicated people who work for CARE Australia. Many of those people work in extremely harsh conditions with what could only be described as great courage. Some of the work that CARE Australia does for Australian non-government organisations is unique, and that has to be well understood.

It is quite clear that the report of the auditor in general finds CARE Australia to have an effective control structure in place, but I note that it does still need to improve certain management practices. The specific examples of the Mozambique and Sudan projects are a matter of real concern. I note that action has already been taken to remedy one of those concerns and it is being taken to remedy the second concern in Sudan. I also note that the minister has sought legal advice on those particular cases. We can only wait and see what that advice is.

There has been, however, considerable administrative reform within CARE Australia over the last few years. It has to be remembered that most of the complaints raised in relation to CARE occurred before 1991—some time ago. These were administrative problems in an organisation which was growing very fast and was in its infancy. Clearly, much of the administrative shortcomings that existed then have been rectified. There have been no instances of double dipping found by the auditors, such as CARE being paid twice by different bodies for the same project. It is important to note that there has been a positive response by CARE to the report, acknowledging the need to revise certain administrative practices.

In terms of actual aid delivery, CARE still performs a very good job in the field with committed workers and efficient use of aid donations made by the Australian public. I note on page 74 of the auditor's report something which is of particular importance: the auditors have examined CARE's figures since its inception in November 1987, which indicate that an average of 88 per cent of total income, less fundraising costs, is expended on the delivery of aid related services. Of the selected sample taken by BDO, the average for all similar Australian organisations was 89 per cent. If you take CARE as at 30 June 1994, then the figure was a very high 96 per cent. I understand that the auditor's figure is higher than CARE's own estimate of, if you like, the efficiency of its organisation. In that sense, it is an organisation which is now performing very well.

I certainly support what the minister has said on the voluntary code of practice. I look forward to the negotiations on that code of practice coming to a successful conclusion. As I said at the beginning, a lot of the publicity CARE has received is, I suspect, more associated with some of the personalities involved in the organisation than necessarily a reflection on the organisation's overall levels of efficiency. Yes, there have been problems. These are not, in my view, enormously serious problems, but they are problems that need to be rectified and they are being rectified. The sooner we can rebuild national confidence in CARE Australia and, therefore, in other non-government aid organisations, the better.
