Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

The lack of integrity underpinning the 1995 Budget; the lack of transparency in the presentation of the Budget; and the regressive impact that the taxation measures in the Budget will have on Australian families.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have in my hand a particularly pertinent document with regard to the nation's consideration of the 1995 budget. It is an extract from AAP's reports of this day and carries the dateline `QLD: KEATING SAYS THIS IS AS GOOD AS IT GETS FOR BUSINESS—BUDGET 95—KEATING LEAD—BRISBANE, May 11 AAP'. I think it is so important a document in the consideration of the budget that I should, as I propose this matter of public importance, read into the record the rest of this brief but incredibly accurate AAP report that reveals so much about the arrogance of our part-time Prime Minister (Mr Keating), full-time emperor. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Struggling small business owners should sell out if they can't make a go of the highest growth economy Australia has ever had, Prime Minister Paul Keating said today.

PARA.TAB: "This is as good as it ever gets," he said, when asked about concerns about the effect of corporate tax increases on small businesses feeling the pinch.
"If they're feeling the pinch, they're feeling it in the highest growth economy we've ever had," Mr Keating told ABC Radio here today.
"We're been growing at five to six per cent with two per cent inflation so if they're feeling the pinch they ought to say, `small business is not for me'.
"Because it's never going to get any better. This is as good as it ever gets.
"So if they're feeling the pinch, they'd better say, `well, I think, I'd better go back to PAYE (pay as you earn) employment'."

SPEECH.PARA: That was this country's Prime Minister just two days after the budget. That is why the people of Australia will say that they have had absolutely enough of this Prime Minister and this budget when they get an opportunity. They will dispatch him to a new job—if he is able to find one, be it in Paris, Berlin or elsewhere—upon the result of the next election.

PARA.TAB: I am happy enough to concede that the making of a budget is a complex and lengthy process and it does involve some constraints. It involves constraints on who can know what at various stages of the budget process. The most notable example of that this time was in respect of the decision on the privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank. The Prime Minister does not seem to know much of the detail of that. Yesterday we exposed that that was the case for the Treasurer (Mr Willis), but we exposed it today with respect to the Prime Minister.

There is another good reason why the government did not feel disposed to bring into the consultations a great deal of the cabinet—the inner ministry—the outer ministry or the caucus. If in fact it had, it would have had a meltdown from that same cabinet, outer ministry and caucus, because as we get into the detail of the budget we see what this budget really does. It is with a great deal of regret that I record that this budget extinguishes for all time Labor's light on the hill with regard to social justice, fairness and equity. It introduces a series of regressive tax increases that will increase the gap between rich and poor, as borne out by ABS studies and its findings and more comprehensive studies.

I am pleased to wear today the Smith Family `special pass' in the build-up to its special appeal—the Smith Family Day—to be held on 15 May 1995. The member for Riverina (Mr Hicks) has contributed to that, as has his good friend Pro Hart. Go out and ask the Smith Family whether it thinks the gap between rich and poor has got less under Labor. In fact, you do not have to—just turn straight to the ABS studies, which show that that gap has got bigger.

You would think that the government might feel a little sheepish about this or at least would want to know what the distributional effects of its budget would be. But no. It is not even game enough to use its own computer in Treasury, its own Prismod model and computer package, to ascertain what the total holistic distributional effects of this budget are.

It is all very well for the Treasurer to say that only certain categories of retired people are affected. The government has, in fact, stolen one of our longstanding policies with regard to the abolition of unrealised capital gains tax. The effect is the same: there is a reduction of pension for a pensioner who holds shares and they go up in value. That has gone into the budget. That is one of the coalition's policies that the government has stolen.

It is all very well for the government to point out that there are certain niche categories that will have some benefit, but what it runs a million miles from is declaring to the House that the sales tax increases in this budget are regressive, are going to affect families, are going to affect poor families, are going to affect those families lucky enough to be in a position to attempt to remodel their kitchens or whatever and, more particularly, are going to affect young people.

One of the first purchases young people will make in stepping out in life, having completed their primary and secondary educations, is a motor car. It may be second hand; it may be a motor bike; or, ultimately, it may be a very small first-hand motor car. Many of them have no choice but to attempt to do that as they seek to get to their place of employment beyond the public transport system; as they seek to get to additional tertiary education and tech college courses and the like. They will now find their situation belted by the huge sales tax raft on new cars, which, I am sure the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence (Mr Bevis), who is at the table, will concede, will have a knock-on effect into the second-hand car market.

TALK.START.PARA: —It goes up another per cent in July.

—As the member for Murray points out, there is a double whammy of this old regressive sales tax. Not only will it increase by what is in the budget; the previously legislated increase also applies. So we have the situation of an horrific sales tax being put on cars, and a knocking around of the young people of this nation—the Triple J listeners whom the Prime Minister tried to woo yesterday in a somewhat disastrous broadcast.

PARA.TAB: I have to say that I share their concern. One of the biggest first purchases I made in my life was a small vehicle. I was in a situation where there was no public transport available and I had to try to get home occasionally from the Holsworthy Army Base in Sydney where I was serving in the army. It was a good old small Holden near EJ type. These people will feel cheated by this budget.

The lack of fairness and justice on the housing side with regard to small business I will leave to my colleague the member for Forrest to speak about. It is a lack of justice. It is one that we will expose further and further as we build on the rhetoric of the Prime Minister when he said—and I repeat:

SPEECH.PARA: This is as good as it gets.

Those are the words injected into the budget debate by the Prime Minister this day. Those words will echo the length and breadth of this land, starting with the debates today in the House and the Senate, but elsewhere more so, including a budget breakfast in Brisbane tomorrow. I now have another quote from the Prime Minister from 2 December 1992. He said:
I say any economy that can't travel at 4 per cent without spilling over into imports should give the game away.
. . . we ought to be able to run this economy at 4 per cent at least, and will need to bring unemployment down in a sustained marked way in the long term.

Given this quote, it should be noted that the growth forecast contained in the budget for 1995-96 was 3 3/4 per cent, drifting down to 3 1/2 per cent later on. The current account deficit, meanwhile, is expected to increase from 3.9 per cent to six per cent of GDP. In short, we will have a current account deficit, according to the budget, of a further $27 billion. With this economic growth rate, Australia Incorporated vis-a-vis the world will be sucking in imports in a way which the Prime Minister said we should be able to manage—in a way we have not been able to manage—and as a consequence Australia Incorporated on its current account deficit will be $27 billion in the red.

PARA.TAB: There is a legacy to that for the next generation and the generation beyond. It is a horrific circumstance and will not be overcome by the increase in the company tax rate from 33 per cent to 36 per cent. Do you know what that increase does? It removes another element of our competitiveness where the tax rates—

TALK.START.PARA: —What's your rate?

—I will deal with that. We will lose an element of our competitiveness in Asia, in some of the ASEAN economies and elsewhere. Let me say of the great canard advanced by the Prime Minister during question time today: yes, we had a higher company tax rate but, in the context of that Fightback package, why would we not? We were going to abolish payroll tax before the introduction of the GST. We were going to abolish petrol and diesel fuel excise tax before the introduction of the GST. We were going to abolish sales tax, remove it from the statute books, no ifs no buts.
—Do you still support that?
—No, I do not because a GST is no longer our policy.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—It's yours now.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleagues are absolutely correct. The nature of the sales tax extensions in this particular budget are all about a GST. It is going to cost you government, and deservedly so, as it adds to the gap between the rich and the poor in this country.

PARA.TAB: A bit more ought to be said on that corporate tax rate. It leapt from 33 per cent to 36 per cent. If you are at the top end of the town—big unions, big governments, big deals—there are legitimate ways and means where the effective rate of taxation will be something less than that. If you are at the small business end of town—the one where the Prime Minister said, `This is as good as it gets'—what do you face? You face the full whack of a 33 per cent to 36 per cent corporate tax rate.

Those in the small business sector, which the government knows little about in practical terms, face a circumstance in which they can do two things. Firstly, they can decide not to put on the person they interviewed last week or the week before and go back into the bunker mentality, which we do not want them in, in terms of genuinely getting the economic recovery under way. Secondly, they can look at retrenchment to ease the burden of their situation arising from the increase in the corporate tax rate from 33 per cent to 36 per cent.

You can lightly dismiss small business and the taxation circumstance you have dealt out to it in this budget but it will now lightly dismiss you. The sooner the voters are given the opportunity to do that, the better for all our sakes.

The effect of this budget is not only a greater gap between rich and poor solidifying the hopeless record of Labor on that score but also the one thing that tears it apart from its own core fundamental beliefs—the beliefs that Treasurer Willis referred to at his recent anniversary dinner before he produced a shabby budget like this. That is, this budget and the last Dawkins budget have continued to drive an increasing gap between those in rural and regional Australia and those in capital city Australia who do not have access to public transport. That will be further exacerbated by this sales tax increase where people have no choice but to buy motor vehicles. It affects not just rural and regional Australia but also the nappy valleys on the edges of Sydney, Melbourne and elsewhere which are too often a long way from the public transport systems developed many decades ago.

Finally, as we give proper credence to this matter of public importance on the lack of integrity of the budget—its lack of transparency and its regressive taxation measures—I ask: what will it do right here in Canberra? What will it do for jobs generally on this day when an important employment figure has been announced?

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, they tell us.

—All they can do is quote the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters (Mr Johns). A headline in a recent newspaper reads `Many to be out of job, says Johns'. He is your minister. Do you deny this? Do you reject his comments? Here it is loud and clear.

PARA.TAB: I know the great new member for Canberra (Mr Smyth) will quite rightly sheet this home to the minister at every opportunity. I have a new found concern for the economic performance of Canberra. I see it as part—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's always been there.

—It has perhaps been disguised. I have a new found concern for the economic prospect of Canberra not only because of the new member for Canberra and the new ACT government but also because of its linkage with the regional economy of southern New South Wales. Government members have been caught out and exposed by the words of their own Prime Minister in his arrogant style. He went over the top twice today. I will leave the other one aside for the moment. But let us never forget that this is not as good as it gets and the budget will fail. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEVIS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —Members of the opposition, including the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer), are obviously fairly excited by the comments of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) earlier today on Brisbane radio. They are a fairly easily excitable lot. Since the delivery of the budget on Tuesday night, those opposite have been rather fascinated—I must say it is predictable—by the bottom line that the government was able to produce in its 1995-96 budget. So they should be rather fascinated with the bottom line that produced a surplus. A surplus is something which is unexplored territory for the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the Liberal-National coalition opposite. They have never encountered it before. In all those years that they occupied the treasury bench in this country, they failed to reach a surplus on any single occasion.

PARA.TAB: It is worth recalling in the context of this debate about the economy and the budget that in the 40-odd years since the current method of calculating budget outlays, expenditure and revenue was put in place—it was put in place in 1953—the opposition, when in government, failed to get a surplus. It did not achieve a surplus on a single, solitary occasion. From the day that Robert Menzies got the idea that he should form the Liberal Party and spent all those years in lazy government, they have not once had a surplus. In fact, in the 40-odd years that the current accounting system has applied, only four surplus budgets prior to this budget have been recorded by the Commonwealth, and they were all budgets of Labor governments led by Bob Hawke and the current Prime Minister. They were the budgets of 1987-88, 1988-89, 1989-90 and 1990-91.

The last time the Liberals had a chance to try to balance the books, which was the last time they were in office, the now Leader of the Opposition, who was then Treasurer, produced a budget with a whopping $4 1/2 billion deficit. This deficit equated to 2.6 per cent of the country's GDP. If we took that 2.6 per cent today and applied it in today's dollars, it would mean a budget deficit of $12 billion. That is the scale of the deficit that the Liberal Party produced for Australia when it last held the reins of government. That was the performance of the current opposition leader when he was the Treasurer. Against that background, those opposite stand in some wonderment at a government that has been able to produce not just the first surplus budget but the fifth surplus budget in current accounting history.

Prior to Tuesday night I think there was an expectation abroad in the community and in the markets that would have looked favourably upon a deficit budget of maybe $2 billion to $4 billion. Certainly, they would have been tickled pink with anything in the $2 billion range. The government produced a surplus in excess of $700 million. It is worth recalling not the petty political comments of those opposite but the comments made earlier today by the senior analyst from Moody's. The Treasurer made some reference to this earlier today in question time. The senior analyst from Moody's in New York, Vincent Truglia, made these comments this morning on the budget:

SPEECH.PARA: From our point of view, going to surplus is a good idea no matter how it is achieved. So I think this is an appropriate policy to take under present circumstances.

The government's approach in this budget is, to quote his own words, `an appropriate policy to take under present circumstances'. One of the focuses of the budget was to exert some influence on the current account. In a contribution that rambled mainly across earlier comments of the Prime Minister on talkback radio and touched a little on the budget, the Leader of the National Party made reference to the current account. Let us look at what the senior analyst from Moody's had to say about Australia's current account and the efforts of this government to address it. He said:

. . . the best way to try to deal with a current account deficit is to try and reduce the Government deficit. As a result, I don't know what else you could ask the Government to do to try to deal with a current account deficit, the size of which no one, as far as I know, had really predicted a year or so ago.

Again that is an endorsement of the government's strategy in this budget to turn around the current account deficit. It is worth making mention of the figures in relation to the current account deficit. It is true that the budget estimates indicate a current account deficit at current dollar levels. That is current dollar levels in a bigger economy. The nation's wealth in 12 months time will be greater and, as a result, the current account deficit will fall as a percentage of GDP. That is the important measure. The important measure is not the absolute dollar figure. The measures taken by the government in this budget have turned that around. That fact is acknowledged by the senior analyst of Moody's in New York even if it is not understood by those opposite.

PARA.TAB: At the moment, those opposite are devoid of not just economic policies but policies across the board. It is because they are devoid of policies in the economic area that they seek to cast some doubts on the methodology. They try to throw a smokescreen around the budget and divert attention from the good underlying economic substance that is contained in it.

When you cannot talk about the content try to attack the process. That seems to be the idiom. It is a fairly well worn political ploy and one that is fairly readily recognised around here and one that is not about to fool the public in their consideration of the budget. The Treasurer's comments in relation to the budget on Tuesday night were absolutely plain and unequivocal as to how the surplus had been produced. On the first page of the budget speech the Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: This—
that is, the surplus—
is achieved by cuts to spending, increases in revenue, and asset sales—
he was up-front about the asset sales—
including part of the proceeds from the sale of the Government's remaining equity in the Commonwealth Bank.
He went on to say:
Importantly, the Budget for 1996-97 will be in surplus excluding asset sales and special debt and capital repayments.

That important point seems to have been lost by the opposition and, I am sad to say, lost by a number of people in the gallery. In 1996-97, the budget will be in surplus without any regard to asset sales and without any regard to special debt repayments. That is an outstanding turnaround. It is a turnaround in the bottom line of the budget which has never before been seen in this country.

PARA.TAB: There a few things that I should mention about asset sales. Although the Leader of the National Party did not mention this in his speech, it is actually embedded in the matter we are debating. I suspect that this will be part of the contributions of others in this debate. It is worth recognising that the opposition has run the line that somehow this surplus is illusory and that we should not include in the budget surplus a calculation for the revenue generated by asset sales.

That is a fairly quaint approach to how the budget should be put together. It is a different approach to the one that has been adopted in the past. The budget this year has been produced using the same conventions and the same methods as have been used for many years by this government and the former government. When the present Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer that was the method he used. I suspect tonight we are going to hear from the Leader of the Opposition that the bottom line figure is illusory. It is arrived at by a method which he used when he was Treasurer.

What are the alternatives if you do not do that? Those opposite say that when we purchase a major item we should include it as an expense, but when we sell it we should not include it as revenue. Is that the logic of what those opposite are saying or are they saying that we should cut that out of the budget too? Are they saying that if we have a big spending item in this budget we really should not include it as an expense? They do not think we should include the sale of an asset as revenue or income.

If that is the approach they want to adopt they might get a few surprises. I had a quick look through my own portfolio area of defence at just a handful of the major acquisitions this year. In this calendar year defence will be purchasing, in major acquisitions alone, in the order of $1.6 billion. If you want us to take that out and pretend we are not spending that this year, that will be a novel approach to budget accounting. Of course the expenditure should be included. Of course the benefit of the asset sale should be there. In effect, the asset sale represents the income stream that asset would have returned had we kept it. That is what the asset sale is. It is a totally legitimate inclusion. It is an inclusion which you adhered to when you were in charge of the treasury bench and it is in total conformity with the approach adopted by international standards.

A lot of this has to do with people's expectations about the future and how good people's crystal balls are. I want to go back just 12 months, to the last budget and the comments that were made by people opposite then about our estimates. Bear these in mind when we listen tonight to `Dr Doom' and the doomsayers about the terrible time ahead of us. Last June, in response to the budget, in an MPI not dissimilar to this, the shadow Treasurer, the member for Higgins (Mr Costello), said:

SPEECH.PARA: Remember this. The crucial forecast in the government's budget was for a surge in private business investment. That is the crucial figure.

That is what he said of last year's budget. He then went on to give us an idea of what his crystal ball told him about that, in his words, `crucial figure' in the budget. He said this from his crystal ball—this is your shadow treasurer, your spokesperson's crystal ball:

All we can see is that the recent figures show no sign of a surge in private business investment at all, no sign of that massive lift, no sign in capital expenditure figures, no sign in the national accounts, no sign that business investment is coming up.

Your prediction, from the person on your side responsible for treasury matters, was that there were no signs at all. We predicted that there would be a 14.5 per cent increase in business investment. That is what we said in the last budget. Do you know what it was, Mr Deputy Speaker? We got a 24 per cent increase. Put that against the best guess estimate of members of the opposition. They said that there were no signs that there would be any increase, that we would not get 14, we would not get 10, we would not get five, that there were no signs to believe that investment would rise at all. Not only did we reach the 14 1/2 per cent mark that we set in the budget; we exceeded it dramatically and will return an increase in investment of 24 per cent in the current financial year.

PARA.TAB: It was not just that forecast that you got wrong, and it was not just that forecast that we exceeded. There were other critical forecasts in last year's budget. The GDP forecast was 4 1/2 per cent, we said. You said, as Leader of the National Party, that we would not reach 4 1/2 per cent. You now know, although you do not want to admit it and you will not say it publicly, that we are saying 5 1/2 per cent growth. You said we would not get 4 1/2. Your assessments are not worth the paper they are written on.

The unemployment forecast in the budget was 9 1/2 per cent. We said it would fall to 9 1/2 per cent. You said it would not. You said we could not reduce unemployment to 9 1/2 per cent. We have reduced it well below that. The figures out today, from memory, show it at about 8.4, 8.5 per cent. That is an outstanding achievement, one which you have not to this moment applauded. At every turn your shadow spokesperson hops up and tries to paint some cloud over the ever improving employment figures. It is about time you woke up to yourself.

Let us look at the tax burden. The Leader of the National Party wanted to make some play on that. At the last election you went to the people, two years ago, with a Fightback package, which you all signed up in blood, with a pledge to increase the company tax rate—that is right, increase it, make it go up—from 39 to 42 per cent. But that is not too surprising, given your performance when you were in government.

The last budget you brought down, the Howard budget of 1982-83, had a company tax rate not even of your promised 42 per cent—the last company tax rate you had was 46 per cent. That is against this budget, which has a 36 per cent tax rate for companies. You are complaining about this budget producing a 36 per cent rate, when you had a 46 per cent rate when you were in office. The same situation applies through private taxes. Regrettably, time will prevent me going through those. But it is worth recalling that the top marginal tax rate under a Liberal government was 60 per cent; it is now 47 per cent. The bottom marginal tax rate under you when you were in government was 30 per cent; it has now dropped to 20 per cent. When we want to talk about who is taxing high, there is no mistake on what is shown by the figures. The figures show that it is you, my friend. When you were in government, you were the people who ensured a high tax regime in both company taxes and personal taxes.

The motion today and the rhetoric today is a good piece of politicking because you know you have a major headache. You have said you will not increase taxes. You have said we should not count asset sales. You have a $10 billion hole in a budget that you would have put together—$10 billion worth of cost cuts that you should now come clean on. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening's matter of public importance is on the lack of integrity underpinning the government's budget and, of course, its effect on the housing and small business sector. But, firstly, I would comment that the government tries to run the line to the Australian people that it has, in fact, run a budget surplus of $718 million.

PARA.TAB: However, we only need to look at the government's own budget document, the budget statement of 1995-96, and turn to the back to the `unadjusted budget deficit'. I would read this to the House as it goes to the relevant point. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Further adjustment can be made to . . . measure of the budget deficit to eliminate the effects of net advances to the States and assets sales. This adjusted measure can provide a more accurate picture of the underlying position of the budget. The National Fiscal Outlook adopts this approach in looking at the deficits of the Commonwealth and States and Territories budgets.

Table 2 below outlines that budget deficit. What do we find when we look at table 2? In fact, the government has got, true to form, the asset sales of $5.3 billion-odd and a true budget deficit of $8.2 billion contained in its own document. Of course, it is even higher than that. Mr Deputy Speaker, if you throw in some other minor fiddles and asset sales, the real figure gets up to $8.7 billion. So much for honesty and integrity in regard to the budget outcome! But that budget document is set down on the basis that the government will deliver. It has $5.3 billion worth of asset sales to make the bottom line look good.

PARA.TAB: Let us have a look at the government's record in delivering asset sales just in the 1990s. We will not go back because your record is lousy all the way through. In the 1990-91 budget period, your budget had asset sales contained within the budget document of $1 billion. How much did you deliver—$161 million. I repeat: $1 billion, and you delivered $161 million. In 1991-92, how much was in the budget paper—$625 million. What did you achieve—$301 million, which was not even half. In 1992-93 in the budget documents there were $1,600 million worth of asset sales. What did you achieve—$801 million. You got halfway there in that year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Qantas.

—Remember, Qantas is now in for the fourth time. In 1993-94 you had $2,400 million. That is the only year you came close. You flogged the Commonwealth Bank and the Snowy Mountains Corporation in that lot. You sold $2,400 million-odd worth. But it gets worse, fellas. In the 1994-95 budget you had $2.4 billion—and you achieved $55 million.
—It didn't come near it.

—It did not come within a bull's roar. If you cannot even come close on your past record, how can we trust the integrity of your present figures when you have a whopping $5.3 billion and you try to con the Australian people that you are going to run a surplus?

PARA.TAB: Let us look at what other measures you have put into your budget and the promises that you and your Prime Minister (Mr Keating) have made. I remember that on 19 November 1992 the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: What I am promising is not to put up tax.
I will look at not only the aggregate rates of tax but also the budget measures contained within the 1993-94 budget papers.

PARA.TAB: In 1993-94—this is after the Prime Minister promised not to put up taxes—taxes went up by $1.5 billion, running out in out years to $3.7 billion. We need only look at this year's budget—and remembering the Prime Minister's promise that he would not put up taxes—to see that the tax measures went up $2.397 billion. Company tax this year went up $320 million. Tax on the automotive industry—on people trying to buy cars—went up a whopping $330 million. On people trying to build or renovate their homes, taxes went up $215 million.

What about the Medicare levy? Who promised not to put up the Medicare levy? The Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) said, `There is no proposal to increase the levy and there won't be. Both the Prime Minister and I have repeatedly ruled out any increase.' How much will the Medicare levy raise for the government? How much will it rip into the pockets of the Australian people? Another $230 million. So much for no increases!

But it goes on. The tobacco excise went up $70 million. Revenue protection measures—more tightening and squeezing of small businesses and subcontractors—went up $396 million. The government will screw more out of government business enterprises to make the bottom line look good, and it will get another $107 million out of that. Where are you going to hit the ordinary Australians and get them again? In the pocket. You will increase bank licence and supervision fees. What will that raise? It will raise $185 million.
Mr Bevis interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —So you do not mind swagging the Australian people out of another $185 million. Is that what you are saying? The chief of the Commonwealth Bank—the bank that you want to flog off by selling the remaining half—said, `New taxes and charges in the budget are likely to push up variable rates across-the-board.' So much for the government helping ordinary Australians! Other measures are going to go up $544 million.

PARA.TAB: No new taxes? What were the Prime Minister's words? He said, `What I am promising is not to put up taxes.' They were his words, not ours. Yet taxes have gone up $2,397 million. So much for not trying to put up taxes! What happened to the government's tax cuts? The Prime Minister promised this just the other day, and we can also go back and see what he said in the One Nation statement on 26 February 1992. In the One Nation statement, he talked about tax cuts—surprise, surprise! The Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: These substantial tax cuts will result in a reform of the tax scales of maximum benefit to the great majority of working men and women of Australia. They will underpin the Accord to ensure that workers do not find their real disposable income increasingly eroded by effective taxes.

What happened to taxes? They have all gone up, when the Prime Minister promised they would not. Can you believe what the Prime Minister said on AM radio recently? He said, `What is more useful: a handful of cash now which will disappear'—it sure disappeared—`or something that goes on forever?' I have to say that ordinary Australians cannot wait forever. They will not wait forever. You have a lousy track record. You have put up taxes. Why should they ever believe you?

PARA.TAB: Let us look at what you are doing to housing. You are now whacking a tax on all the fittings that people put into their kitchen area—the sinks and furniture. You are putting taxes on hardware. You are increasing taxes in those areas. You are taxing kitchen and bathroom cupboards. You are putting taxes on screws, nails, glues, adhesives and ceramic floor and wall tiles—all of those things.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. Oh yes, you are right.

—The tax is going on ceramic floor and wall tiles; you do not even know what tax you are putting on. It will increase the price of the family home for the very low income earners by at least $1,000 and up to $2,000. That is what the government is doing for ordinary Australians. So much for no new taxes!

PARA.TAB: But it is not only that. There are taxes for people who want to do a bit of work around their home on the weekend. If they want to paint their home, they will find there is a tax on paint now. If people cannot afford to have a full brick home with face brick, they will find that you have taxed them because they have a less affordable home with fibro. If they paint it, they will be whacked with a 12 per cent sales tax on the paint to paint both inside and outside their home. If they want to do weekend work around the home, they will be taxed on their hardware—their nails, screws, paint and glue. You will put tax on their family home after taxing their cars by $1,000.

So much for no new taxes. You are increasing, as I said, the company tax rate. There are some 350,000 incorporated small businesses in this country. They are trying to repay debt after your recession they had to have. What are you going to do? You are going to rip out their retained earnings by whacking up the tax rate on Australia's small business. They are going to pay extra taxes. They are going to pay extra bank charges. They are going to pay extra for their homes. They are going to pay extra for their cars. They are going to pay extra taxes, even though your Prime Minister said on 19 November 1992:

SPEECH.PARA: What I am promising is not to put up tax.

It is another broken promise. How can we accept the integrity of this budget when you could not meet your sales predictions for asset sales? You broke your promise in regard to increased taxes. How can anyone believe this Prime Minister? How can anyone believe someone who said:
`What's more useful: a handful of cash now—
which they still have not got-
which will disappear—
it sure will—
or something that will go on forever? `

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance from the opposition has been pretty underwhelming. It looked pretty impressive with words such as `integrity', `transparency' and `regressive', but so far I have not heard the opposition relating at all to the budget.

PARA.TAB: One thing is pretty darn sure. What is particularly transparent is that the opposition has no policies. I expect to be suitably underwhelmed this evening when the recycled Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) gets up and gives a response. Already he has been locked into `no new taxes' by the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party (Mr Costello). I think he has been referred to in certain quarters as the permanent low altitude flier. He is pretty good at getting up and making smart remarks during MPIs, but we have never heard from him one piece of credible economic policy.

The Treasurer (Mr Willis) brought that to the House's attention during the debate on yesterday's matter of public importance. What did the opposition achieve out of the MPI yesterday? The Leader of the Opposition, a former Treasurer of this country, and a supposed future Treasurer of this country, the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, went hell for leather on this sale of the Commonwealth Bank. Today the Treasurer was able to read something out of the prospectus which indicates that he made it very clear at the time what government policy was and what government policy is all about.

I said on budget night that this 1995 budget had snookered the opposition and they were snookered again today, hoisted with their own petard by the fact that they made such a big play out of this prospectus from the Commonwealth Bank. It had forgotten to read the fine print, but all the fine print is in the budget papers. Nothing has been hidden from anybody.

In question time and during the debate on the MPI on the day of the budget, there was a great deal of talk about Mr Tony Cole, the former secretary to the Treasury. I gather that he was on Four Corners the night before. Tony Cole's words were quoted and requoted. What does Mr Tony Cole say about this budget? Presumably he is someone who would have a fairly good grasp of what is going on. In today's Australian he said:
The Budget is always a political document, even more so in the last year before an election. . . . . . . . . .

This budget shapes up well by the standards of past election-year Budgets. We can be relieved that the Government appears to have decided economic credibility is to be an essential plank in its election platform.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that indicates a pretty decent judgment. He was particularly pleased about our decision to accelerate national savings through these very tax cuts going in to support employee superannuation contributions. He says:

PARA.TAB: The decisions to accelerate the introduction of employee contributions to superannuation and to switch proposed tax cuts into direct contributions into super accounts of low to middle-income earners—

SPEECH.PARA: not regressive at all—

will make a lasting and considerable contribution to national savings. The tax switch means what was to be a large hole in public and national savings will be converted largely into a transfer from public to private savings.

PARA.TAB: A Budget like this in an election year should encourage our international creditors to believe Australia has at least recognised it can no longer ignore its chronic savings problem. And that is important.

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the day what will affect the livelihoods of families will be whether we can manage this economy and produce a sustainable recovery with jobs. I might remind the two speakers for the opposition that we have a very good track record on increasing the standard of living for families. As Tom Dusevic said in the Australian on 20 April, when he was reporting on an EPAC report Income distribution in Australia: recent trends and research:
. . . and the fact that average material living standards per capita have risen by almost 30 per cent under Labor . . .

Although he notes that there has been the income disparity that the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) talked about, this is a worldwide trend that has been affected by technological change, globalisation, internationalisation and more women in the work force. I note the very positive numbers in today's employment growth figures. Women are the real winners in long-term employment by today's figures—80,000 of them. They are getting the jobs and they are out there helping to support their families.

PARA.TAB: I think it is very important to remind ourselves when this argument about income disparity is brought up that many policies of this Labor government over the last 11 years have made sure that we have minimised that disparity. The social affairs correspondent for the Australian mentions some of these things in his article. He states:

SPEECH.PARA: Awards and minimum wage arrangements have retarded the development of a "working poor" in Australia. And when wider measures of income are used—taking into account our well-targeted social security payments, progressive tax system, high rates of home ownership and the whole range of social wage benefits such as health and education—inequality is slightly less pronounced.

That is the backdrop to this 1995 budget. I think we should be very clear about the fact that it is a very balanced way to provide in an economically responsible way for the future of this country. We have just heard from a front bench spokesperson for the opposition, someone who would have carriage in a Liberal-National Party government. The only thing he could do was talk and worry about very small ticket items in this budget. It has been a Labor government that has bitten the bullet on national savings, on superannuation, to make a real difference for the future of this country, for the families of this country.

PARA.TAB: Talking about the families of this country, our agenda for families and the specific things we have brought in with this budget are a very proud part of a long-term strategy to make sure that families are at the centrepiece of our policies. It is very pleasing to see that Father David Cappo, who was on the International Year of the Family Council and who is the national director of the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission, agrees wholeheartedly with us. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: As well the Superannuation savings plan should provide a strategy for dignified retirement incomes for low income families. And an important aspect of the new Social Justice Strategy is the use of new funding ($247m) in the Better Cities Program that will also attack the alarming growth in locational poverty traps in Australia,"
He says further:

This budget should also help prevent further damage to family life in Australia by staving off another interest rate rise. And deflecting tax increases away from those families most in need in a tight fiscal era is a social justice achievement to be applauded.

Let me just outline some of those excellent initiatives that we have brought in in this budget. Might I also say that we have delivered on every 1993 election promise for families and women. We are about announcing policies and then carrying them through. Let us look at some of the excellent initiatives in this budget that will further our agenda for families. The first one is the maternity allowance that will give women and families greater financial support, at least $816, at that very difficult time when a new baby comes into the family. That will make a significant difference.

PARA.TAB: In child care we are freeing up 31,000 places, targeting those for the needs of working mothers. One initiative that I am particularly pleased about is that families in rural and remote areas will benefit from $7 1/2 million for 500 innovative child-care places. This has been applauded by rural women all across Australia. This is a very important issue. The needs of families in rural and remote areas are being attended to.

Children with special needs will get $17 million over four years. We have a continuing commitment to provide child-care places and 12,000 new family day care places are part of this budget policy. Eight thousand new places in community based centres and 40,000 new outside school hour places are to be achieved by 1999. In fact, we will be spending $12 billion in direct assistance to families, including of course services like education and Medicare.
Everyone, including companies, knows only too well that profit share for companies has been the highest it has been in a long time. Paul Simons, the Chairman of Woolworths, said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have only had the 33 per cent rate for a couple of years but now it is back into the middle ground which is where, perhaps, it should have been all along.

When they stop being political about it, companies that have had high profit share will know that they have a responsibility to contribute to this economy and to the welfare of families. At the end of the day, low interest rates will make a difference to the houses of all families in this country, to the jobs that are available and to small business. That is why this budget is an excellent, bold and thoroughly responsible document. (Time expired)

No.27Schedule 1, page 11, item 29, after proposed section 73BDA, insert the following section:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Purchaser-Provider Panel

PROCTEXT.PARA: " `73BDD.(1) There is established a panel, known as the Purchaser-Provider Panel, to monitor the operation of this Division, and of hospital purchaser-provider agreements and medical purchaser-provider agreements, and to report to the Minister as provided by this section.
`(2) The panel consists of members appointed by the Minister for periods not exceeding 2 years in accordance with this subsection:
(a)the Complaints Commissioner (who shall chair the panel);
(b)2 members appointed by the Minister following consultation with the medical profession, including specialist practitioners;
(c)2 members appointed by the Minister following consultations with organizations concerned with the provision of services by private hospitals;
(d)2 members appointed by the Minister following consultations with registered organizations;
(e)2 members appointed by the Minister following consultations with organizations concerned with the provision of services by public hospitals;
(f)2 members appointed by the Minister following consultations with organizations representing consumers.
`(3) The performance of the functions of the panel is not affected by a vacancy or vacancies in the membership of the panel.
`(4) Members of the panel may be reappointed after a term of appointment has expired.

`(5) Any statistics information or data provided to the panel in the course of its activities by a registered organization, hospital, medical practitioner, or agency of the Commonwealth shall not be in a form in which the personal or medical particulars of a patient or patients can be identified or inferred.
`(6) For the purposes of the Privacy Act 1988, the panel is to be taken to have obtained that information only for the purposes of discharging its functions.

`(7) Unless both parties to a hospital or medical purchaser-provider agreement give their consent in writing, no agreements or provisions of an agreement may be required by the panel to be furnished to it.

`(8) Subject to subsection (9), no later than 1 October each year the panel shall provide to the Minister a written report on the operation of this Division, and of hospital purchaser-provider agreements and medical purchaser-provider agreements, during the immediately preceding financial year and such reports may contain any recommendations the panel thinks fit to make.

`(9) The Minister must cause a copy of each report received from the panel under subsection (8) to be presented to each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after receiving it.
`(10) The panel will be disbanded no later than 30 June 1997.".

"61A. After section 73D:

PARA.TAB: Insert:

PROCTEXT.PARA: `Division 5A—Removal of hospitals etc. from non-contracted benefits
Definitions
`73E. In this Division, unless the contrary intention appears:
"determination" means a determination under section 73EA;
"treatment" means:
(a)hospital treatment, and related services, provided by or on behalf of a hospital or day hospital facility; and
(b)any professional service rendered to a patient while that hospital treatment is provided to the patient at the hospital or day hospital facility.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Determinations relating to non-contracted benefits in respect of particular treatments at particular hospitals etc.

PROCTEXT.PARA: `73EA.(1) A registered organization, a State, a Territory or the National Health and Medical Research Council may apply in writing to the Minister for a determination relating to episodes of treatment of a particular kind provided at a hospital or day hospital facility specified in the application.

`(2) If the Minister is satisfied that the standard of treatment of that kind provided at that hospital or day hospital facility is unacceptable, the Minister may, by written notice given to the hospital or day hospital facility, determine that subparagraph (ii) of the condition set out in paragraph (bf) of Schedule 1 no longer applies in respect of episodes of treatment of that kind provided at that hospital or day hospital facility.
`(3) The determination must be made in accordance with the guidelines issued under section 73EB.
`(4) The Minister must:
(a)cause copies of the determination to be given to each registered organization; and
(b)cause a copy of the determination to be published in the Gazette.

`(5) If the Minister decides not to make a determination, he or she must notify in writing the registered organization that applied for the determination, and the hospital or day hospital facility in question, accordingly.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Guidelines for making determinations

PROCTEXT.PARA: `73EB.(1) The Minister must issue written guidelines setting out the grounds for deciding whether the standard of treatment of a particular kind provided at a hospital or day hospital facility is unacceptable.
`(2) The guidelines may also specify matters to which the Minister must have regard in considering whether any such grounds, or particular grounds, exist.
`(3) Guidelines issued under this section are disallowable instruments for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Effect of determinations

PROCTEXT.PARA: `73EC.(1) A registered organization is not obliged under an applicable benefits arrangement to pay a benefit in relation to the provision of an episode of treatment if:
(a)at all times during which the episode of treatment was being provided, a determination was in force in respect of episodes of treatment of that kind; and
(b)the episode of treatment in question was provided at the hospital or day hospital facility to which the determination applied; and
(c)the benefit would, but for this subsection, be a benefit of a kind referred to in subparagraph (ii) of the condition set out in paragraph (bf) of Schedule 1.
`(2) Subsection (1) has effect despite:
(a)subparagraph (ii) of the condition set out in paragraph (bf) of Schedule 1; and
(b)the applicable benefits arrangement in question.

`(3) This section does not affect the payability of benefits by a registered organization in respect of episodes of treatment provided in a hospital or day hospital facility with which the registered organization has a hospital purchaser-provider agreement.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the amendments be agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: We have before us today a range of Senate amendments to the Health Legislation (Private Health Insurance Reform) Amendment Bill, which was introduced into this House some time ago by the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence). Since the government initiated this legislation, there have been attempts based on misleading information to misrepresent the impact of the legislation. The government remains committed to this bill and its intentions. The opposition's amendments have largely come from vested interest groups. Its amendments are designed to represent its sectional interests.

PARA.TAB: The AMA and procedural specialists continue to mislead people about the effect of the proposed changes. Some groups have claimed that the legislation makes it compulsory for doctors to contract with funds. There is no compulsion with respect to doctor contracts. I challenge any of the groups to point to a clause which can possibly be construed as compelling doctors to contract. Patients will retain their freedom of choice when choosing their doctor or hospital. The difference will be that either there will be no costs or, if there are out-of-pocket costs, patients will know exactly what they are up for if they choose a contracted doctor. That is the difference.

If insured people are treated by a doctor under contract, they will be covered for some and possibly all above-schedule charges. If they are treated by an uncontracted doctor, they will be in exactly the same situation as they are now: Medicare will pay 75 per cent of the scheduled fee, their health fund will pay 25 per cent of the scheduled fee and patients will be responsible for any above-schedule charges. That is very clear.

There have also been claims that all existing private health insurance products will be abolished. Again, this is simply not the case. Funds will be able to continue to offer all the products they offer now, and they will have the freedom to offer new products such as eliminating medical out-of-pocket costs.

The most absurd claim is that the reforms will lead to a reduction in the quality of care. Nobody from the doctor lobby has explained how this will happen. It just chants this like a mantra. Quality of care remains in the hands of the doctors. They will continue to decide all aspects of clinical treatment. The legislation does not interfere in their role in any way. Doctors seem to equate quality of care with the size of the out-of-pocket charge the patient meets.

Benefits will still be paid to 100 per cent of the MBS fee for in-hospital treatment for doctors who choose not to contract. Hospital contracts will also provide cost certainty for patients. Hospitals will also have a guaranteed default benefit if there is no contract with a health fund. All reforms to the health system are initially opposed by doctors, but later those sensible reforms, like Medicare itself, are embraced at least by the progressive elements of the profession.

The hospital contracts will also provide cost certainty for patients, and hospitals will have a guaranteed default benefit if there is no contract with a health fund. This bill will provide increased flexibility for patients, a better health insurance product and better value for money. The issues have been debated exhaustively in the media and in the other place for hours. The government considers the reforms in this bill are essential to a healthy and competitive health insurance industry, and we seek to finalise this legislation today.

The amendments passed by the Senate clarify the legislation and make the intent of the legislation even more transparent. The key amendments, first, require health insurance funds to provide psychiatric and rehabilitation coverage; secondly, ensure that stamp duty will not be payable on contracts covered under this legislation; and, thirdly, ensure that where industrial agreements exist employer-employee health benefit schemes are protected for a grandfather period until 1 July 1996.

I believe the reforms to be passed by the House today are essential if the private health industry is to survive and prosper into the next century. I commend these amendments to the House. They are long overdue. It is time we got on with this process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commiserate with the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Theophanous) on his illness. I think he should probably sack his doctor. I will not make many comments on the Health Legislation (Private Health Insurance Reform) Amendment Bill because it has been extensively debated in the other place. But I will just say a few things for the record.

PARA.TAB: The opposition is opposing this legislation. Back in February I said that our specific concerns about the legislation were: ensuring an adequately available default benefit, taking reasonable measures to protect sensitivity and privacy of patient data, and adequate provisions for the operation of the Trade Practices Act. That was a pretty wide gate that the government could have driven through had it wanted to and it was conceivable that it could have had coalition support for this legislation.

I think the measures before parliament at the moment are the wrong prescription for private health insurance. The Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) has made much of the ability of the bill to offer coverage for out-of-pocket expenses. But she has completely failed to address the main reason people drop out of private health insurance; and that is cost. Sixty-four per cent of people who drop their private health insurance do so because of the cost of premiums. Those premiums have gone up progressively over a decade because the government took $100 million out of the reinsurance pool, because the government ended the bed day subsidy and because the government reduced the Medicare rebate for in-patient services from 85 per cent to 75 per cent—and expected the funds to pick up the tab every time.

So we now have a situation where we have an accelerating rate of decrease of fund membership—2.1 per cent last year; and 64 per cent of them are doing it because of cost. Fifteen per cent of people drop out of private health insurance because of the gap. The average gap is actually $80 per episode. So this whole complex legislation and the whole process we have been through may address problems for 15 per cent of people, at an average cost of $80 per episode, but it will not address the main problem. I make the prediction here today: should the Labor Party be re-elected we will be looking at 30 per cent of the population with private health insurance coverage by December 1997. It could actually be less than that.

With regard to the Trade Practices Act, I think it is important that I read into the record some comments by Bob Baxt. Bob Baxt was Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission; he was a Labor Party appointment. He has made some particularly relevant comments on this legislation. In a letter dated 27 March 1995 he says:

SPEECH.PARA: I should indicate that I favour the general implementation of the Hilmer Report which is to be considered at COAG on 3 and 4 April. But at the same time I have always stressed the importance in government "hastening slowly" in extending the reach of the Trade Practices Act. A bolder approach may result in greater damage being created than the benefits that might flow from the adoption of the Trade Practices Act. The New Zealand experience in a number of areas where there has been a broad, universal and speedy application of competition policy to areas previously tightly regulated, has been less than satisfactory.

In this regard the Australian Government's policy on telecommunications is a classic example of a "hastening slowly" approach. This has achieved and is likely to continue to achieve, greater good in the short and long term than if the Government were to adopt the type of approach that was embraced by the New Zealand Government . . .
He goes on:

My major concern . . . is the blind acceptance of the proposition that the Commission, by using the Trade Practices Act, will be able to overcome any unfair or improper conduct on the part of powerful health funds, powerful hospitals or other powerful players in the health industry, acting either alone or together.
He then talks about the authorisation process that the government places much store on. He says:

. . . the authorization process is also a costly and time consuming one. Hank Spier in his evidence suggests that an authorization may be dealt with effectively in two to three months. Whilst this may be true in certain areas of the economy where the Commission has had considerable experience, I would suggest that in this industry a much longer time period is relevant. It could take six to nine months before some of these matters are effectively dealt with by the Commission. Furthermore there is always a chance that the Commission's decision may be appealed to the Trade Practices Tribunal—this has recently happened in the Newsagents case where from start to finish the whole process took over 2 1/2 years.
Mr Baxt finishes off with this warning:

There is a need to reflect on the considerable damage that might be caused in a very short time by the misuse of market power, or other unfair conduct which might occur in a scenario where the Commission, and others, will find that the Trade Practices Act does not offer the kind of protection that has been assumed will be available to the relevant participants.

They are the words of perhaps the most experienced person in the country on the Trade Practices Act. That is the warning he gives the government on the operation of the act. He was the Chairman of the Trade Practices Commission for four years.

PARA.TAB: Our concerns have not been met. I have absolutely no hesitation in voting against this legislation. The minister has talked much about putting consumers first. If funds that have as much as 70 per cent of market power in one state misuse that market power, irreparable damage will be done to the private health sector. We are not against a notion of reform. Some reform is needed in this area, but it needs to be done in a sensible, commonsense, non-ideological way.

When three major groups—the doctors, the hospitals and half the insurers—are opposing this you have to think you have it wrong. The fact is that you do have it wrong. Because, as the minister said, the contracts are voluntary—and we have never portrayed anything different—I do not think people will take them up. At best, this will be a flop; at worst, you will actually do damage. It will be a flop. People will not take it up.

You could have had something that would have worked, but you are incapable of negotiating or addressing legitimate concerns of medical specialists and private hospitals. In the end, we will get what I think will be an unworkable piece of legislation. It is not the way we would have approached the problems of private health insurance. We certainly reserve the right to review and amend these measures in government because, in the end, we will have to pick up the pieces of this mess.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I concluded at the commencement of question time, I had referred to the explanatory memorandum tabled with the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 5), which indicated that the number of people liable for tax under the Migration (Delayed Visa Applications) Tax Act is minimal. According to the department's own figures, I indicated that in June last year there were about 58,000 people who were unlawful non-citizens who had outstayed their visas by more than a year and were, therefore, in a category caught by the visa tax act.

PARA.TAB: I am not going to deal with it, but I simply raise the question: why is the government using tax legislation to compel social behaviour in this context instead of limiting the use of tax legislation to raise revenue? It is a significant issue and one in which the difficulties may have been brought home to the government in this case.

I am not convinced that the statement in the explanatory memorandum that a minimal number of people are liable for the visa tax is correct. According to the June 1994 figures, the amount of money owing by unlawful citizens under the provisions of the visa tax act is conservatively estimated at in excess of $850 million. It would be foolish to suggest that that amount or anything like it could be collected. The amount in question is far from minimal, even on a most conservative estimate.

Another way to look at it is to look at the results of the efforts of the government in identifying unlawful non-citizens in the financial year 1993-94. During that year, as I indicated earlier, more than 16,000 were located and nearly 9,000 were the subject of enforced departures, leaving approximately 7,500 who were not dealt with by the coercive measure. If the 7,500 were identified and were to pay only one year's tax at $3,000, the amount collected would be about $18 million. In the context of the government's budget that is not a large sum, but in the context of the government's enforcement program it represents roughly 50 per cent of the cost.

The figures I have been quoting were provided to my office as late as this morning as the latest figures available to the department. It is my understanding that as yet no-one has been taxed under the provisions of the visa tax act. I assume that in the nine months since September several thousand have been identified and of those a substantial proportion was not deported. The question the government might answer is: why was no tax collected?

It is not readily apparent to me that the government is in any position, having regard to the length of time the act has been in force, to decide that the aims of the visa tax act have or have not been achieved. If the government is in such a position, it has not provided any evidence upon which this House could reach a similar judgment. This is really an example of the government's legislative incompetence or its administrative incompetence or both. It has decided to go down a certain path to achieve a policy goal and it is now pulling the plug.

The government states in the explanatory memorandum that it has subsequently become apparent that the objectives of the visa tax act are already being achieved through other current legislative and procedural mechanisms. I invite an answer to the question as to what these legislative mechanisms and procedural mechanisms are.

The reasons given for the change of approach are hardly credible. What is the minister's real reason for wanting retrospectively to repeal the visa tax act? Will the government tell the people what it really is up to? The information available presently suggests that the government really has no idea what it is doing.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs CROSIO
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank all of the speakers who contributed to the debate and the opposition for supporting the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 5) before the House. A number of questions were raised, and I feel it is only right that I should at least reply to them.

PARA.TAB: The member for Tangney (Mr Williams) was concerned about the Migration (Delayed Visa Applications) Tax Act. I believe the member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) also touched on that very briefly. Can I just say that, even though they have extrapolated a lot of figures which sound good, like all figures they are not always accurate. We are repealing the Migration (Delayed Visa Applications) Tax Act because, first and foremost, as with all immigration matters, it is moving legislation. We must change as society changes.

Members opposite were concerned that some people would qualify and some would not and that some would be responsible for the payment. I can assure them that not everybody would be. If they studied the immigration debate that we have had over the last three to four years, they would see how many changes have been put into place. We as a government now find that it is quite irrelevant to have this particular procedure.

We have now our offshore decision makers, who are very carefully considering all applications for both visitor and temporary visas, with a view to reducing the incidence of overstaying. We have also put in place the provisions in the Migration Reform Act 1992 relating to the recovery of cost. We have only very few classes of visas that would enable successful applications from persons unlawfully in Australia. I wanted to touch on that for the benefit of the honourable member for Tangney.

In compassionate circumstances the implementation of a visa tax certainly would not be appropriate. There is certainly no doubt in the mind of the government and the community at large that that has served its term. What we have put in place over time with the amendments to the Migration Reform Act is certainly a lot better.

The member for Berowra was very concerned about the changes to the 816 and 818 visa class and the effect that would have on adult migrant education and the availability of English languages. He also quoted figures, but I can assure him that the figures he quoted were a little incorrect. We have, at this stage, 432 principal applicants who have entered into the AMEP in the language area. When one considers how many actual visas have been issued, that is a very small number.

We must in this legislation make it very clear that those people who were granted those visas had adequate knowledge of the English language. To now, because of an anomaly in the act, take up the extra space in the AMEP with other classes is both illogical and, as far as the government is concerned, never part of the visa classification. That is what the amendments will do.

As far as we are concerned, it is very difficult to get from the department a rough estimate of the potential approval rate of the 11,000 people who have already been granted that particular class of visa, but I reiterate that only 432 have accessed the AMEP. We are saying that they should not have access to that program. It is quite illogical to have a passage in the legislation that would allow them to do so.

The only other matter that I want to touch on relates to passenger cards. I inform the member for Berowra and the opposition that the legislation makes it mandatory for everyone to fill in the visa passenger cards when re-entering this country. We are putting these amendments into the legislation to give us a more flexible and sensible approach. At the moment, it is mandatory that they fill in those cards. We are saying that it should not have to be that way. People make visa applications and in those applications they provide all of their details relating to such things as their health and character.

We know that with multiple entries into this country circumstances may change so there will still be a certain number of questions still left unanswered on the card. We have to retain the health and character questions because they will be necessary in relation to New Zealanders. As members know, when New Zealand citizens enter Australia they are granted a very special category of visa subject to meeting certain conditions and the application for the grant of that category of visa. It should be noted that the questions on the passenger card apply to all incoming non-citizens and not just New Zealanders.

I have very quickly tried to answer a few of the concerns that were raised during the debate. I am sure I will be given other opportunities to speak on this matter when we make further amendments to the Migration Reform Act. In closing, I say to all those who expressed concern that this is Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 5). That is how many amendments we have had to this legislation.

We are a progressive government but, most importantly, we are listening to the concerns of the community at large and what is happening both in our department here and in our embassies overseas. I think we have to make sure, at all times, in relation to immigration legislation, that it is not set in concrete and that it is flexible enough to meet amendments and changes in society. That is what this bill is about. It is meeting the concerns of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration in recommendations 10 and 11. But, most particularly, it is meeting the concerns of the community. I commend the bill to the House.
