SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I became Leader of the Opposition, only three months ago, I said within a very short time that the great bulk of Australians believed that after the worst recession in 60 years they had enjoyed but five minutes of economic sunshine before the economic sky started falling in again. I know by their constant reaction that those who sit opposite do not like that little analogy. They do not like it because it sums up what the great majority of Australians throughout this nation really believe. That is why they do not like it.

PARA.TAB: The truth of the matter is that the great majority of Australians do feel like that at present, although regrettably, for reasons that I hope everybody understands, there is one section of the Australian community—namely, the farming section—and many others who live throughout rural Australia who do not even believe, because of the prolonged drought, that they have even enjoyed five minutes of economic sunshine. They believe they are a section of the community that for four long years suffered a drought before the Keating government recognised their plight.

That sense that after such a very short period of time the economic sky began to fall in again really did encapsulate how the great majority of people throughout the Australian mainstream felt. They felt that way after the worst recession in 60 years. They felt that way because of the neglect of a part-time Prime Minister (Mr Keating), because after 12 years and now 13 budgets a problem which grows worse by the year has not been effectively addressed. That sense of only five minutes of economic sunshine encapsulated the sense of drift, the sense of insecurity, the sense of concern and the sense of apprehension felt by so many Australians throughout the country.

There is another reason for it, too. They have grown weary of being led by a Prime Minister whose only stock-in-trade is dishonest hyperbole. They have grown weary of being told that budgets are going to bring home the bacon. They have grown weary of being told that they have never had it so good. They have grown weary of being told that they will get tax cuts, only to see them snatched away after the re-election of the Labor government. That is why I believe that the great majority of the Australian community have reacted in a negative fashion to this budget.

The real test of this budget is the extent to which it has been able to dislodge that sense of despondency, that sense of concern felt by so many people in mainstream Australia. But before I deal with my assessment of whether this year's budget has passed that test, has cleared that hurdle, let me say something about the context of my reply to the budget. There seems to be this curious notion opposite, entertained by the Prime Minister and others, that tonight is the occasion on which we reveal all of our policies. I know the Prime Minister would love that to happen.
Mr Bevis interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my right!
—I don't need any protection, Mr Speaker.
—You may.

—I know the Prime Minister would love that to happen. He would love that to happen for two reasons. The first reason is that it would divert attention from a failed budget. The second reason—and a reason that the great bulk of the Australian people are well aware of—is that I know and they know that, if we put our policies on the table tonight, that bloke over there would pinch them all. He has done it once again.

PARA.TAB: Government members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, they laugh. But isn't it interesting that, if you go through the budget, the item that has attracted the most attention in the last 24 hours is the sale of the Commonwealth Bank. Do you remember 10 years ago when the Liberal Party advocated the sale of the Commonwealth Bank? Do you know what Paul Keating and Bob Hawke said? They said they would fight the sale of the Commonwealth Bank to the last drop of Labor blood. They said that, while there was a light on the hill, they would fight it to the bitter end. They said that Ben Chifley would spin in his grave if anybody contemplated selling it.

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, do you know what? All those fine Labor principles, all that heroic rhetoric, counted for nought when they wanted the dough to produce a fraudulent balance. Let me just make one thing clear about coalition policy—and I make it very clear to the Australian people: coalition policy will be revealed at a time of our choosing, not Paul Keating's nomination. The responses to the budget speech conform to a number of categories. The first and most prominent of the category of responses to the budget is that the budget contains, without any exaggeration, a litany of dishonoured and broken promises.

The first and the worst of those broken promises is the final repudiation of the much vaunted One Nation tax cuts. The Prime Minister went to the last election knowing in his heart that the Australian nation could not afford the unfunded tax promises that he made. So deceitful was he that he even concealed from his senior ministers his decision to promise all of those One Nation tax cuts when he made his infamous l-a-w, law, promise.

Mr Speaker, in case anybody imagines that that is just a piece of opposition hyperbole, that that is just a piece of Liberal Party propaganda, let me remind you of the damning condemnation of the Prime Minister from the former Secretary to the Treasury, Tony Cole, only last Monday night when he said that the Prime Minister's office had deliberately falsified the economic forecast in the One Nation statement—caught red-handed; deliberately falsified.

But it did not stop there. We then come to a little thing called a company tax reduction which was promised at the time of the last election. I remember seeing the Prime Minister deliver that speech. He said, `The only way that we can get Australian companies working for Australia is to reduce their rate of company tax by 6c.' He stood up there and he promised it. He said, `This is the centrepiece; this is the heart of the government's economic policy, the heart of the government's business revival policy.' What has the government done two years later? It said, `Oh, we'll take it back, we'll just take it back like that.' That promise accounted for absolutely nothing.

Then we have the increase in the Medicare levy. The Medicare levy is going up from 1.4 per cent to 1.5 per cent. Anybody who knows anything about the operation of the Australian health system must know that it is sheer lunacy to increase the cost of being in the Medicare system without compensating adjustments in relation to private insurance. The greatest problem with Australia's medical system is the drain of people out of private health insurance, the haemorrhaging of private health insurance. Unless something is done to fix that, you are going to put further pressure on the public hospital system. And by driving up the Medicare levy without any compensating adjustments, you are going to put further pressure on the public hospital system. I have already dealt with the sale of the Commonwealth Bank.

Not content with breaking promises made before the last election, not content with dishonestly repudiating most of the promises made in the recent election campaign, the government wanted to go a bit further. It looked around and said, `Right. We will see if we can increase the price of a new home for young home buyers in Australia.' It decided to impose not a one per cent tax or a two per cent tax but a 12 per cent tax on home building materials, which will add something like $2,500 to $3,000 to the cost of a new home.

But that still was not enough. It decided to increase the sales tax on cars by five per cent. The reality is that the tax increases in this budget represent the biggest hike in tax collection of any Commonwealth budget since the second Keating budget in 1984. Taxation collections are going to rise by almost nine per cent in real terms in this budget. You have to go back to the Keating budget of 1984 and before that to a Whitlam budget more than 20 years ago to get a rise in the taxation collections that equals this.

Let me make it very clear to the House and to the Australian public that the coalition will vote against in both houses of parliament the rise in company tax, will vote against the new 12 per cent tax on home building materials, will vote against the five per cent rise in car sales tax and will vote against the rise in the Medicare levy.

All of those taxes violate the pre-election promises that were made by the Prime Minister and the government. All of them constitute straight electoral fraud and straight electoral dishonesty. We will also oppose the attempt by the government to undermine the independent contractor system by dragging them into the PAYE tax net.

The real fiscal outcome of the 1995 budget is not the surplus of $770 million talked about by the Prime Minister. The real fiscal outcome—and you can find it if you are patient enough to read through the documents right to the end—is actually a deficit of $8.2 billion. Everybody knows that this glittering surplus, as it would like people to believe, is being achieved by the essentially fraudulent devices of including the asset sales in the budget figuring.
Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why, when we come to government after the next election, we will introduce a charter of budget honesty which will not allow this to happen again.
—You! You! You—honesty!

—That is why we will separate the capital out of the recurrent side of the budget. Let me say this: I think a lot of people listening to this would remember when the inflation rate came out about three weeks ago. What did the Treasurer beg us all to do? He said, `Ignore the headline. Take no notice of the actual figure that the Statistician has produced because that is only the headline rate. What I want you to have a look at is the underlying rate—not the rate that has been published by the Statistician.'

PARA.TAB: Let me take a leaf out of the Treasurer's book. I would like the Australian public to have a look at the underlying deficit, and I can tell you that the underlying deficit is $8.2 billion. That is why financial markets have seen through this budget, and that is why financial markets have not given you the enormous boost that you were hoping for. That is why the negative reaction with the Australian dollar has been to the measure and the order that it is.

One of the sectors of the Australian community that is being hardest hit by this budget is the small business sector. I will illustrate one of the things that has happened to the small business community since this government came to power. When this government came to power, this was the size of the income tax act in Australia. Twelve years later, this is the size of the income tax act in Australia.

If you people opposite understood anything about the operation of a small business, you would understand the enormous paper burden that that kind of burgeoning of the tax act has imposed. Not only have you given them that, you have increased their taxation, you have extended the PAYE tax system and you have imposed an absurd provisional tax uplift factor on them. You are imposing new charges via the Reserve Bank. As David Murray, the managing director of the Commonwealth Bank, said in this morning's Melbourne Age, higher interest rate charges will be a result of those new charges and taxes imposed by the government.

It is almost the ninth anniversary of an interview the then Treasurer, the now Prime Minister, gave on the John Laws program when he declared that unless something were done about Australia's chronic current account deficit this country would become a banana republic. One of the reasons the Australian public is so cynical about you lot opposite, and one of the reasons the Australian public wants to have a change of government, is that nine years later you have done nothing to cure that problem, by the Prime Minister's own admission. In a speech he gave to the Monash University only a short period of time ago, the Prime Minister said that the current account deficit remained Australia's most intractable economic problem.

You pretend that your budget has done something to fix the current account deficit problem. Why is it, then, that you forecast that the current account deficit next year will still be 5.5 per cent of the gross domestic product? Why is it that it will still be the second worst current account deficit in the industrialised world? Why is it that, after nine years of recognising that unless something were done about the current account deficit this country would become a banana republic, you have failed to do anything about it? It remains our biggest challenge.

One of the reasons it remains our biggest challenge is that this government, particularly under the stewardship of Paul Keating as Prime Minister, has gone to sleep on the job of economic modernisation. Some things were done in the early years of this government, under the prime ministership of Bob Hawke. There were one or two things, but they were done a long time ago. Since Paul Keating became Prime Minister, we have gone into reverse on the process of micro-economic reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Hilmer?

—I thought you'd say that. I thought you'd say, `What about Hilmer?' Whenever you talk about competition you say, `Hilmer, Hilmer, Hilmer.' You have to understand that 80 per cent of Hilmer deals with the states and in relation to the bit you are responsible for, like reforming the labour market, you have gone back to the dark ages since the last election. Even your mate Bob Carr, a recently elected Labor Premier, says that the unfair dismissal provisions Laurie Brereton introduced after the last election act as a brake on employment. It is the complete failure of this government under the stewardship of Keating to do anything serious about micro-economic reform which is the major reason the great problem with the current account deficit has not been tackled.

PARA.TAB: By contrast, our position on labour market reform remains clear as a strong, effective alternative. The coalition will reform Australia's arthritic labour market. We will bring about genuine workplace bargaining. The goal of that policy is higher real wages through higher productivity. We will bring balanced unfair dismissal laws. We will not tolerate an unfair dismissal law that actually works as a disincentive for thousands of small businesses throughout Australia to take on more staff. We will do something about Australia's antiquated and out-of-date transport and communications infrastructure.

You can carry on. You can laugh and guffaw but you cannot laugh and guffaw at the fact that in those areas Australia remains well below world best practice. A 1992 survey of ports showed that Sydney had dropped from 24th to 31st in the level of efficiency, that Melbourne had fallen from 28th to 37th and that Melbourne—and this is under your government, not under some other government—was operating at 66 per cent of the efficiency of Auckland and 39 per cent of the efficiency of Antwerp, which is the most efficient port in the world. Those figures demonstrate very clearly that—just as it is in the area of the labour market so it is in other areas—you have failed miserably to bring about the necessary pace of change and reform.

This budget, and the follow up to the budget, has been very big on talk about savings, superannuation and the security of Australians in their retirement. I want to say a couple of words to those people who might be following that debate: what guarantee do those people who think they may benefit from this new plan have that the contributions promised by this government, if it is re-elected, will eventuate against the background of a man who promised you tax cuts before the last election but took them away from you immediately he was re-elected?

Given the track record of this man, there seems to be an absolute guarantee that he will fail to honour his obligation if he is re-elected. I would say to all of those Australian workers that I know what you will end up with if you re-elect this man—you will end up with a situation where you pay the three per cent out of what otherwise would have been a wage increase and he will repudiate his commitment to make a contribution to the fund. That is what he will do. If he is true to form, that is exactly what he will do. Don't anybody who is listening to this broadcast believe that he is going to behave in any other fashion.

I can say to those same people that on a change of government any existing retirement benefits will be preserved. We will introduce, as promised during the last election campaign, a retirement savings account and we will alter the superannuation rules to ensure that superannuation funds are not controlled by trade union officials against the interests of ordinary Australian workers.

Another aspect of the catch-up politics that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have played in this budget is in the area of family policy. I welcome, on behalf of the opposition, the introduction of the maternity allowance. I might observe in passing that one aspect of that maternity allowance was in fact a response to opposition pressure—pressure to make certain that the maternity allowance applied not only to mothers in the paid work force but also to mothers in the unpaid work force.

I also want to say on behalf of the opposition that family policy ought not to be a footnote to industrial relations negotiation between the government and the ACTU. Every time you look at family policy it is not in the context of sitting down and looking at how families are affected by the behaviour of government in all its aspects and manifestations but rather it is a question of how you can skew family policy, how you can mould the needs and concerns of family policy, to suit the rigidity of the industrial relations system. Instead of families being skewed to suit the industrial relations system, the industrial relations system ought to be skewed to suit the needs and the interests of Australian families. So family policy will not be a function of negotiations with the ACTU but will cover all aspects of government policy under the coalition.

There have been many things said about the Prime Minister of this country, and not too many have been complimentary. I thought one of the more interesting things that has been said about the Prime Minister was said last weekend in the Sydney Morning Herald. It was an article written by Donald Horne, who is a former Chairman of the Australia Council. He is not a noted apologist for the Liberal Party. It is fairly well known that Donald Horne does not really agree with me on quite a number of issues of significant debate in Australia at the present time. It was a very interesting and lengthy article about the attitude of the Prime Minister towards arts policy. This is what Donald Horne had to say in the article. He was quoting a conversation with the Prime Minister, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . one of the delights of office was to be sitting up here in the front at Opera in the Park, with the sandwiches and champagne, instead of being out there with the mob, sharing a Mars bar.
That, of course, encapsulates very accurately the arrogance of the Prime Minister, an arrogance that people understand and have come to have contempt for over a long period of time.

PARA.TAB: What has now happened is that it is not only the arrogance of the Prime Minister that the Australian public is unhappy with, it is not only a failure of style; it is also a failure of substance. This budget, in its inadequate response to Australia's economic problems, is a prime example of the failure of not only prime ministerial style but also prime ministerial substance. Many people would acknowledge that arrogance is always offensive, but perhaps it becomes bearable if the person exhibiting the arrogance has something to be arrogant about.

I do not really think the man who gave us the worst recession in 60 years has anything to be arrogant about. I do not think the man who gave us the highest debt levels since the Great Depression has anything to be arrogant about. I do not think the person who gave us the highest unemployment since the Great Depression has anything to be arrogant about. I do not think the man who gave us the highest sustained levels of interest rates has anything to be arrogant about. I do not think the man who is giving us the second worst current account deficit in the Western world has anything to be arrogant about. And I do not think the man who has elevated the breaking of election promises to an art form has anything to be arrogant about.

At the beginning of this speech I set certain tests for this budget. Quite clearly, this budget has failed those tests completely. I believe that the only conclusion the Australian people will draw is that the time has well and truly come for not only new ideas but also new people to govern the affairs of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 31 January 1995:

PARA.TAB: Has his Department placed a moratorium on applications to become a civil marriage celebrant; if so, (a) how long has the moratorium been in effect, (b) why was it imposed, (c) when will it end and (d) are there any special circumstances whereby applications will be processed on grounds of necessity or urgency.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Yes, a moratorium has been placed on the acceptance of applications from persons seeking to become a civil marriage celebrant.
(a) The moratorium has been in effect since 1 November 1993.

(b) The moratorium was imposed both to undertake a review of the policy and procedures in relation to the Civil Marriage Celebrant Program and to allow consideration of a very large waiting list of applications for possible appointment.

Until the moratorium was imposed, the procedure in relation to appointments was for cyclical reviews of federal electorate areas each three years taking into consideration the number of celebrants already appointed to the electorate. Existing celebrants were asked for their views on the need for further appointments. Many suitable applicants were not appointed when account was taken of the location and views of existing celebrants and this led to the accumulation of a large waiting list of applicants. The moratorium is providing an opportunity to clear the waiting list, make more celebrants available to the community, giving greater public choice and access, and introduce more efficient administrative procedures to the program.
(c) The moratorium will be lifted as soon as possible and before the end of this financial year.

(d) As a result of the appointment of suitable applicants from the waiting list a significant increase in the number of celebrants available to the community is occurring. Most if not all areas in Australia will have the services of a celebrant available. During the period of the moratorium it has been possible to make appointments from the waiting list where a genuine and urgent need has occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 6 March 1995:(1) How many Aboriginal pastoral properties (a) are currently held and (b) were previously but are no longer held.

PARA.TAB: (2) With respect to each of the properties referred to in part (1), is he able to provide details of the (a) name, (b) location, (c) size, (d) time of (i) acquisition and (ii) relinquishment, where applicable, (e) title description, (f) cost or details of other methods of acquisition, (g) number of persons (i) living and (ii) working (A) casually and (B) permanently on the property, (h) usage of property including cropping and numbers and types of stock and machinery, (i) annual (i) running costs, (ii) gross profit or loss and (iii) net profit or loss, (j) tax paid, (k) total sum spent on development and the nature of those developments, (l) funding of other costs, including wages, and the source and total of all funding from non-property income generated sources, and (m) housing or workplace buildings which are in breach of local government regulations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the following information in response to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) As at the 30 June 1994 the number of pastoral properties held by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations that were acquired through the Land Acquisition and Maintenance Program (LAMP) is 77.
(1)(b) I am advised that ATSIC is not aware of any pastoral properties, owned by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations through funds made available from ATSIC, that have been sold.
(2) Attached is a list of the properties acquired since 1972 with information on the: property name, location, size, cost, time of purchase, and current use.

In relation to the remaining parts of the question, ATSIC does not have a database in place to enable the level of detail to be provided. Most of this information may be available or obtainable by approaching each holding organisations, however, to obtain this information sought would involve the Commission in considerable research and I am not prepared to authorise the time and resources entailed in collecting the information.

(3) In addition to the information supplied it should be noted that ATSIC only has responsibility for a Land Acquisition and Maintenance Program for a further two financial years (1995-96 & 1996-97). The Indigenous Land Corporation (ILC) will then receive all of the annual draw down of $45 million (indexed). The Act to establish the ILC establishes a framework in the Indigenous Land Corporation will have at its disposal indefinitely a substantial annual sum of money to put towards the restoration and enhancement of the cultural, social and economic well-being of Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders.
The Indigenous Land Corporation's functions in relation to its land acquisition role includes:
purchasing interests in land for the benefit of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander corporations for the benefit of those communities;
transferring land it acquires to Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporations for the benefit of those communities;
making grants to Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporations so that they can acquire interests in land; and
acting as guarantor for loans made by third parties to Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporations so that they may acquire interests in land.

The powers of the Indigenous Land Corporation include the power to make contracts, to invest its money, to appoint agents and be appointed as an agent, to set up companies, to invest in companies, to enter into partnerships, joint ventures and profit sharing arrangements, to accept gifts, grants and bequests, to act as a trustee and to charge for its services. In relation to its functions generally, the Indigenous Land Corporation will act in accordance with sound business principles when operating on a commercial basis.

The Indigenous Land Corporation will be required to prepare and revise regularly a National Indigenous Land Strategy for a three to five year period, covering such matters as the acquisition of land for granting to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander corporations and land management and environmental issues affecting indigenous-held land.

In addition, the Indigenous Land Corporation is required to prepare and revise regularly Regional Indigenous Land Strategies relating to areas whose boundaries it will determine. Like the national strategy, regional strategies will cover a three to five year period and deal with land acquisition and land management and environmental issues in each region. The Corporation must consult with ATSIC Regional Councils on regional strategies.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 6 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) When did the Native Title Act 1993 become law.
(2) How many native title claims have been made and granted since the Act became law.
(3) What are the details of each claim made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lavarch The Hon M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The substantive provisions of the Native Title Act 1993,(except for Part 10) commenced operation on 1 January 1994.

(2) Since 1 January 1994 there have been 61 claims for native title lodged with the National Native Title Tribunal. The Tribunal has not made a determination that native title exists in relation to any of these claims. Three claims have been referred to the Federal Court for determination because they were unable to be resolved by mediation before the Tribunal.

(3) As proceedings in relation to the claims are currently before the Federal Court and the National Native Title Tribunal it is not appropriate for me to provide any detail of the claims, other than information which is publicly available.

There are a number of procedures under the Native Title Act which ensure that those who may be affected by a claim receive information about the claim. When a native title claim is accepted, the Registrar is required to advertise the claim and notify other people who may be affected by the claim. The Tribunal maintains a Register of Native Title Claims which includes a summary of claims accepted for processing by the Tribunal. The register may be inspected by the public in all capital cities on payment of a $20 inspection fee.
In addition the Tribunal maintains a schedule of applications received and an open file for each claim accepted both of which may be accessed by the public.
